PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin (from 209 citizens), Mr Ferguson (from 320 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 162 citizens), Mr Langmore (from 238 citizens), Mr Melham (from 261 citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 191 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That attention is drawn to Australia's location and involvement in the Asia/Pacific region where there exists a number of actual and potential conflicts, along with several countries which can ill afford to pay for the importation of military equipment yet feel obliged to do so.

That Australia is increasing its role in the arms trade in this region, and in particular, it is supporting and participating in AIDEX `91. The arms trade is detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from health, education, social welfare, and is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of people of the Asia/Pacific region.
The petitioners therefore appeal to the Australian Parliament to:
Stop all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.

Direct those Government Departments participating in AIDEX `91, i.e. Defence, Austrade, Industry, Technology and Commerce, to cancel their bookings for space at the exhibition and withdraw their support for AIDEX `91.
Redirect all monies currently being used in promoting the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
Explore the possibilities of setting up an Agency for the development of techniques for conflict resolution.
Increase overseas aid to counteract the reduction since 1983/4.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hand (from 48 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 37 citizens), Mr Melham (from 126 citizens) and Mr Sinclair (from 136 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Abortions: Government Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:

PARA.TAB: Every abortion kills an unborn human baby. More unborn Australians are killed every year (80,000) than the Australian death toll for the whole of World War II (30,000).
Australia's population is aging. Our live birth rate is below replacement level.
About 98 percent of abortions in Australia are performed for non-medical reasons (see SA Health Commission statistics).
Post abortion depression is a silent epidemic and is linked with the growing incidence of child abuse by mothers who have previously had abortions.
The Australian Government should not fund the killing of future Australian citizens.
Mothers with problem pregnancies need positive help to carry their babies to full term.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
pass the Abortion Funding Abolition Bill 1990, and
help pregnant women with problems to continue their pregnancies.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

That our Federal Parliament therefore implement the following policies before 1st January, 2001 AD:
(1)The Adoption of a Christian National Anthem—"God Bless Australia" to the tune of "Waltzing Matilda".
(2)The Adoption of a Christian National Motto—"One Nation Under God", for use on our coins, banknotes, etc.
(3)The appointment of practising Christians as Vice Regal Representatives of our Christian Queen, Elizabeth II.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned petitioners, reject the final report of the Brisbane Airport Task Force, because it failed in its basic charter to "minimise the impact of aircraft noise on surround communities.

It failed to recommend their own conclusions that an extended Cross Runway would "significantly reduce aircraft noise" and that an extended cross runway could operate as the "main or supplementary runway," which, along with the Main Runway would enable 80% or more planes to go in and out over Moreton Bay, as promised.

We urgently request that money be made available for an extended Cross Runway as the most cost effective and practical solution to Brisbane Airport noise and safety.
We also request that changes be made to flight paths over Hemmant, Tingalpa and Bulimba-Balmoral, Morningside areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure on disclosure of in camera evidence and the related minutes.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over a period there have been concerns, particularly since the establishment of a comprehensive committee system in the House of Representatives and as a result of the fact that joint committees do not come under the scope of the Procedure Committee, about the inability of committees to take evidence in private, other than under the rules which have previously applied. The rules for in private—generally called in camera—evidence do not provide protection under circumstances where maximum protection is thought to be desirable. A problem arises because the rules, although they allow the House to authorise a committee to take evidence in camera, do not provide a mechanism whereby the House can prevent a member of the Committee from disclosing that material; there is no provision for penalising a member for disclosing material under privilege.

PARA.TAB: This matter was raised in a letter to the Committee by the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) who expressed his concern about the lack of strength of the privacy provisions for in camera hearings where an undertaking to a person giving evidence was felt necessary. The Committee has considered the whole matter and has found that it is not possible to adjust the existing in-privacy provisions to cover both the normal operations of a committee which may wish to take evidence in private without putting major sanctions on that evidence and a situation where a committee—and many of our committees now deal with commercial confidences and other matters of very serious consequence—wishes to take evidence and protect that evidence to the degree which is desirable.

The recommendations which have been brought forward leave the existing provisions for taking evidence intact: written submissions that the Committee can publish or otherwise according to its own decision; the taking of oral evidence in public, which is the normal way of taking evidence; and taking evidence in private where a witness is informed that the evidence may, on the decision of the Committee, be published or released by the House without prior notification. The Committee recommends that those three existing provisions be maintained.

The Committee has recommended the introduction of a new category of evidence. For the purposes of differentiating I will call it in camera evidence because it more appropriately fits the term `in camera' than the private evidence provisions we have. That provision would allow the Committee, by resolution, to take evidence in a manner whereby the disclosure of that evidence would be prohibited without first obtaining the permission of the person who has given evidence or, in the case of the House determining, without the prior approval of the Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition, the Prime Minister and other officers. The purpose of that is that the House cannot be denied the right to release evidence. But if one gives an undertaking to a witness that evidence will be treated confidentially, the witness is entitled to accept that undertaking. I would expect that committees would only go into those circumstances after due consideration and when it was considered absolutely necessary for evidence vital to their deliberations.

The report also provides fairly severe penalties for members of the House of Representatives who breach those undertakings. Those penalties are clearly set out in the report. This proposal does not, as I have already said, apply to the existing arrangements and this House cannot apply it to joint committees. But one would hope that the joint committee rules and those which are covered by statutory prohibitions could be amended in order to bring in such a procedure.

The report also provides that if there is a criminal offence, or something of a very serious nature, the chairman, with the permission of the committee, can notify the Speaker who would then have to make judgments on what to do. I believe that this provides committees with another means of taking evidence; it does not change its procedures unless the committee wishes to change its procedures; and it offers people who may wish to give evidence under these circumstances the opportunity to do so with some confidence that their evidence will not be disclosed and possibly that their lives or their commercial operations placed in jeopardy. Mr Speaker, I commend the report to the House, and I move:
That the House take note of the report. (Time expired)

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO IRELAND AND THE EUROPEAN INSTITUTIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland and the European Institutions, September 1991. May I particularly acknowledge the presence in the gallery today of the Irish Ambassador, His Excellency Mr Martin Burke, and officers of the Embassy. I would also acknowledge Senator Jim McKiernan's presence in the gallery today. Senator McKiernan was part of our delegation.

PARA.TAB: I will go to some specifics in terms of the issues. We were very pleased that the delegation had the opportunity to visit Ireland and the European institutions. First of all I would like to mention the people whom I think we ought to acknowledge. We ought to acknowledge the deputy leader of the delegation, Senator Baden Teague who, along with his colleagues in the other Parties, made a point of having this as a bipartisan delegation. From the point of Australia being represented overseas, in my view that is very important and I would like to acknowledge it.

I would also like to acknowledge my colleagues Ted Grace, Neil Andrew, Stewart McArthur, Gordon Scholes, Senator Brian Harradine and, of course, Senator McKiernan, the Cavan lad, who is here with us today. I would like to acknowledge their spouses who accompanied us and also particularly our Committee secretaries Richard Gilbert and Albertha Williamson who provided excellent support to the delegation. I particularly thank Richard for having this report ready so quickly.

I should also acknowledge the officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mark Pierce and his group; parliamentary relations officer Richard Coventry, for his support; and our Ambassador in Ireland, Mr Terry McCarthy, and his wife Margaret, who accompanied us on the delegation. I thought that was very valuable. I also acknowledge the help of the Ceann Comhairle, Sean Treacy, who welcomed us at the airport and saw us off there much healthier and happier as a result of our experience.

I want to return to the support given by Martin Burke. We are very grateful for his support, and I think the relationship between Australia and Ireland has been strengthened by his work and, hopefully, by our work in this report. I acknowledge and thank his officer, Ray Bassett, as well. I also thank Mr Jorgensen, EC Ambassador, and Mr Roderick Skinner. For their work in Strasbourg and Brussels, I particularly want to thank Mr Hugh Borrowman; Mr Peter Gallagher, the Charge d'Affaires; Mr Tony Rottier from the OECD; and Mr Bombeek, who provided our transport. All of those people deserve acknowledgment and I thank them for their support.

To get to the substance of the matter, I should begin with the International Fund for Ireland. The delegation is quite unambiguous in its attitude towards the Ireland fund. There was some misrepresentation on one occasion in Australia about the Ireland fund. Delegates went there with an open mind and, as a consequence, I am happy to recommend that, having regard to the beneficial work of the fund in supporting projects such as the canal scheme, and keeping in mind the cultural links which exist between Australia and Ireland, the delegation is of a view that the Australian Government should join its British, Irish, United States, New Zealand and European counterparts in supporting the fund and its projects. The delegation therefore recommends that the Government commence negotiations with both the UK and Irish governments with a view to making a contribution to the International Fund for Ireland.

That view is supported unanimously by the delegation. We came to that view after having seen the value and importance of the work that is undertaken in the north, where there are high levels of unemployment and where people can be offered some future. Australia can provide, in a moral sense and a political sense, support for what we regard as a very important development. I say this for people who would make the observation, `Oh, well, Ireland is one of these rich west European countries'. The response to that is that Ireland, like many countries, is rich in certain respects, but is also bedevilled by high unemployment and by long term historical problems. It is up to people in the Irish diaspora—such as Australia—to be supporting those in Ireland. The delegation is quite unanimous in that view and I believe that our visit there certainly clarified in our minds that that ought to be the case.

We were delighted to have meetings with the Taoiseach, Mr Haughey, and with the President, Mary Robinson. We also had a very valuable visit to the Waterford factory, which enabled us to see a value added product. The original material for crystal is often very cheap but, when the value is added in terms of production, we end up with very high value products; and that was clearly the case. While in Ireland we also visited Biocycle. A briefing given by Biocycle suggested:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . had the Irish principals not proactively pursued the Australian innovation, it would have been some time before the technology reached Europe.
Accordingly, the delegation recommends:
. . . that the government including Austrade, as well as Australian business, take special note of this and pursue market opportunities in Europe in a more proactive and strategic way.

This is not the first time that I have actually had evidence that Austrade is not without blemish. I have to say—and it is a bit sad to say it—that in some areas of the world Austrade does not seem to be doing its job. I do not know why it is and I do not know what the answer to that is. Perhaps the answer is to have people who are more market oriented. Certainly we found both in Europe and Ireland that there were business opportunities for Australia that were not being pursued adequately enough by Austrade. That is obviously not an across the board statement, but it certainly applies to some particular instances.

PARA.TAB: The other point I make about the Irish visit is that I think what we saw was a wide range of the fabric and quality of Irish life. We came away convinced that the relationship between ourselves and Ireland needs to be further strengthened. I return to my comments about the Ireland fund. That fund is a substantial way that we can strengthen our relationship with Ireland.

I move to the European scene. Seventy-three countries were represented at the Strasbourg Conference on Democracy. One country had had representatives for only one week—the Estonians had literally gained their freedom in one week and were represented at the Strasbourg Conference. It was a very worthwhile discussion.

The International Institute for Democracy in Strasbourg asked the Australian Parliament whether it would host a regional colloquy on democracy in 1992. We have recommended to the Presiding Officers that it be actively considered. I believe that was well worth while.

The exchange between ourselves and the European Parliament was very worth while. We covered a wide range of topics, particularly in relation to international relations, relations in the region and GATT negotiations. Mr Lambrias and the President of the European Parliament, Mr Baron Crespo, deserve our thanks. We are delighted to see the Secretary-General of the OECD, Mr Paye, is visiting Australia. That will provide a very good focus for this ongoing discussion. Mr Andrew and I met with Mr McSharry and we had a very good interchange.

I believe one of the outcomes of the attempted coup in the Soviet Union is that there is now a real awareness in Western Europe that it has to do something substantial about trade reform. One of the recommendations we make, incidentally, is that we ought to mount a trade products display in Europe in cities of high unemployment such as Manchester, Liverpool, and Newcastle.

We should be showing the Europeans just how cheaply Australian farmers can provide their products. As the Australian booklet identified, Australian farmers can provide products much more cheaply than the Europeans. We ought not mince words about that. We ought to get on the front foot and show the Europeans that we can actively market unprocessed food in a very active way. I believe that is one of the things we ought to be doing.

It is interesting that there seems to be a lack of understanding about Australia. In another context, I referred to the fact that I believe Radio Australia needs to play a greater role in pursuing our interests in Europe. I think there is a regional focus in this part of the world, but I think it underestimates the importance of the relationship that we have with Europe. Europe is our second largest market, yet our presence there, aside from such things as the Neighbours television program and so on, is somewhat reduced.

The delegation pursued a bipartisan approach on our agricultural concerns in Europe. My colleagues opposite will certainly be adding to that because they did so well when we were away. We must pursue this single view about agriculture in Europe in light of its importance.

In summing up, I believe it was a visit well worth while. I thank those people for their support. I thank particularly my colleagues for their support during the visit and our families for their support, because these visits are not taken without some pressure on families. It is nice to see some families present here today. I think the people who participated in the visit would feel that it was a job well done and worth doing. I certainly look forward to hearing the comments of my colleagues in this debate. I believe that we have made an impact in Europe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) in saying how proud I was as a member of this Parliament to be a part of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland and the European Institutions. I place on record the delegation's thanks to Mr Richard Gilbert for his prompt report, which was tabled today, a short time after the five weeks that the delegation spent in Europe.

PARA.TAB: I also remark on the bipartisan approach of the delegation. The leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Stirling, made the observation that the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and I were particularly interested in agricultural matters. I note the very strong support of Government members on this issue. I think we represented the Parliament in a very unified manner on most of the issues that came before us.
In passing, I acknowledge the helpful support of Mr Bombeek, our bus driver, who added a certain element of friendliness to our visits to both Strasbourg and Brussels.
I also acknowledge the presence of the Ambassador from Ireland here in the gallery and thank him for his hospitality prior to our leaving and again last night.

As honourable members would know, there are very close links between Ireland and Australia. I think the delegation enhanced those longstanding links of Irish ancestry, both to honourable members of this House and to parts of the Australian population. I do acknowledge, like the leader, the contribution of our Ambassador, Mr Terry McCarthy, and Mrs McCarthy. They accompanied the delegation throughout Ireland and were most helpful.

There are 3 1/2 million people in Ireland and, as I say, we do have long associations with Irish history and Irish background. Half of the population lives in Dublin, and we spent some time there becoming familiar with Dublin and its particular approaches. The politics of Ireland are dominated by history and it is very difficult for somebody who is not familiar with the historical background to come to some understanding as to where the political parties stand. It is quite clear that families' historical attitudes are the dominant feature of Irish politics, although there may be some changes now taking place. Obviously, the Anglo-Irish conflict, which has gone on for hundreds of years, still plays a dominant role in the attitudes of the senior politicians and personnel that we met.

In my view, the entry of Ireland to the European common market has made a tremendous difference to the attitude of the Irish. They are now more outward looking in terms of selling their product overseas rather than being dependent on the English market for their products. I support the observations of the leader of the delegation that Australia should contribute to the international fund for Ireland and give tangible support to our longstanding links.

During our visit to Ireland we made some observations about agriculture. From the farm visit we made it was very clear that the housing of stock for 4 1/2 months is a very important feature of Irish agriculture and, of course, the support of the CAP to farmers in Ireland is fairly important. If that is withdrawn, there will be a considerable reduction in living standards for Irish farmers. I acknowledge the great hospitality of all those people we met in Ireland and thank them for the genuine way in which their Ministers and their personnel looked after us on every occasion. We appreciate it.

Moving to Europe—in my view, the attitudes in Europe are dominated by the fact that under no circumstances do those in Europe want another war. Even in 1991, the recollections of the First World War and the Second World War loom large amongst the population and those people we spoke to. Also, the recollections and memories of hunger are still very much a part of those people in Europe—both the older and younger generations—who can recall that food was scarce during the war years. I think that has dominated the attitudes towards the common agricultural policy.

The European Community, consisting of 12 member states, encompasses 340 million people. The attitude is to try to keep the European Community together and to have a free flow of people, goods and services. The attitude is, as I say, dominated by this background that I have mentioned.

I will just refer to the common agricultural policy, with which this Parliament has been concerned. There is a subsidy of about $US60 billion to farmers in Europe. Eight million farmers are looked after by the common agriculture policy. There used to be some 30 million farmers in the 1960s, so there has been a considerable reduction in the numbers of farmers involved. Eighty per cent of the subsidy moves to 20 per cent of the farmers, as always is the case, so that the better farmers receive most of the subsidy. However, the European might in manufacturing and commerce is able to support this sort of subsidy operation, much to the upset of Australian farmers.

The Americans have two million farmers and they are involved in subsidisation of grain in their wheat enhancement programs. Coupled with the CAP, that impacts very poorly upon the Australian farmers and causes them considerable difficulties.

I make the observation that the environmental issues—which are No. 3 in public perceptions, after inflation and unemployment—will be a major factor in the debate about the common agricultural policy. We had evidence that pollution by nitrogenous fertilisers and by pesticides was becoming a very important political factor in the debate. So the pollution of water streams and land would be important in this whole argument.

Intensive livestock production under the CAP policy means a build-up of manure and livestock waste products, another environmental difficulty. There are 83 million head of beef cattle and 23 million head of dairy cattle in Europe. That gives us some indication of the environmental difficulties, especially when the cattle are housed for 4 1/2 months during the winter period. I think there will be public concern about that.

At the Council of Europe, as our leader has mentioned, we attended important discussions. In the OECD debate, on behalf of the delegation I was able to raise with the Secretary-General, Mr John Claude Paye, our attitude to the CAP. I raised the issue of what would happen if the CAP continued discriminating against Third World countries, Australian efficient agricultural producers and other agricultural producers around the world. His answer was—and it is very interesting, because he is a very important person in terms of attitude and opinion forming—that there was a sea change in attitude towards the CAP by the Europeans, that there was a movement to some greater economic rationality, and that, inevitably, these sorts of subsidy arrangements could not continue. His final comment, of course, was that there were more consumers than there were farmers. Inevitably, some more sensible approach might come about.

We visited the European Parliament. We were able to observe the 518 members in action with their five-year election program. I make the interesting comparison that the European Parliament has nine languages to deal with. We have a bit of trouble dealing with just the English language in this Parliament. It was interesting to see the way in which debate took place in nine languages and the interpreters that were required.

The year 1992 looms large as a key date in European thinking. Every objective is close to that date in bringing Europe closer together. The proportional representation approach of the democracies in Europe and the European Parliament, in my view, does not enhance strong government; it moves towards the lowest common denominator, and there is a lot of consensus politics.

There is a split in Europe between Strasbourg, where the European Parliament is, and Brussels, where the Council of Ministers operates and where the real power is. Debate on that will be ongoing. There still remains a conflict in Yugoslavia. The Europeans are moving together, yet Yugoslavia is the centre of a major argument. We had a wonderful briefing from Manfred Woerner at NATO. Some of the issues raised about Russia were certainly enlightening in this era of dramatic change with the Berlin wall going, the collapse of the communist regime and a changed role for NATO. The collapse of the Berlin wall and the quite dramatic change that the whole of eastern Europe is undergoing were reflected in the conversations and briefings we had.

It was a most valuable delegation in terms of the cultural and trade exchanges. It is worthy of note that Australia still maintains very strong trade links with Europe and with Ireland. Whilst we are developing stronger trade with Asia, European capital investment and our relationship with Europe are very strong—by way of both history and our current arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today as a very proud member of this Parliament because I had the great honour of being on the trip to Ireland and Europe and particularly because I was visiting the land of my childhood. Certain people in the gallery will note that I said the land of my childhood, not the land of my birth. But at least I can claim that my background is 100 per cent Irish. My mother has guaranteed me that I was conceived in Ireland. So my accidental birth outside of its boundaries is a cross I have had to bear. Nevertheless, I feel Irish. It sometimes hurts me when I go overseas to be introduced as somebody who was not born of the sod, as they say, but brought up of the sod. Nevertheless, I take no glory away from the only genuine Irish member of the Parliament in Australia. I refer to my colleague Senator Jim McKiernan from the lovely county of Cavan in the mid-north of Ireland.

PARA.TAB: I would like to correct the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), the leader of the expedition, if I may. He stated that we had a great time in Ireland and that we left much healthier. He can speak for himself; I did not leave any healthier at all. I found the hospitality of the Irish very trying—

TALK.START.PARA: —He was diluting the Liffey water.

—Yes, we did indulge in some Liffey water. I do not want to sound frivolous, but there are many members of this delegation who will deal with the serious matters. I was very proud and we had a great, bipartisan delegation. We all got on exceedingly well, led by our Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that impressed me about Ireland this time was the new Ambassador to Ireland, Terry McCarthy. I congratulate the people who instigated his installation in Ireland. I am sure that Terry and his wife, Margaret, will go from strength to strength. It was a pleasure to meet them.

The other highlight when we landed in Ireland, something about which we had to educate our Liberal friends on the other side of the House, was the game of hurling. We had the great honour of attending the All-Ireland Hurling Final. I found out afterwards that we were very privileged because there was a delegation in Ireland from America which could not get tickets. We were very privileged on that score.

The visit of the delegation to Europe occurred during a time of intense debate over the future economic, political and social shape of Europe. For instance, the world has seen immense change in the Soviet Union, especially regarding its role as a superpower. The world is also experiencing difficulties in maintaining and upholding the free trade principle.

Basically, in most of the negotiations that we had in Europe, especially with the European Parliament, we were trying to convince our European friends of what a bad deal we had in Australia. When people in Australia say that we are on a jaunt around the world, it is not quite true. When we try to explain the CAP, people probably think it is the favourite in the 3.30 at Warwick Farm.

Let me explain for the record what it means when we say that European farmers are subsidised. We in Australia can kill a prize beast, dress it up, package it, put it on a first class Qantas seat to Europe and sell it for less than Europeans would pay for meat produced in Europe. We can dig coal up in Newcastle, export it to Europe, put it back down a mine, remine it and sell it cheaper. This gives some idea of how highly subsidised European industrialists and farmers are. But that is not the real problem. The real problem occurs when we try to sell on other markets outside Europe where Europe dumps its surplus stock. That is where the whole problem originates. But I will leave that matter for my other friends to talk about.

I wanted to spend a couple of minutes of my time in supporting the delegation and speaking on the International Fund for Ireland. While I may seem biased, having originated from that part of the world, I think donations to the fund from a country such as Australia would be money well spent. Australia has such a great connection with Ireland. Nearly 40 per cent of our people have some Irish connection. I think that is a great contribution from a small country such as Ireland—immaterial of the circumstances at the time that drove the Irish to this country. Nevertheless, we pride ourselves in being the main movers in the establishment of this great country that we now call home.

The money being spent is peanuts. The European Common Market, or European Community—which, incidentally, includes Great Britain—spends #10.7m sterling; the United States, a very rich country, spends #10m sterling; Canada subscribes #430m sterling; and our neighbours in New Zealand, who do not have the same connection with Ireland, see fit to spend #120,000 sterling. I think it would be very befitting of this country to make a contribution. I will not suggest an amount of money; I will leave that to my parliamentary colleagues. I strongly recommend, in support of our chairman, that we should be spending money on a country such as Ireland because of the deprivation that has always existed there. Honourable members should remember that some people, such as Senator Jim McKiernan and I, did not come to this country originally because we thought it was the greatest country in the world; we came because there was nothing in our homeland. It is only by accident that we came to the other great country in the world. I really plead with my parliamentary colleagues to look very seriously at the International Fund for Ireland and make a subscription, hopefully in the next Budget.

For me personally, my return to Europe was a nostalgic one. I would just like to spend a few minutes on some of the things that happened to me in Ireland and in Europe, and on one of the reasons why it was so fulfilling for me. My grandfather disappeared in the First World War as a young man of 19, and he was never found. My family never had the resources to carry on and find out what happened to him. It was left to his grandson some 70-odd years afterwards to find his name on the Menin Gate, which is the entrance to the Fields of Flanders where the massacres of the First World War happened. We found the name. I was not quite sure that it was his, but the Commonwealth War Graves Commission has since confirmed that the name on there is indeed my grandfather's. I would like to thank publicly the Commonwealth War Graves Commission for its help. Roger Dalley showed us around the fields in Europe and particularly the largest graveyard of Australians. It holds 13,000 young Australians who gave their life for freedom and are now buried in the Fields of Flanders. It was a very moving experience, and probably such experiences dictate my anti-war attitude. We also visited an ex-concentration camp. It was a very moving experience but, I would not want to go there again. Nevertheless it was probably worth seeing it and noting what man's inhumanity to man achieves.

I just want finally to point out an `error' made by Richard Gilbert, and I congratulate him on his prompting me. His `mistake' is on page 54. The photograph there—I will not say which character in the photo I am referring to —should actually be of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur)!

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in this debate on the report of the parliamentary delegation to the European Parliament. Much has been said on the matter and, although I would like to avoid repeating what my colleagues have said, inevitably there will be some repetition in the comments I want to make.

PARA.TAB: I consider myself very fortunate to have been a part of this 1991 delegation. I believe that the one point that characterised this delegation was the timeliness of the visit. I found myself, as someone whose background is not Irish but who was there as a visitor, fascinated by Ireland and many of the preconceived ideas I had about that country were inevitably shot out of the water by the experience I had as a member of this delegation.

On the delegation there were three people—Senator Harradine, Senator McKiernan and the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace)—who knew a great deal about Ireland because their families had direct links with Ireland. We can tell when they stand to speak in this chamber or in the other place that that odd accent they have comes from somewhere other than Australia.

Visiting Ireland was an experience of being showered with hospitality that made me—a non-Irish person, not one of the 40 per cent of Australians fortunate enough to have direct links with Ireland—feel very much at home. I want to join my colleagues in expressing our appreciation to Ambassador Martin Burke for all that he did prior to our departure for Ireland to see that we were adequately briefed on the things that we might experience there. I want to express, too, my appreciation to the Irish Government for all that it did to make us feel so very much at home.

I place on record the delegation's appreciation to the Irish Government for selecting Miss Louise Tobin to accompany the delegation throughout its tour in Ireland. I would be grateful if the Ambassador could also bear in mind the fact that the delegation is indebted to Louise. No-one could have done more to make us feel at home and no-one could have done more to ensure that all of our needs were met, but all of that was done in a most unobtrusive way. Most significantly of all, we discovered that invariably if we thought there was something that we might need, Louise had already anticipated that need and taken steps to ensure that it was met. I also want to embrace the remarks of previous speakers and acknowledge the very valuable role being played by Ambassador Terry McCarthy, the Australian Ambassador now located in Dublin. His is a relatively recent appointment. It is obvious that he is very pleased to be appointed to Dublin, and he will really strengthen Australia's present links with Ireland.

For me the tour of Ireland was an excellent backdrop to the European Parliament, and it was a learning experience. As someone who had not previously visited Ireland, I had no idea just how much was being done in Ireland to make it an efficient and effective member of the European Community.

I think everyone in the delegation was surprised at the computer-based industrial development that has now made Ireland rival the rest of the European Community in this particular area. All of us were delighted at the dock redevelopment that we visited. In fact, many of us this morning are wearing the ties that we were presented with during that visit. I endorse the remarks that have been made by my colleagues about the International Fund for Ireland and the work that we saw that fund doing in canal development to the north of Dublin.

I particularly want to make a comment or two about agriculture in Ireland. I am grateful to my colleague the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for his support in ensuring that the Irish Government was prepared to find an Irish farmer who would host the delegation. It was a real experience to visit farmer John Ryan's farm and discover just how much Irish farmers are like Australian farmers. Their farm practice may be different and inevitably the weather and the climate demands that much of what they do is done in an environment quite foreign to Australians, but their hopes and aspirations are just the same as the hopes and aspirations of so many of my constituents and the constituents of the honourable member for Corangamite. They seek to have a property that they will pass on to their children in better shape than they inherited from their forebears.

It was to the Ryan's great credit that they were not only hospitable in the traditional Irish way, embarrassingly so, but also that they were keen to show us all both the pitfalls and the advantages of being a farmer in Ireland. I believe the honourable member for Corangamite would agree that it was for us a real learning experience and timely in that it provided just the backdrop we needed prior to travelling to Strasbourg and participating in the European Parliament.

The feature of attending the European Parliament for me was once again that this was such a timely visit. I am indebted to the leader of the delegation, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) because it was possible for him and me to meet Agricultural Commissioner McSharry who happens also to have been the agriculture Minister in Ireland. I think Australians should pay tribute to Commissioner McSharry because he is proposing changes in the EEC that are electorally unpopular but fundamentally responsible.

I think there has been far too much focus in Australia, particularly in the last two months, on what is seen as the USA's attack on Australian farmers and far too little focus on the simple reality that we are in fact caught as farmers not as a result of what the USA is doing but as a result of the pressure that exists between the USA and the EEC.

This was a timely visit for me because I discovered that all the Government has been saying and all the Opposition has been saying about keeping the GATT negotiations alive was absolutely right. How does anyone in Australia suppose we can generate the $40 billion or $50 billion currently being spent in farm support in the EEC? All sorts of statistics have been given this morning, but I leave the Parliament with this sobering statistic: the annual subsidy for each dairy cow in the EEC is greater than the per capita income of half of the world's population. We cannot match that sort of subsidy.

The only chance Australian farmers have to continue to operate while waiting for subsidies to be reduced is the GATT round. Meeting with Commissioner McSharry and with the European Parliament reinforced for me the importance of the GATT round and the importance of keeping those negotiations alive.

Time will run away from each of us participating in the debate on this report on our visit to the EEC. I would not want to focus solely on the European Parliament. I want to stress, as my previous colleagues have, the importance for me of the conference on democracy. I echo the sentiments of our leader. It was a rather sobering experience to be there and to realise that many countries participating in this conference on democracy were countries for whom democracy was a very recent experience.

Most of all, I found the briefing from NATO invaluable because, once again, it was timely for us to be in Europe. We were in Europe just as the dilemma that still persists in Yugoslavia was beginning to emerge. We were there to experience how the Europeans feel about all the changes that have occurred in Russia. It was valuable for someone like me, who presumed that NATO may no longer have a role, to discover that while NATO recognises that its role will be geared down, nonetheless it continues to have a very important role in Europe in keeping Europe stable in all the uncertainty that currently dominates the Russian landscape.

Given that Russia is moving into winter, and that we cannot expect democracies to survive where people starve, the responsibility Europe has on behalf of the rest of the world to ensure that some of its food surpluses find their way into Russia cannot be overstated. I found it timely to be in Europe and to be speaking to NATO at a time when it is grappling, in tandem with the European Parliament, with how the real needs of the Russian people will be met in order to keep democracy alive and well in Russia.

I, too, wish to pay tribute to my colleagues who made bipartisan travel such a pleasure. I wish to thank Mr Gilbert for all he has done in producing such a timely report. He has said that he enjoyed being part of the delegation. I am not quite sure why because he was the one who had to be up first in the morning to ensure that all the delegation's needs were met. We are grateful to him for all that he did.

I would like to conclude by echoing the sentiments of the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace). It was, for all of us, a very sobering experience—those children in the gallery might be interested to consider how sobering it was—to stand at the Menin Gate and see the names of thousands of Australians who have no graves in Europe because no trace was found of them at the end of the First World War. To consider that that was what war once did was, for all of us, a very sobering experience. The honourable member for Fowler is not alone in his abhorrence of war. I expect every one of the Australians who suffered there shared the attitude of the honourable member for Fowler.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to make a few remarks on the delegation to Ireland and the European Community. Like most working class Australians, particularly coming from Victoria, I have some Irish connections, although I think my family is basically English. My paternal grandfather was named O'Brien, which is an unusual Irish name! But I never met him because he was killed in France in 1916 during the First World War.

PARA.TAB: The visit to Ireland highlighted a number of things: the importance of the European agricultural policy to its member states, and the difficulties which would arise and will arise if that policy is materially changed. It also highlighted the fact that whilst Ireland has been a major beneficiary in the farm subsidy area, and also has been able to attract substantial and important industries because of its position in the EEC and its early membership, there are problems for other sections of the European Community.

Right across Europe the question of employment appears to be as great a problem, although not as heavily discussed as it is in Australia. In Europe there are currently of the order of nine million guest workers. There is approximately 12 1/2 per cent unemployment.

While we were in Europe French farmers attacked trucks carrying produce from Britain —another EEC area—because they were coming into their areas and the French farmers thought they were threatening their living standards and their entitlement to their markets. They are problems we all know about here and are problems that are not going to be easy to resolve. They will make it difficult for internal governments—I agree with the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) on this point—which are relatively weak because of an electoral system which guarantees that there cannot be majority governments or that majority governments are almost impossible to achieve.

In Europe there is another problem which may be corrected, but at this stage it does not appear likely to be corrected in the short term; that is, the lack of a representative decision making government with authority over the bureaucracy that runs Europe. There is a ministerial council, but that is a bypassing of democracy rather than an element of democracy. It enables a group of Ministers to meet and to make decisions which become binding on their parliaments. That is not the way in which I understood democracy to work. The European Parliament at this stage is a talk shop, and that is unfortunate because it will be necessary for Europe, if it is to have more unity, to have a representative form of government which has authority over the policies which are adopted.

We had meetings with numbers of people, probably more than could be dealt with in a report and more than can be adequately dealt with in a short debate. The primary element of our visit—this has been covered by all speakers—was to deal with the problems of European subsidies and European and American destruction of third markets. In Ireland we were told that surpluses were being created in some European countries, and I will not mention them, where cattle were being lot fed with American dumped grain and then sold into third markets with European subsidies. There was never any economic basis for the cattle at all but, quite seriously, that is the stupidity of Europe at the moment.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The time for this debate has expired.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 September, on motion by Dr Catley:
That the House take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies was tabled on 12 September. My colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) gave a tabling speech in my absence. This report, part of the broad subject, `Australia as an Information Society', is entitled The Role of Libraries/Information Networks. The honourable member for Adelaide in his speech foreshadowed that I would deal with the recommendations when I entered the debate.

PARA.TAB: A few words about the context of this second report would be appropriate. In our first report we concluded that Australia was an information society already, but rather a passive one, marked by extreme fragmentation in which the organisation and control of information was widely dispersed, with no overall policy framework. There is an extraordinary ambiguity in information. It has the capacity to be centralised, shoring up existing power structures, or it can be extremely dispersed and promote personal autonomy. Which model do we want? Up to now, we do not say.

We recommended the adoption of a national information policy and urged recognition of the centrality of information as a factor in production, employment, trade, education, culture, media ownership and control, social justice, government, and national autonomy. We were not urging a rigid centralised system of control on information—far from it—just that there ought to be a recognition by government, Parliament and the community of the importance of information and information issues, and that failure to respond was to Australia's detriment.

Our third report, still to be written, will examine the `Yes, Minister' problem, the inequity in access to information in government and the risk that the Parliament's role will become increasingly peripheral. The second report, The Role of Libraries/Information Networks, must be seen in the context of the first and even the third reports. There is no national library policy, any more than there is a national information policy. We need both. Libraries are the Little Orphan Annies of government. They are an obvious starting point for an effective national information network.

The Committee's main recommendation calls for the development of a national library policy and for the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), or indeed the Minister at the table, the Minister for the Arts, Tourism, and Territories (Mr Simmons), to make a detailed statement about the adequacy of existing library and information networks. The Committee also calls for the development and provision of libraries and information services to be placed on the agenda of a Special Premiers Conference.

Because of the fragmentation of responsibility for various aspects of information in the Commonwealth system, no Minister has responsibility for libraries. One Minister, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has responsibility for one institution, the National Library of Australia, but no general responsibility for libraries. The States and local government bear the cost—the heavy cost of providing library services. But has the question of libraries, and

SPEECH.PARA: library funding, ever been placed on the table at a Premiers Conference? No, it has not. This is a classic illustration of the old adage `out of sight, out of mind'.

PARA.TAB: As the honourable member for Adelaide pointed out, the Whitlam Government in 1975 established a committee chaired by Allan Horton which produced the valuable report Public Libraries in Australia. While some elements of the 53 recommendations have been adopted piecemeal since then, the central thrust—the need for a national perspective—has been ignored. Since 1976 the demand for public library services has increased enormously, and the cost of books has risen even faster. Nevertheless, increases in public funding for libraries have been extremely modest. We pointed out in paragraph 1.14:

SPEECH.PARA: The Horton Committee estimated (6.7) that to meet the library needs of local government—
local government, not the States—
an additional $50m in 1975 prices would be needed over a 10-year period to reach an acceptable standard.

That is $500m over a decade in 1975 dollars. In Queensland, for example, between 1976 and 1989, there was a 60 per cent increase in book use. That is characteristic of what happened in the other States.

PARA.TAB: There has been an explosive increase in publication worldwide, a phenomenon often referred to as the information explosion. The figures provided indicate that the National Library, CSIRO and 18 Australian universities are now able to buy fewer monographs and current series titles, that is, journals and the like, than they were in 1976.
I seek leave to include in Hansard figure 1, Comparative changes in library acquisition costs, and table 2, Acquisitions from the National Library, CSIRO and 18 university libraries.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This problem can only be overcome on the basis of sharing, using comparative cooperative networks. The most obvious example of networking is one that we are very familiar with here, the relationship between the National Library of Australia and the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library. If the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and I want to pore over a Gutenberg Bible, we do not need to have two, provided we can both have access to one. But the question is how effective the networking can possibly be.

PARA.TAB: We reviewed the Horton Committee very closely and recommended adoption of its main principles. The first three are probably the most important: firstly, the provision of public library and information services should be the collective responsibility of the Commonwealth, States and local levels of government, funded in part by each of these levels of government; secondly, the provision of equality of service on the basis of reasonable need should be ensured by the Commonwealth and State governments; thirdly—about which we have to put a caveat—the provision of basic public libraries and information services should be free of charge to all members of the community. Perhaps if we underline the word `basic', the concept of free provision follows. But if there is one area in which we tend to converge, it is that we can no longer expect absolutely free service in every area; that there has to be, where appropriate, some element of user pays. So whilst supporting the last principle in general, the Committee recognised that appropriate changes will be required to meet special needs involving significant use of resources.

As the Committee indicated in its report, paragraph 1.23, in discussions with the Committee in June 1991 Allan Horton estimated that only eight of the recommendations—17, 18, 24, 29, 30, 36, 37 and 38—had been implemented. Thirteen had been implemented in part—4, 5, 10, 13, 14, 16, 25, 26, 27, 28, 33, 35 and 42—and the rest were either ignored or overtaken by events. He thought that the most significant achievement was the establishment of the Australian bibliographic network, or ABN. Begun in 1981 on the recommendation of the National Library of Australia, it changed the face of library services in Australia, allowing for greater efficiencies in cataloguing and acquisition, minimising duplication and offering the possibility of a distributed national collection. It was the basis of the cooperative and coordinated approach recommended by the Committee of inquiry.

One of the other factors that we wanted to comment on was of course the role of libraries as a factor in combating illiteracy. The Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, in its recent report Words at Work, stated that we have in Australia something of the order of one million adult illiterates. Remember of course that literacy is a moving target. Once the old UNESCO test of the ability to read and write a simple letter was enough. But now, in an increasingly complex society, the ability to be able to read directions, the ability to be able to read a label, the ability to be able to understand the form that one is filling in is increasingly important, so the question of literacy is a moving target. It is very much to our national detriment if we do not make sure that we are able to use the existing resources effectively to deliver services. I see from the clock that time is running out. I seek leave to re-enter the debate at a later hour.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second report by the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies. This report, entitled The Role of Libraries/Information Networks, has been produced in conjunction with the previous report, Australia as an Information Society: Grasping New Paradigms, which was tabled on 6 June this year. The first report has been generally well received by the community, certainly among professionals and specialists who deal in information and in certain sections of the media. We are as yet to receive any formal response from the Government, and this is awaited with great interest.

PARA.TAB: There is a great responsibility upon the Government to take these reports very seriously. This goes for the Opposition too, even though it has no legislative need to respond formally. In mentioning the first report, I would like to make it clear to my colleagues that both these reports should be seen in conjunction with each other; they are part of a series. Let me reiterate some of the themes raised on that first report to put the matter into some context. Together with the rest of the developed world Australia is an information society. Incredibly, 40 per cent of our labour force is employed in the collection, processing and dissemination of data or knowledge.

Yet in this context, we are also defined as a passive information society. We are net importers of information and information technology. Unlike similar small countries, such as Sweden, Switzerland and Holland, we do not have a highly developed ideas and information based export economy. Our export base remains rural and dependent on our raw materials to a remarkable degree, with a very questionable future outlook.

In the move to create `the clever country', it is crucial that we come to terms with the fact that in today's world the main players are those who deal with knowledge and information most intelligently and in a significantly imaginative way. If we become a `smart country', then our export opportunity in the field of information technology—either in software or hardware—should be boundless. The role our libraries have to play is vital in this process. It is a good starting point. As Deputy Chairman of the Committee, I commend the Committee for having undertaken to pursue the topic on libraries as a matter of top priority.

Australia is estimated to be blessed with some 14,000 libraries, with a total stock of some 75 million volumes. This is an enormous national resource and, as such, this report seeks to bring to the attention of Government and the Parliament the fact that something must be done in the name of preserving, maintaining and renewing this resource in the most practical way, given the excitingly new and futuristic technology that already exists.

Some 16 years ago Prime Minister Gough Whitlam commissioned the then librarian of the University of New South Wales, Allan Horton, to head a committee of inquiry into public libraries in Australia. The Horton report made some 53 recommendations, which unfortunately were not taken up by successive governments. This is regrettable because the situation we find ourselves in today is that libraries have experienced an extraordinary growth in demand and are finding it tough going indeed in providing the level of service that is expected of them with their limited and stretched resources.
The Pro-Vice Chancellor's (Research) Committee, the university body, met recently, and in reference to university libraries—I quote from the Canberra Times of 29 August 1991 —said:

Old equipment and inadequate library and computer resources, the legacy of dwindling infrastructure dollars hampered research in Australian universities seriously . . . Australia's international competitiveness could suffer as a result.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Max Neutze, the Committee Chairman, went on to say:

PARA.TAB: As a result, library resources and computer facilities are inadequate, buildings are overcrowded, and poorly maintained, and equipment is often out of date. Australian research cannot keep up with its international competitors and train post graduates if it has to be done on outmoded equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a regrettable situation where some of the best minds and skills we have in this country have to be constrained in their advance by something as basic as the lack of adequate information resources.

PARA.TAB: The report before the House, The Role of Libraries/Information Networks, puts forward several recommendations. Following the speech by the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), there is no need to go into each recommendation in detail. The report is readily available and all honourable members of the House should be reading it.

The report before the House seeks to redress a situation which has essentially been one of neglect by past Commonwealth governments. The report calls on the Government to take a more active and concentrated approach than it has done hitherto on our libraries and information systems. It calls for the Commonwealth Government to take the lead in formulating a coordinated national approach. As it is, our library and information sources lie dispersed and relatively uncoordinated at a national level. With a more coordinated approach, we could and should see the development of a national databank. This is vital to Australia's future and should not be regarded as a mere collection of words.

With specialist knowledge being developed within institutions, and with inter-institutional access to information, we might manage to cut out the enormous amount of duplicated work that currently goes on. A lot of this ground had been covered by the Horton report recommendations. Nevertheless, the report by this Committee is not just a rehash of Horton's recommendations, tragic though it was that they were taken little notice of during the past 16 years.

In 16 years a great deal has changed and the context of information and information systems is wholly different today to what it was in the mid-1970s. The essential recommendations and tenets put forward by Horton still hold true and we look forward to a response on the matter from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), despite the very limited responsibility she has in the field of libraries, in the not too distant future, or even if we could hear from her office.

I am grateful for the great opportunity afforded to us as members of the Committee to discuss these issues at length with librarians and information professionals across the length and breadth of this country. It is a little disconcerting to see the onus that is put on librarians to be current with information. Clearly, there is a need for specialists within the domain of information services, and what should develop is accessibility to this specialist information. Technology allows to us to do it but no-one seems to be listening.

In my closing remarks, I again thank my colleague the honourable member for Lalor for his unfaltering chairmanship. I also thank the State librarians and others in the profession who gave the Committee their time and provided us with such detailed and thorough submissions. I thank those who assisted the Committee in the compilation of the information, particularly the staff, Mr Ian Dundas, Ms Kelly Fitzsimmons and Ms Margaret Swieringa, for their outstanding dedicated service.

In dealing with libraries and information networks in our society, let us not forget that they were originally intended to be `food for the soul'—or nutrimentum spiritus, as I think the Latins used to say—as still inscribed at the State Library of Berlin, or as `medicine for the soul', as it was inscribed at the great library at Thebes all those years ago. The old dictum that an ignorant and/or illiterate society is an oppressed society is part of the philosophy which underlies what we have been trying to achieve.

There is so much more to be said and there is so much more to be learnt. I am looking forward to participating in our next report. The degree of enthusiasm that comes from each and every member of the Long Term Strategies Committee, which was formed by the honourable member for Lalor, should be stated in this House. In my closing remarks, I congratulate him on his appointment to the board of UNESCO in Paris, while he was working on this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his tabling speech on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) stressed the relationship of this report, The Role of Libraries/ Information Networks, to the first report, Australia as an Information Society: Grasping New Paradigms. Clearly, both reports are interrelated with Australia's trade situation. Paragraph 1.8 of the first report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a passive information society and needs to make an urgent transition . . . unless it is to become marginalised internationally.
It further commented:
In information technology alone, Australia is a net importer with a trade deficit each year estimated (depending on the IT definition used) of between $4 billion and $8 billion.

This week—it depends on the definitions used—the EPAC report on the OECD survey of a variety of countries was certainly an indictment of Australia's performance in this greatly expanding sector of world trade. In the Age of 11 November it was noted that in 1989-90 we had a trade deficit of about $12 billion in this area.

PARA.TAB: Australia's percentage of exports of technologically sophisticated goods is 0.2 per cent compared with Hong Kong's 1.9 per cent and Austria's 1.1 per cent. Looking at international comparison, the Congressional Office of Technology Assessment in the US commented that world trade and intellectual property impact on more than 2.2 per cent of the US labour force and 5 per cent of its gross national product. Exports of intellectual property are 25 per cent of US exports.

In this report and the related reports that have been produced, we are not just talking about libraries' impact on recreation, informing citizens about events in the country and helping their particular localised businesses; we are talking about an issue that is central to Australia's international trade. That should reinforce the demand of previous speakers that these reports be taken note of.

There have been previous references to the Horton report, which indeed, as the honourable member for Cook (Mr Dobie) said, certainly led to a very sad performance by a variety of governments. It took a period of 67 months for the final in a series of Ministers to come back and report the findings of an interdepartmental review of the Horton report. Indeed, it is a fairly shocking situation for any government when such a central report to our nation's good should be shovelled off in such a fashion. I should say in passing, however, that the Horton report was not a total waste of time, for on page 6 of our report we note:

SPEECH.PARA: The activity in the States however stands in contrast to the failure of the Commonwealth to make a significant response.
So indeed the Horton report did have an impact on the thinking of a variety of State libraries, and it did cause some of the changes made.

PARA.TAB: The Committee made a variety of suggestions. Obviously they largely involve expenditure of money. I will briefly go through some of them. One of the points that was made was the very great disparity in funding throughout Australia between regions and between municipalities. The figures range from $5 to $40 per capita. It is advocated that to overcome that unevenness in library networks there should be an acknowledgment that this vital national need is indeed the responsibility of all levels of government.

Coming from an electorate that includes the Parramatta library system, I find this of particular importance because that library system, whether under liberal or independent administrations, has been indicted as Sydney's worst. It is typical of what happens with the duplication of systems that Holroyd and Baulkham Hills, previously being part of the joint effort, broke away from it because of its inept management of its responsibilities.

Another central point that we make is the need to develop the Australian bibliographical network. I note that its tenth anniversary was this year. It has managed to catalogue eight million records with a yearly input of a further one million. I think it is very central that the Government does indeed put funding towards this national need. I also note that in its report of its 10 years it comments on a point that we make, that there is a growing demand for script other than Roman. That again relates to another matter that we raise, the particular need for an emphasis on Asian materials. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to speak this morning on the report of the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies entitled Australia as an Information Society: The Role of Libraries/Information Networks. This report should not be seen in isolation. Rather, it should be seen as the second report of the Long Term Strategies Committee's investigations into Australia as an information society.

PARA.TAB: The first report, tabled on 6 June 1991, dealt with the broader question of the increasingly important role of information to our economy, our democratic institutions and our national well-being. This second report looks at the role and future development of libraries in great detail. The Committee has concentrated its attention on the important matters which have remained unresolved since the Horton inquiry into public libraries was presented in 1976.

In singling out libraries for particular attention, the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies has acknowledged the important role they have to play in providing access to information for Australian citizens. Access to information is most important in a vibrant democracy and is important to our social and economic development.

In principle, I support the recommendations of the Committee as detailed in the report. However, I do have a number of concerns about the direction of the Long Term Strategies Committee in its deliberations on this matter. I am concerned that too much emphasis has been placed upon the issue of funding. I happen to believe that the Long Term Strategies Committee should be looking at the broader issues, and to this end I believe that the Committee should have given more consideration to the issue of technological change as it affects the role and future development of libraries.

As a Long Term Strategies Committee, we need not confine ourselves to the issues of today and, in particular, to the day-to-day budgetary issues confronting libraries in 1991. It is very appropriate for us to look to the future and to inquire into the future needs of libraries, librarians and library users. In this regard I am concerned that this report falls short of the mark.

The rapid development of technology has had and will continue to have a major impact on the library industry. Honourable members are well aware of the impact of computers on all Australians. Many Australians now have a computer at home and nearly all have some access to a computer at either school or work, or perhaps at their local library. Australians are already studying at American universities via their home computer linked by telephone and modem. The role of libraries in such technological and educational advances should be the subject of review by the Long Term Strategies Committee. We need not restrict our thinking or our investigations.

Education, in particular tertiary education, is one of the growth industries of the 1990s and this will continue into the twenty-first century. Libraries should play an important role in this area and there is a golden opportunity for Australia to take a lead in this regard. It is the responsibility of the Long Term Strategies Committee to look at these new and challenging opportunities. The brief of this Committee is much wider and less restricted compared to other standing and select committees of this Parliament.

In the context of Australia as an information society, libraries and library professionals have an all-important role to play, but we must be careful that the search for the elusive dollar does not become the main issue. It is not the role of the Long Term Strategies Committee to act as a budgetary watchdog for libraries, yet most of the recommendations contained in this report relate to funding. I believe that the Committee must adopt a wider approach to such issues.

Whilst I have some concerns about the direction of the report, I recognise that it is an important document for all library professionals and library users. This report is only the third major review of Australia's library system and therefore is of great importance to that industry. In many respects, the report is a reconsideration of the Horton inquiry report tabled in April 1976 but never acted upon. It is important to note that the Horton Committee recommended nine broad guidelines as the basis for assisting public libraries, and the Long Term Strategies Committee reviewed those guidelines and endorsed them. Other members have offered detailed comments regarding the recommendations of the Committee but I do not have the time to do this.

In conclusion, I urge the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to take note of the main recommendations of this report. I look forward to monitoring the progress of the development of a national library policy. I trust and hope that this report will not suffer the same fate as the 1976 Horton report.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I thought the indication was that there would be time this afternoon; I have only two minutes now. However, I take up the point made by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). Curiously, comparatively little was raised on those technological issues in the actual submissions. To some degree we are limited by that. Of course, it is the sort of issue that we ought to be talking about in the Long Term Strategies Committee generally. I accept that view completely.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I think it is also fair to say that the primary emphasis of the report was not on providing an additional quantum of money. If the networking is right and we spend $X on facilitating networking, then it may not be necessary to spend $2Xm or $3Xm on book stock. Perhaps again that is an area where, if we had had a longer period for discussion within the Committee itself, that could have been developed. As I mentioned earlier, there is a higher degree of political consensus on this issue. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) played a significant role historically in this matter. We all accept that the Commonwealth cannot be regarded as a milch cow from which we just squeeze out the nutrients that other people use. We have to be able to use our existing resources more effectively; hence the emphasis on networking rather than simply increasing the quantum.

However, I am also concerned that, although we have this extraordinarily rich facility, the extraordinarily rich facility is not being used effectively. Somehow it has to be put much higher in the thinking of government; it has to be very high on the national priorities. The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons), who is at the table, and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly), as the senior Minister in the Department, have a very important role to play—but not in isolation. As we said in the earlier report, we have this extraordinary fragmentation in the area. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has a different view of what an `information' means, as do all the other departments. We need to bring them together.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption of debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House commends Australian agriculturalists on the voluntary reduction in toxic pesticides used in primary production over the past 20 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pick up a comment or two unrelated to this debate which were made by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). He pointed out that there is a good deal of consensus in this House on a number of issues. He was talking specifically about information exchange, but those of us who are participants in the political process know that, contrary to popular opinion, there is a great deal of consensus in the chamber on a vast range of issues. In fact, the bulk of legislation introduced by the Government is supported by the Opposition. One does not spend long in this chamber before one discovers that there are no easy labels and that there are not simply goodies and baddies on the respective sides. But it strikes me that in one area of society people are, in the present environment, automatically labelled as baddies. This morning I want to put in a word or two for the so-called baddies who use the toxic pesticides in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The popular impression abroad is that agriculturalists, once they `take' a can of concentrated insecticide, are somehow seen by society at large as addicted.
