It is imagined that, like druggies who cannot get off their particular addiction, agriculturalists simply have to use pesticide because they love to pour it out, and that the consumer is the one who suffers. The purpose of my motion is to point out the nonsense that currently pervades the community when members of the community imagine that agricultural chemicals in Australia are somehow doing the food chain harm.

Frankly, the so-called baddies, the users of agricultural chemicals, are the very people who least want to use them, who minimise the use of them and who are most anxious to reduce the use of them. Mr Deputy Speaker, put yourself, if you will, in the position of a farmer forced, for example, to drench his sheep, or a fruit grower forced, by reason of the crop that he is producing, to sit in a tractor seat with a machine behind him blowing out concentrated agricultural chemical and obliged to spend the day in a fog of agricultural chemical. It is not a situation he wants. Frankly, it is a situation that he wants to avoid. So I want to put on the record the real effort that has been made by Australian agriculture to minimise chemical use, and the success of that approach.

I want to point out to consumers that Australian produce that they are consuming is not only absolutely safe but also safer than products available from the rest of the world. More than that, 99.9 per cent by weight of the chemicals ingested by Australians occur naturally. I think that too few people appreciate that the responsible legislation in Australia is such that chemical companies are obliged to spend at least $25m per annum on developing chemicals that will have a minimum toxic effect on Australians, and it should be pointed out that every chemical must meet what is called the `no observed adverse effect level'. That level is then reduced by 100 times before the chemical is made available for registration.

But even if this level of regimentation did not apply, we would still have the situation in which primary producers around Australia are determined to reduce their pesticide use, and have successfully done so. People should be more aware of the fact that over the last two decades broad-based agricultural chemicals used to clean up a range of agricultural pests have now all but disappeared. The chemicals that were once found in every farmer's shed—gusathion and parathion, with which the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) would be familiar—are now rarely used. That is because they have been replaced by chemicals that are specifically designed to target the pest that is causing the farmer concern and would, of course, reduce the crop that he has available to sell.

In place of broad-based agricultural chemicals, all farmers now practise integrated pest management techniques. Why? Because the farmer does not want to expose himself to the chemical levels of the past. Of course, having in the past been obliged to use chemicals at a particular level, he was then obliged, quite rightly, to market fruit which did not have more than the allowable residual levels of chemicals on it. So he found himself in a bind. How could he clean up his pest problems without exceeding the minimum allowable levels? Today, every farmer, particularly the fruit farmer, is involved in some form of integrated pest management. Today, far from using broad-based chemicals, farmers are using chemicals that are targeted specifically to a particular pest. With the integrated pest management techniques, what farmers rely on intentionally is accurate timing for chemical use. It is by no means rare when making one's way around an orchard to find various lures in the trees. With these lures the farmer can, by means of either a molasses bait or, in some cases, something as simple as corrugated cardboard attached to the tree with a velcro strip, measure how many goodies and baddies have accumulated behind the corrugated strip and, when the baddies exceed the goodies, take the opportunity to apply an appropriate pesticide spray.

Far more now than ever before, integrated control is part of the role that every farmer now plays in order to target pests. As if this were not reassuring enough, farmers are going beyond integrated control and into biological control. They are using the lures that I mentioned to indicate to them when they should introduce the predators needed to control the pests that are causing them problems in their orchards. What is crucial for pesticide control in Australia is timing, and it has been the work of departments of agriculture applied to properties and used by farmers that has allowed this timing to become critical and chemical use to fall as dramatically as it has fallen.

Australians can be assured that, whenever they pick up from a shelf an item of foodstuff that has been made in Australia, it has met the most rigorous demands and that the chemical level in it will in 80 per cent of the cases be zero—that is, non-recordable; no effective toxic chemical at all—and in 99.7 per cent of cases be below the minimum allowable levels, which themselves are well below the levels that are accepted in the rest of the world.

The other real change that has occurred in respect of toxic pesticide use for which farmers ought to be commended is the change in application. Whereas once farmers used large-volume spray rigs in order to saturate an orchard or a field with pesticide, those rigs have now been replaced by equipment that uses atomiser jets that allow for a very small application. I illustrate that statement as follows: if I were to have on my desk a basketball, it would cover about one corner; but, if I were to fill that basketball with ping-pong balls and then pour them over my desk, the entire desk would be covered by ping-pong balls. I use that illustration because presently in agriculture in Australia the minimum droplet size is used. In terms of droplet size, farmers are covering their farms and orchards with chemicals along the lines of ping-pong balls rather than basketballs. So, using small droplet size, one-twentieth of the quantity of chemical achieves precisely the same end result.

The purpose of my remarks and of this motion are to reassure all Australian consumers that the products that they pick up on the shelves, particularly those produced in Australia, not only are entirely harmless but also in fact have a lower chemical residue than that tolerated by the rest of the world. More than that, Australian producers have led the field in minimising chemical use because it has been in their own interests to do so and because they have been the people most at risk from excessive use in the past. Frankly, Mr Deputy Speaker, if you are concerned about the quantity of chemical that you may imagine you are ingesting, may I simply recommend that you eat a little less, because it is not the chemical that is doing you harm; it is the natural chemicals in the fruit that you will be ingesting. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. I second the motion.I am pleased to second this motion moved by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). The only criticism I have is that we do not have enough time to speak on this matter. It is one of the most important issues in Australia. I am very pleased to be involved in this debate because there is no doubt that Australian farmers have come to understand the need to reduce the amount of chemicals that are used. What the honourable member for Wakefield has said is 100 per cent correct—we have reduced the chemicals that are being put onto our primary products, and our food is the safest and the best in the world.

PARA.TAB: What I wish to speak about is the very exciting integrated pest management program that is under way in Bundaberg. At the outset I would like to compliment John and Penny Hall from Crop Tech Laboratories Pty Ltd, Newfarm Road, Alloway in Bundaberg, who are involved in the integrated pest management program and who are dedicated to improving not only the environment but the agricultural sector. It is that type of research and dedication that is so important. I was very pleased when our current Treasurer (Mr Kerin), at the time Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, visited Crop Tech and met the fruit and vegetable growers in Bundaberg this year to see what exciting things the IPM program is doing.

Because time will run out before I finish, I would like to get in as much as I can regarding the Bundaberg IPM program. Growers were facing rapidly escalating pest problems that had not been solved by high pesticide use. With the downturn in prices, of course, that was creating a massive squeeze. They have now enthusiastically embraced this community based approach to develop a sustainable pest management system. This program has a high emphasis on training growers in improved crop management practices, such as better crop hygiene—which is vital—and the use of crop rotations; close crop monitoring and pest identification; spraying of chemicals only when necessary; selection of products that are safer to beneficial insects; and the release of parasites and predators to control pests. As the honourable member for Wakefield mentioned, there are the goodies and the baddies among insects and other parasites in the fruit and vegetable environment. By learning about technology we are able to minimise the effects that they have on our fruit and vegetables and reduce the amount of chemicals that are needed, and in doing so of course reduce the cost structure for our farmers.

The fruit and vegetable growers of Bundaberg, Childers and Gin Gin districts who care about our future will now proudly display the IPM logo on their produce. I am pleased to hold it up for all to see. The logo will soon appear on selected fruit and vegetables from the Bundaberg region. It will signify the growers' commitment to minimal pesticide usage. To be authorised to use this logo, the grower must have satisfied the IPM committee that he or she has put into practice the principles of integrated pest management, IPM. Users of the logo must maintain a responsible attitude towards minimising pesticide usage and incorporating alternative means of pest management where possible.

Fruit and vegetable growers in the Bundaberg region have taken this very innovative and positive step to protect the future of their industry and the environment. The $200,000 IPM project was designed and initiated, as I have said, by Crop Tech Research, a private consultancy and research organisation based in Bundaberg. The project is funded by the growers of the Bundaberg, Gin Gin and Childers areas, the Committee of Direction of Fruit Marketing and the Horticultural Research Development Corporation.

So we have our State body, along with the Government and private enterprise, working to produce the best technology for the industry. The objective is to introduce and develop in Bundaberg for the Queensland fruit and vegetable industry an integrated pest management pilot program which will reduce the growers' reliance on chemicals as the main tool in pest and disease control, and to develop new and innovative control options for inclusion in a whole farm pest management strategy.

I would like to point out—and I am sure that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have partaken of our great produce from the Bundaberg area—that we are now the leading horticultural section in Australia. The fruit and vegetable industry in Queensland is now worth some $700m—a massive industry. Of course, we are looking overseas to expand our markets and we have already gained market access in New Zealand and in South East Asia. The Minister for Resources (Mr Griffiths) is fully aware of and committed to those export initiatives. Through his innovation and hard work with AQIS and through the protocol arrangements with New Zealand we have been able to break down some of the barriers, particularly with cucurbit crops, to gain better market access. Bundaberg is well known for producing the best cucumbers and zucchinis in Australia and there is a massive opportunity and market for them in New Zealand.

The grower awareness of the philosophy of integrated pest management principles has improved in response to the planned extension program. As part of the program, two IPM videos have been produced and distributed to growers. Pest and disease activity on a wide range of crops, with advice on their management, has been the topic of daily radio and newspaper reports. As well as all the technology, it is a matter of getting all the information out to the growers and getting them to relate and communicate.

An extensive grid system of 160 pheromone traps has been used to monitor the distribution and population dynamics of potato moth, the major pest of tomatoes in the region. Weekly data are used to plot areas of heavy infestation on GIS software, and the resultant maps are published weekly. The sources of these infestations are identified and offending growers are counselled on crop hygiene. In other words, we are monitoring on a daily and weekly basis. If producers fail to comply with the advice offered, the IPM coordinator has the power under the Plant Protection Act to order the destruction of the crop. As a result of the IPM program the average time taken for the removal of crop residues has dramatically decreased. This is reflected by a significant reduction in population levels and subsequent damage.

The expected continued decline in pest populations will enable the program to address the use and encouragement of beneficial insects that have been suppressed by heavy chemical use. This is one of the sad aspects of overuse of chemicals. We not only kill the bad insects, but also kill the predators that can actually do a better job through mother nature. The next stage of the program will see the establishment of a comprehensive monitoring system for tree crops.

While the integrated pest management program is widely known in the citrus and other tree crop industries in other areas, very little was known by local growers of the principles that could apply to vegetables and trees in our region. We are now emerging as a fast growing area for avocadoes and mangoes. Sadly, this morning I spoke to two avocado growers in the Childers region who were hit by a severe hailstorm last night. We will not know for quite some time how much of a crop loss they will suffer because some of their crop was just setting. Custard apples and mangoes have been damaged as well. But our area is expanding in tree crops as well as in the vegetable area.

Many growers mistakenly thought that the IPM program meant biological control or organic gardening and were apprehensive. The perceived benefits were, however, much more attractive than the alarming situation they faced. The program received very good support when it was proposed.

Education was therefore a first step towards creating an awareness of the basics of IPM. Two seminars were run, a manual was produced outlining the principles of IPM in our situation and two videos were produced dealing with cultural control and the benefits of monitoring crops spraying only when necessary instead of on a rigid program. Over 300 daily radio reports on both the ABC and the commercial radio station 4BU have been used to pass on information on the activity of pests and diseases to help growers with monitoring operations and ward off potential problems. The great aspect about that is that private companies and the ABC are cooperating and working together. With that sort of approach we are going to overcome many of the difficulties in agriculture.

I think we have come a long way in the last few years. The one positive thing to come out of the downturn or the rural crisis is the realisation finally that we have to work together. We have to work smarter as well as harder. It is through this type of technology that we will improve the profitability of farmers, reduce the reliance on chemicals and therefore reduce the health risk for workers and farmers alike. We will also succeed in being more competitive with the rest of the world. As I have said, I am only sorry that time does not allow me to continue, because this is one of the most important private members' Bills ever put before the House. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion proposed by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) that we commend Australian agriculturalists on the way they have used toxic pesticides over the last 20 years. I think all Australians realise that it would be far better for us to grow our crops and produce our food with minimum use of insecticides, fungicides and pesticides, but we have to be realistic about this and remember that we face a great challenge from the insects that inhabit the world. If we did not use insecticides and pesticides to a certain level, millions of people would starve because our crops would be raided by insects. Handling this food production problem is a real challenge for mankind.

PARA.TAB: The honourable members who have spoken to this motion have extensive horticultural areas in their electorates. My electorate is no different from theirs, in that all of McDonald's chips for Australia come out of the northern part of Australia and are processed in my electorate. Northern Tasmania grows a tremendous amount of peas and other processing vegetables, and therefore we are very familiar with chemicals, pesticides and fungicides and take a lot of care with them. People have realised in the last 20 years that the long term impact of these chemicals on the quality of our food might be quite marked.

The farming community certainly has been conscious of the need for care. The farming community, in general, is very careful in its use of chemicals. Farmers are essentially the world's first environmentalists, because they are always concerned about the way in which they treat their soils and the way in which things may accumulate in the soil, and about the products which they produce.

Only today I received some information about a survey conducted by Frank Small and Associates on the opinion of farmers and their use of chemicals. The farming community was asked whether farmers should prove knowledge of correct use. Ninety-five per cent of the farming community surveyed indicated that they believe farming people should be able to show that they know how to correctly use the chemicals which they are putting on their crops. The survey also showed that 88 per cent of the farming community believed that the chemicals they were using may contaminate water and soil. That is not unexpected, because I think many of the horticultural farmers in this country are aware of the long term implications of use of pesticides and chemicals. Seventy-three per cent of our farmers actually believe that they use too many chemicals. That makes me question why that has occurred.

The horticultural farming community has found that the pressures of commerce and of price and demand have been such that they have often used chemicals to maximise production, without giving a lot of thought to the long term effects. As a consequence, they have used more chemicals than they really wanted to or felt it was good to use. Therefore, as a country we need to think carefully about the demand which is placed on our food producers, ensuring that price pressures do not lead our farmers to use chemicals as a short term measure to increase their productivity.

There is no doubt that farmers are very conscious of the effects of toxic pesticides and have done a considerable amount to reduce their use. I agree with the previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), that that attitude has been helped by the scientists who have undertaken to find more effective ways of producing less harmful substances which can be used to spray our crops.

There are three different types of compounds. There are the old compounds, of which very large quantities had to be used—for example, anything from 1,500 to 5,000 kilograms per hectare—and now we are down to using one-thousandth of a kilogram per hectare. Massive amounts of the old compounds were required to get any effect, while with the modern compounds the quantity required has been drastically reduced. We have also the experimental compounds, which as yet are not named but are being worked on by scientists, which will ensure that minimal amounts are used.

In general, the journals on this—for example, the journal of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association—state that Australia's use of farm chemicals is low, owing to Australia's climate, geography and topography. That has come about because Australian farmers have taken on the new chemicals available and have cautiously applied them to their crops. To illustrate further the extent of this reduction, the National Health and Medical Research Council's market survey of 1987 shows that there has been a change in the incidence of detection of various chemicals in food. I will use as examples three types of chemicals to show that there has been a change which has largely been brought about by farmers changing chemicals.

In 1985 the detection rate of lindane was 7 per cent in the approximately 1,100 areas surveyed. In 1987 no lindane was detected in the 691 areas surveyed. In 1985 the detection rate for DDT analogues was 14 per cent. In 1986 it had reduced to 10 per cent and by 1987 it was down to 9 per cent. We see a gradual decline in the presence of these chemicals in our food. In 1985 there was a 1.9 incidence rate of hexachlorobenzene and by 1987 that incidence had dropped to zero. In the 691 vegetable and food samples taken, it had dropped down to zero—there was no incidence of that chemical.

We have evidence that the chemicals in our food are on the decline and we also know that the chemicals are being used in much smaller quantities. Various groups have been established quite voluntarily. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice), spoke of one in Bundaberg with which I am familiar. There is also one in northern Tasmania known as the Tasmanian Agricultural Productivity Group. That has been established voluntarily by people involved in the chemical industry to try to ensure that farmers are well educated about this matter and that they are taking action to reduce the use of toxic chemicals. I congratulate the farming people of Australia for taking this action, and I fully support this motion moved by the honourable member for Wakefield.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) on presenting this private member's motion. I do not have any agriculturalists—it is a lovely term, is it not—in my electorate, but I have a host of consumers and, to some extent, it is consumers who are driving and requiring of producers that we use a minimum amount of pesticides and artificial means by which to keep vegetables—especially fruit products—as free from disease as possible. But there has to be some interplay between consumers, producers and retailers.

PARA.TAB: Whilst the honourable member is quite right to congratulate agriculturalists in the reduction of the use of pesticides, et cetera—the figures are in—consumers and even supermarkets have a role to play in educating people as to what is and is not possible. At the same time though, I think we should continue to push the producers to ensure that we have the best standards in the use of pesticides and the safest means of producing good vegetables and other products.

I am sorry that I missed the speech of the honourable member for Wakefield. I am not sure whether he mentioned the joint initiative in the apple and pear industry whereby growers, environmental groups and consumers have recently got together in the last 14 months or so in order to reduce pesticide use in the growing of apples and pears. This is a joint initiative of the Apple and Pear Growers Association and consumer and environmental groups with the aim of reducing pesticide use by 50 per cent over the next five years. That is a marvellous step and is very much in line with the motion. There is also an agreement to de-list 12 currently used pesticides in that industry.

It is basically a good news story, although from time to time we will always hear that someone is blowing the whistle on the use of pesticides in the production of food products—and thank goodness for the whistle blowers. Australia, by and large, has an excellent reputation for producing and marketing food that not only meets but also exceeds world residue standards. We are one of the few countries that continues to publish and make available internationally information on chemical residues in foods. I note that we publish annually a market basket survey on prepared food and that results are regularly released to the World Health Organisation and to Codex Alimentarius. We also have a national residue survey.

Information is one of the most powerful mechanisms by which we can force agriculturalists—producers—to further reduce residues. Agriculturalists should inform consumers of the real limits on the reduction in pesticides. A number of factors have contributed to the decline in use of pesticides in the last 10, 15 or 20 years. I will run through a number of those factors.

First, but not necessarily foremost, there has been an increased cost in the use of many pesticides, and that plays on any producer's mind. Producers have looked to more cost-effective ways to reduce the damage to their crops and they have been discouraged through this high cost of using broad spectrum approaches to spraying for more efficient use.

There have been domestic and international trade pressures brought about mainly by consumer and public health concerns for personal health and environmental health, forcing a reduction in the use of pesticides. For the agriculturalist—the farmer—there is the very real self-interest. The farmer is the one who has to get out there and spray this stuff. Farmers have a real concern for their own health in using these materials over a very long period and, of course, in much larger amounts than we would take in as consumers.

There has been a general shift, most noticeable in the USA but also in Australia, to tighter standards—the technological fix; to better chemicals, so that more specific and effective action is taken on target species, not just spraying for a broad range of species; to the use of materials that are less persistent in the environment and that degrade more quickly, so that their effect is not felt in soils for many years. These materials are designed to minimise residues in foods so that, by the time they reach the consumer, they are far less in evidence on the apple, pear, or whatever other product we are about to eat. The materials also give a better delivery of technology so that we do not broadly spray areas that are not designed to be covered at all and so that spray does not drift into townships and so on. We are much more focused on where these materials need to be delivered to a crop—to the target audience, if you like—and that they are delivered properly and without too much waste or overhang.

There is better monitoring of the use of these products and a great deal more scientific endeavour to check out the results of the use of the products and to feed back information to farmers about the effect this will have on their crops as well as their health and the health of consumers. A far better understanding of the biology of pests has evolved which enables us to use not just a chemical means of controlling pests as they might affect various products. I will list a few others. There is a better knowledge of the impacts of the chemicals used; that is, toxicity to other organisms and persistence in the environment, which gives us a better informed grower and consumer. There has also been an increase in the use of natural products and derivatives.

I refer to a recent book by Christopher Robbins called Poisoned Harvest—A Consumer's Guide To Pesticide Use and Abuse. We have come a long way since the publication of the book Silent Spring 20 years ago. It opened the lead on this horrible overuse of pesticides. Robbins indicates in his book that there has been a reduction in the use of pesticides. He does not say the game is over, that we have won the fight or that we need to relax our view on these things—he is not saying that at all—but he says that we have come a long way.

Robbins points out some large supermarkets in the United Kingdom that have very large monitoring programs on the sorts of residues found in products that they sell to consumers. In a sense, supermarkets are competing with each other for the consumer's dollar on the basis of ensuring as low a residue as possible from these sorts of chemicals. That is healthy. Supermarket retailers react to the consumers. Obviously, consumers are now sufficiently well-informed to force not only the farmer but also the retailer of these goods to ensure we have the best possible standards.

In conclusion, I congratulate the honourable member for Wakefield and the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) and the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) for their contributions. This is the second week in a row in which I have debated a matter with the honourable member for Wakefield. I thank him for raising the matter in the House.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired and the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (a)21 large bulk carriers sank between January 1990 and August 1991; and
(b)six of those vessels departed north-west Australian ports with Australian cargoes;

SPEECH.PARA: (2)deplores the needless loss of lives of seafarers;
(3)expresses its concern at the unseaworthiness of foreign vessels visiting Australian ports; and
(4)calls on the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to step up the inspection rate of foreign vessels attending Australian ports.

This motion deals with an issue of the utmost gravity; an issue that involves the exploitation of poorly paid seafarers whose lives are put at risk in the pursuit of cheaper sea freight rates; and an issue that puts at risk the priceless marine environment of this nation and of the world generally.

PARA.TAB: This issue involves continuing acts of callousness and irresponsibility by foreign shipowners, foreign ship operators, shippers, marine insurance companies and the governments of the nations that operate ship registries—nations that have persistently condoned the registration of ships that border on the margin of seaworthiness, or nations that persistently fail to ensure that adequate inspections are carried out on ships that are on their shipping registers or frequent their ports to ensure that those vessels are fit to go to sea.

Today I ask this House: what price the loss of human lives? What price the destruction of our marine environment? I raise these questions because the infamous practices involved are all dollar driven; they are undertaken in the pursuit of profit.

Between January 1990 and August 1991, 39 bulk carriers had been reported missing or lost or had suffered serious structural failure. Twenty-one of those vessels were lost at sea. Six of them were ships that had loaded at Australian ports. Fortunately for Australia, no Australian lives were lost in those disasters and none of the vessels were on the Australian shipping register. In the time available, I will quickly run through the names of the vessels and the dates: the Alexandre P, a Panamanian flag bulk carrier of 94,532 tonnes, foundered with the loss of all 24 hands on 14 March 1990 in fine weather in the southern Indian Ocean. The Sanko Harvest, a Panamanian flag bulk carrier of 33,024 tonnes deadweight, built in 1985, grounded in shoal water in Recherche Archipelago on 14 February 1991 while approaching Esperence. The ship broke up and sank with no loss of life but a certain amount of pollution. The Starfish, a Panamanian flag bulk carrier of 56,277 tonnes deadweight, was built in 1970. It had loaded iron ore at Port Walcott. It foundered off Mauritius on 8 April 1991 with no loss of life. The Mineral Diamond, a Hong Kong registered bulk carrier of 141,028 tonnes deadweight, was built in 1982. It was considered to have foundered with the loss of all 26 Indian crew in very heavy weather in the southern Indian Ocean on 17-18 April 1991.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not being critical, but were all these unseaworthy?
—Of course they were.
—I am very interested in what the former Minister is saying and it sounds very praiseworthy. I missed the early part of the speech.

—I will be happy to provide additional information to the honourable member after I finish. The Manila Transporter, a Philippines flag bulk carrier of 115,960 tonnes deadweight, was built in 1976. In this case the crew abandoned ship in heavy weather on 7 July 1991 after a fracture developed in shell plating and No. 3 hold had been flooded. Fortunately, on that occasion all the crew were rescued before the ship sank on 7 August 1991.

PARA.TAB: The Melete, a Greek flag bulk carrier of 72,063 tonnes deadweight, was built in 1975. It loaded with iron ore at Dampier. The master sent out a distress message on 24 August 1991, when south of Mauritius, stating the ship was taking water in the forward part of the ship. No further messages were received from the ship and a search located two survivors of the crew of 27.

These ships—events such as these and structural failures—hark back to the days of the coffin ships of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. Effectively, we have ships that are unsound to one degree or another; ships that are not being adequately inspected; ships that are on shipping registers not obviously meeting the requirements under international conventions and international standards or international maritime organisation standards; and ships often crewed by, effectively, seagoing labourers, where there may be one or two certificated officers on board and the rest of the crew learning their trades as they go along.

A large part of what is involved is Third World labour: the exploitation of people who have little skill and few employment prospects and who are desperate to get an income and a job. In other cases, safety equipment is non-existent or does not work. Crews cannot complain. If they do complain they lose their jobs. Because there is little monitoring, there is a lack of safety equipment, a deficiency in safety equipment that can be hidden. In some cases lifeboats have been welded down on the vessel to stop them banging around. That is fine unless the lifeboat needs to be used—obviously, in some cases lifeboats have not been used. Firefighting equipment is sometimes totally inadequate.

More recently we had the Kirki off the Western Australian coast, a Greek flag tanker —again, a vessel which, at the time of construction, had a bow plate of about three-quarters of an inch, 18 millimetres. At the time of the incident some of the bow plates were down to a one millimetre thickness. The inquiry into the sinking of that vessel is under way. We will see what comes out of that.

Undoubtedly, there are major breaches of standards involved. There are major failings in inspection standards on the part of the countries of registry of those ships. There is infamous behaviour by the operators and owners of those ships. That responsibility has to pass down the line to shippers and the users of those ships, not to mention the insurance companies, who are also involved.

There is one very simple answer to this. It is that insurance companies refuse to cover cargoes and ships unless those ships are proven to be seaworthy or unless the international classification societies have carried out, at the port of departure, inspections that prove the vessel is seaworthy. That is a very simple, easy answer.

Linked also to this is the damage to our environment. This is what in recent times has attracted attention in Australia. Our environment is priceless. We have fishing grounds that are of enormous concern to Australians and to our economy, and we have vessels coming onto this coast that are clearly not of required standards.

Towards the end of last year the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure went down to Port Kembla. At the suggestion of locals, we sought to inspect a vessel called the Blooming Orchid. That vessel was a rust bucket. The vessel was owned by German companies and crewed by Filipinos. Members of the Committee were denied an opportunity to inspect the vessel on the captain's words that the vessel `was in a condition that would endanger the safety of the members of the Committee if they went on board'.

The vessel sailed from these shores; $500,000 worth of work was carried out. It was not able to load cargo. It was refused cargo because of its condition. It eventually found a cargo from Brazil to Singapore. On the way it again got into trouble. That vessel is now being repaired in Singapore. It came back into these waters in worse condition than it was when we sent it out towards the end of last year.
Again, I raise the question: what price human life? What price no environment? What price are we prepared to accept in low freight rates to allow this kind of behaviour to go on?

The question is not just one for Australia; it is a question for our international trading partners and for the International Maritime Organisation. It is a question that has been taken up vigorously by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins). I commend the Minister for the actions he has taken. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has already initiated a pilot study to find out the performance and loading process of these vessels, whether the loading and unloading methods have a bearing upon their condition and what their condition is. The number of inspectors has been stepped up.

In this motion I seek the support of the House to increase the rate of inspection from the current 25 per cent—ideally so that all vessels coming here under foreign flags would be inspected. I call upon nations around the world to carry out their responsibilities. I ask for the support of members of this chamber in the establishment of a national inquiry, preferably through our Standing Committee, into the overall question of ship safety, both nationally and internationally, as it affects this nation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support every word of the speech by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). The motion he has moved in the House this morning is commendable and echoes my own media release at the time of the sinking of the Kirki which called for stricter application of seaworthiness certification requirements and a review of Australia's requirements of ships entering and leaving our ports and waters.

PARA.TAB: Without any doubt, the honourable member for Shortland is one of the most knowledgeable members on transport issues on either side of the House, particularly on his side of the House. It is a great shame that the honourable member for Shortland is not a Minister for transport. I think his knowledge and genuine sincerity in this area warrant giving him, above all of the Ministers for transport who currently represent the Government, a position. The content of the speech he has just given shows that he has both knowledge and sincere interest in the livelihood and well-being of seamen who go to sea and of the seagoing industry generally.

The honourable member's readiness to move this motion may give a clue to why a man with such talent and integrity is not better used by this Government. The motion calls on the Government to do what it has always been in the Government's power to do, and that is to enforce the highest safety standards for all shipping, be it Australian or foreign, in Australian waters. The motion exposes the hypocrisy of trying to evade Australia's responsibility under the safety conventions to ensure the seaworthiness of ships that enter and leave Australian ports, regardless of country of origin—not only the responsibility to Australia and our own coast but also the responsibility to keep the world's seas safe. The needless loss of life of seafarers is truly deplorable, regardless of country.

Unseaworthiness of vessels is of international concern. Unseaworthy vessels do not select the coastlines they sink alongside and they are just as dangerous one kilometre out of Australian waters as they are one kilometre within them. The Navigation Act gives wide powers to the Federal Government over all ships entering Australian waters and ports, the same power that it has over Australian vessels. Section 189 of the Navigation Act says:

SPEECH.PARA: All ships shall be liable to inspection and survey.
So it is not just Australian ships. The power is comprehensive. Section 190AA(1) says:

A surveyor may at any reasonable time go on board a ship and inspect the ship and any part of the ship, including the hull, boilers, machinery and equipment of the ship, and may require the certificates of the master or of any officer of the ship, or any certificate or other document relating to the ship, to be produced to him.
Sections 207 and 207A of the Navigation Act also define what unseaworthy and substandard conditions are on board ships. Section 207 says a ship is only seaworthy if:

it is in a fit state as to condition of hull and equipment, boilers and machinery, stowage of ballast or cargo, number and qualifications of crew, including officers, and in every other respect, to encounter the ordinary perils of the voyage then entered upon.
If the ship is under foreign certification then it is unseaworthy if:
the condition of the ship or of its equipment does not correspond substantially with the particulars of that certificate or of any of those certificates.
It is substandard if it is:
for the purposes of this Act. . . seaworthy, but conditions on board. . . are clearly hazardous to safety or health.

That could include conditions such as the deck or engine area being covered in grease, causing seamen to fall and injure themselves or possibly be killed, as I suspect was the case with a Japanese engineer on board a ship in Australian waters just recently. He slipped in the engine compartment and was killed. He slipped on a deck that the rescuers were not able to walk upon because it was so greasy. The Act provides for the provisional detention, and then the detention, which can be indefinite unless the faults are remedied, of a ship that is unseaworthy or substandard.

PARA.TAB: These conditions and provisions relate to all ships in Australian waters, not only to Australian ships. The authority for the determination of the above is none other than the Australian Maritime Safety Authority which was created by this Government. The Authority has the power to release a ship conditionally, for instance with a condition that it leave Australian waters and undertake repairs at a specified port. Why has the Government not utilised these very comprehensive powers to ensure the safety of Australian shipping lanes and our coastline and to ensure the lives of all seamen entering Australian waters?

Senator Collins has tried to make foreign shipping a scapegoat for the Government's own failure to enforce maritime safety standards in our waters, which is nonsense since foreign vessels are subject to exactly the same safety provisions of the Navigation Act as Australian vessels as soon as they enter Australian waters. On 5 May the Australian Financial Review carried a report of Senator Collins's address to the Metal Trades Industry Association conference that was held the day before. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: There have been some "scandalous and horrendous" examples of foreign ships where no-one knew how to operate the equipment, Senator Collins said. "In one case they did not know how to shut the engines off on the ship. Someone just started the engines in the home port and they were still running when they got here," he said.

He said the life saving equipment aboard the Kirki was found to be in much the same condition as another foreign ship recently detained by AMSA—it had taken two days to get the other ship's life boats overboard.
That may explain why so many of these ships go down with all crews lost—simply because the lifeboats cannot be launched. The report continued:

Senator Collins said Australian shipping standards were far superior to those used overseas. No Australian owned ship had ever been detained by the AMSA because of deficient safety standards, he said.

Senator Collins completely missed the point, which was that many unsafe foreign ships were neither inspected nor detained; in some cases, such as the Kirki, they had been inspected recently and cleared. The Kirki had been subjected to exactly the same procedures as Australian ships and cleared. There is nothing that makes an Australian ship inherently safer than a properly inspected foreign ship.

PARA.TAB: We do not have a franchise on maritime soundness despite Senator Collins's boasts. We do have an international responsibility to ensure that, regardless of their nationality, all ships leaving Australian ports are found to be sound before they leave our waters so that they do not become a hazard to the rest of the world. The Government has not done this. It is a major concern if a ship founders or sinks anywhere at all—not only in Australian waters. The death of a seaman just outside our waters—or anywhere at all—is just as tragic as when it occurs in Australian waters. We do have an obligation to prevent these incidents when we are able, such as when Australia has the power to inspect and enforce.
Senator Collins has also sought to use this tragic issue to justify the Government's policy of cabotage protection. He said at the MTIA conference:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government stopped cabotage and allowed free trade while insisting that foreign ships were up to the same structural efficiency, crew training and other standards as Australian ships, "you'd frighten away 90 per cent of the . . . people that we've had plying our coasts with sweated labour and death traps".

That is complete nonsense. Cabotage has nothing to do with safety. It relates by definition only to the coastal trade. The Government can and should ensure that foreign ships are up to the highest standards and it has the power under the Navigation Act to do so. Cabotage has nothing to do with making ships safer; it is simply a measure for preventing foreign ships from having access to Australian coastal routes. It does not and cannot apply to foreign ships engaged only in international trade in any event. They come and go through Australian ports regardless of the restrictions on the coastal trade. Senator Collins uses safety as a red herring to divert attention from the reality of cabotage protection. That is, it is a purely protectionist measure for a completely unionised industry.

PARA.TAB: The scapegoat campaign by Senator Collins is a fraudulent attempt to deflect attention from the Government's protectionism and its failure to carry out its obligations to ensure the safety of all shipping in our waters. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) should know better than to echo Senator Collins's absurd claims—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken yet.

—I know, but the honourable member will shortly—and he has said it before—make absurd claims that the Opposition wishes to bring substandard ships onto the Australian coastline. I too voice the concerns of the honourable member for Throsby about such ships as the Berlina, which was recently detained in Port Kembla, but I point out that its detention is a demonstration of what should be done. Shunting unseaworthy ships out of our waters to become a hazard to all other shipping, including Australian, elsewhere in the world and creating a global environmental threat does not solve the problem; enforcing the existing provisions of the Navigation Act will.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Shortland has it right. The tragedy of losses at sea demands action, and the appropriate action is to step up the inspections of foreign vessels, and of all vessels, in Australian waters, for reasons that are humane and also for genuine self-interest. We do not want ships sinking in our waters. We do not want them sinking near our waters. We do not want them sinking anywhere else in the world.

As I said on 9 September, the Opposition would support moves to toughen the international safety requirements for ships. The Government did not respond to that call and has done nothing at all about it. I am pleased to welcome the motion of the honourable member for Shortland. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —If last year over 200 people had died in air crashes, there would be massive international publicity. Yet, almost unnoticed, during 1990 over 200 seamen lost their lives. Correctly, very stringent safety conditions apply to aircraft, but are the lives of passengers and crew on aircraft more important than the lives of passengers and crew on ships?

PARA.TAB: Every so often an item appears in the media about ships being refused permission to load because of their condition. Predictably there is condemnation of the Australian workers involved, as the newspapers or Opposition members use it as a further excuse for union bashing.

I listened to the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp). I have heard many of his speeches on shipping, as he has heard many of mine. That is why he could quote me before I rose to speak. I put to the honourable member for Gilmore that if he is so concerned and if he is genuine here today, he should come with me down to Port Kembla the next time a ship is delayed there, instead of staying in Goulburn and putting out a press release condemning the workers in Port Kembla. He should come down. He has not been to inspect the Berlina, which was there last week, or the Blooming Orchid, which was there last year and which the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and I have seen. It is okay for the honourable member for Gilmore to stand in this House and express fine sentiments, but they are different from the comments and the statements that he puts out when a ship is delayed in Port Kembla.

We are told that our shipping costs are a national scandal and that the only way to bring them down is to open up the Australian coast to foreign vessels. Before we get too gung ho about foreign ships, we should be aware of the dangerous rust buckets we would be permitting around our coast. Senator Collins was right about that, and about the loss of life and cargo and the pollution of our coastline.

Imagine the outcry if clapped-out aircraft were permitted to operate through our airports on our domestic routes. Remember the outcry a few years ago when second-hand buses were being imported and when second-hand trucks were being imported and let loose on our roads. Why the silence about the rust buckets that continue to ply our coast?

I have outlined to this House before the dangers associated with flag of convenience ships, ships registered in countries that do not apply proper standards for the safety and seaworthiness of these ships or the lives of the seamen on them. A recent shipping trend has been second registries, where the national flag is retained on a ship registered in some other dominion, as in the case of France, which has 39 ships now on the books of Kerguelen Island. Kerguelen Island is a French territory in Antarctica populated by penguins. The French have 39 ships registered there.

This form of registration keeps the vessels in the national fleet. Until recently they would only employ officers and not ratings from the host country. However, the officers are now being replaced by unemployed officers from Eastern Bloc countries. In many ways this method of registration is no better than flag of convenience registration.

The number of flag of convenience ships over recent years has remained constant. But I am sure that it comes as no surprise to honourable members that Panama, Liberia and Cyprus alone accounted for 39 of the shipping casualties in 1990. Most definitely, second registries are the new fad amongst the world's shipowners, as they avoid tax and refuse to meet accepted standards.

As I said only last week, the Norwegian registered coal ship the MV Berlina was in Port Kembla harbour unfit to load. It has been correctly referred to as a rust bucket by the local Illawarra media. This ship was crewed by Filipinos, although owned by people in Norway. It was surveyed by the port surveyor who, after inspecting the vessel, immediately ordered that it not be loaded owing to large cracks in the main deck and in between all the cargo hatches. As well, there were numerous other deficiencies and safety problems. In fact, many of the cracks on this ship were covered with tar paper. This is the fourth ship to be held at Port Kembla in the past 12 months because of the need for similar repairs.

The honourable member for Shortland referred to the Blooming Orchid. `Blooming' Orchid is right! We saw this ship last October. It has been condemned seven times in Australian ports since 1986. The last time, it escaped from Port Kembla and was supposed to be repaired in Singapore. It almost foundered carrying iron ore from Brazil to Singapore. Undoubtedly it will be back in these ports again. Really, it is an international scandal. The loss of bulk carriers most certainly is an international scandal.

As this motion says, 21 of these vessels have been lost, and six of them were carrying cargoes from north-west Australian ports. The mining industry is most vocal about the need for the cheapest ships possible and says that the OECD standard is not valid for comparison with Australian shipping. Let the honourable member for Gilmore push that line. The waters off Western Australia are becoming a graveyard for the world's ageing shipping.

The Mineral Diamond sailed from Western Australia with a crew of 27 and disappeared. All that was found was the discolouration of the sea where it was thought that the ship had gone down. There were no survivors. As well as the Mineral Diamond, the bulk iron ore carriers that have foundered or sunk off the Western Australia coast since late last year are the Manila Transporter, the Alexandre P and the Melete. How much longer are these rust buckets going to be permitted to enter Australian ports?

When people start talking about bans being put on ships, they are often criticised. When there is a ban on a ship in Port Kembla harbour I always make a point of going down there and personally inspecting the vessel. As I have said time and time again, most of them are just rust buckets. I defy anyone, including members of this House, to go to sea in some of the ships that have been rightly banned in Port Kembla. I always invite Opposition members to come down to Port Kembla to inspect the ships with me, to talk to the workers and to actually see what is going on.

When I was talking about these rust buckets to the Secretary of the Seamen's Union in Port Kembla last week, he informed me that they videotape every ship which has a ban on it. If members of the Opposition, or even members of the Government, cannot come down to Port Kembla, I will make these videos available to them so that they can see the condition of these ships that the Seamen's Union has put bans on.

At this stage it is not clear, because of the lack of information, just how many of the sunken vessels were lost owing to unseaworthiness alone or as a result of inadequately trained crews or poor seamanship—or, as I suspect, as a result of a combination of all of these. Vessels in bad seas need well-qualified, expert crews to handle them. There may be only one or two certified or qualified officers on board many of the vessels.

Often there is a language difficulty between the officers and the crew. The crew, which is being paid poverty wages, effectively is made up of seagoing labourers. No tears are being shed by the trading nations of the world for these hundreds of Third World seamen who have disappeared without trace and who are known to have lost their lives at sea.

It is clear, as the honourable member for Shortland said, that in recent years we have seen a re-emergence of the coffin ships of past centuries, when ships were sent to sea in an unseaworthy condition or in a condition that was likely to result in their loss and the loss of their crews. For years, seafarers of the world have been pointing to the deplorable condition of many of these vessels that operate as flag of convenience ships.

I would like particularly to pay tribute to the Seamen's Union here in Australia, and especially to my own group at Port Kembla, for the work it has done in this field. For their efforts the members of the union have generally been portrayed as people crying wolf, people who do not want to work or people who would draw undue attention to the safety aspects of ship operation.

We are now seeing the result of the continued neglect of this major safety issue by the shipping nations of the world. The irony is that attention is now being drawn to this practice of using coffin ships not because of concern about the loss of lives at sea but because of concern about the marine and global environment. That environment is a matter of major concern; however, one would have thought priority would have been given to the needless loss of sailors' lives at sea. I sometimes wonder whether it is because most of those sailors come from Third World countries that no-one is interested in them. If they came from Britain or the United States or Australia, it might be different.

We have a concern in this nation about the risk posed to our coastal marine environment by oil spillage from poorly crewed vessels and from unseaworthy vessels in the event that they are wrecked. Recently we had the problem with the Kirki off the Western Australian coast. I suspect the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) will tell us about that again. This focused our attention on the risk to Australia's fishing conditions and our coastal environment. As I have said before, the marine environment is important to all Australians, as are the lives of the seafarers who are forced to man these rust buckets.

I particularly commend the honourable member for Shortland. I agree this time with the honourable member for Gilmore about the interest and concern shown by the honourable member for Shortland in this matter. I think this is one of the most important motions to come before this House and I support his attempt to have the matter referred for inquiry by the committee that he so ably chairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join this debate and to join in the support that has been given by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) to the motion. As the Parliament is aware, and as the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) just mentioned, I am on the record on this matter already on page 2233 of Hansard of 17 October, when I raised a lot of the matters that have concerned me in this particular area. I raised them relating specifically to areas of my electorate when the ship Kirki, which has been referred to today, posed a major threat to one of the major industries of my electorate, namely the lobster industry. We were threatened for many days when that ship sank and spilled some 60,000 tonnes of light crude oil into the sea. That oil covered all the reefs and the marine environment that supports a huge export industry for Australia —the fishing industry in general and the lobster industry in particular. The Sanko Harvest also ran aground there. That was not so much a case of an inadequate ship but certainly of an inadequate crew, and these same concerns arose.

PARA.TAB: Allowing rust buckets to operate within Australia has many problems, the first being human safety—which other members have mentioned—and the second being possible environmental damage. There must be a cost. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) has been talking about the problems in recent times facing some of the names of Lloyds. This has been substantially caused by losses incurred through the loss of these rust buckets and, in particular, the cargoes they were carrying. Naturally, the response from the insurance industry will be higher premiums. It is time that this issue is taken up. The insurance companies themselves should be starting to set their premiums possibly according to the port of registration and certainly after checking their own inspection criteria. Every ship has marks that are set by Lloyds. It is just further evidence of the need for insurance companies to set the level of cargo that each ship should carry. These matters are of great importance.

Constituents of mine managed to board the Kirki and got hold of a piece of deck plate. The Kirki was a very large bulk carrier and yet what was the thickness of that deck plate? It was an eighth of an inch thick. I am told that the bow plate where the actual break occurred was even thinner than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —One millimetre.

—This ship would originally have been built with plate with a thickness certainly above half an inch in the old fashioned measurements. It is totally unsatisfactory that such a situation should occur. It is worth noting that a lot of these ships are operating for parts of the day with no crew in charge at all. I have had a number of complaints from fishermen in my area that ships have sailed by them and it has been clear to them that there has been nobody in charge. These ships have been on autopilot, steaming through fishing areas.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that too much of our waters are available for these sorts of environmentally damaging ships to sail in—ones that carry environmentally or potentially environmentally damaging cargo. They seem to come in close along the coast wherever it suits them and certainly do not follow a straight line from their point of departure. Some people have suggested that this is to drop a few drugs off on the way down. Others have suggested that they pick up some special tide. But, if this Committee is formed, we should be looking to designate certain areas where ships operate when they arrive and depart our shores. I am not sure that the little benefit they get from a bit of tide can compensate for the losses that might occur to other industries.

I want to talk about how we manage this problem. The honourable member for Throsby pointed out that the Seamen's Union puts bans on these ships. I hope this Committee will, if it is necessary, provide through government the necessary resources for government inspectors to do this task. I do not believe it is a role for trade unions. They might be the only people there, and I accept that, but it does bring criticism upon them. At times they have been known to take unnecessary action, and I think there is probably a better understanding today of the level of action that should be taken.

I remember that in my State some years ago I lunched with some people who were involved in the manufacture of fibrous piping in Western Australia, working with the Hardie company. They had very efficient plant that was working three days a week because that was all the pipe they could sell in Western Australia. They had Asian subsidiaries that were overloaded with work. There was a boom in development work in Asia at the time and they thought they would try to service some of their possible contracts out of Perth. They went to the shipping company that was servicing, very competitively, their Asian subsidiaries and invited it to give quotes to come to Australia. The shipping company refused point blank to do so and said it would not operate out of Australian ports because of the difficulties it had coming and going. I do not know whether some of its ships were of a very low standard, but Hardie's is a very responsible company and I am sure it would wish to get its product safely to port.

We have to remember that there is certainly an understanding in international shipping and other areas that Australia is a very difficult place in which to operate. On one occasion when I queried why Australian freight rates were about the same level as those in the war zone of the Red Sea, one shipper said to me, `Up there we lose a boat occasionally, but in Australia we never know when we are going to get them back'. I think those matters must be put on the record as well, because whilst I support wholeheartedly the proposal of shipping coming in and out of Australian ports—I am on the record as making some other suggestions—I believe that in that process we must be extremely responsible.

Unfortunately, the word `safety' has been elevated to a point of industrial negotiation. That is a pity. I am astounded, for instance, that in the building industry a matter of safety can be settled with money. I just do not see that people can be made safer by paying them more money. Yet we see this time and time again. When people do those sorts of things, it brings the issue of safety—which is very important—into disrespect.

I put it on the record that, whilst I am totally supportive of the motion—and I am totally supportive of the concerns expressed today by members of the Government—when we have our inquiry we must make sure that we do not follow what Australians and other people seem to do so often: go from the extreme of a ship that is an eighth of an inch thick to demanding rules and conditions that would make Australia totally uncompetitive.

In closing, I would like to remind people of the benefits that we could achieve as a nation if we had a major international shipping industry. I am not a supporter of a closed shop in any way, and for that reason I believe our interstate shipping should be more competitive and open to other operators. We hear the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) talking constantly about value added. The quickest bit of value adding that we can do is to freight our own goods in and out of our own country. That is a pretty significant fact. I have just checked some figures, and for 1988-89 shipping freighted into Australia totalled 33 million tonnes and shipping freighted out of the country totalled 267 million tonnes. That is a lot of freight. Every bit of freight leaving Australia goes a long way towards improving our finances.

The current account deficit for 1990-91 was $15.7 billion. The export aspect of shipping represented a loss of $605m, and the loss on shipping for imports was $3 billion. Three and a half billion dollars out of $15 1/2 billion related to shipping in and out of this country. Surely we should be looking to increase our shipping on world best practice. That includes letting seamen go to sea for longer. Maybe we can get some flats on the boats so they can take their families with them. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join with other honourable members in supporting the motion moved by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He has asked me to apologise for his absence for the rest of the debate; he has to chair a meeting. I was pleased to see that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) was supporting the motion as well.
—He is good on shipping.

—It flies in the face of the Liberal Party's position. He talked about trying to increase Australia's involvement in the shipping industry. I believe it is Liberal Party policy to remove the existing restrictions through the cabotage system.
—And I said that.

—That is a great pity. On the one hand, he said that he wants to increase Australia's involvement and do something about international safety standards yet, on the other hand, he is saying that he wants to allow all the foreign ships to take over Australia's internal and domestic trade. Those two things have to be in conflict. After all, the present rule, as honourable members would know, is that a foreign vessel can ship cargo on the domestic routes only if there is no Australian vessel available. It seems that the honourable member for O'Connor is saying that he is happy to see the foreign vessels come in. That flies in the face of what he just said: he wants to see more freight or goods carried by Australian vessels.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for O'Connor also had a crack at the unions in the building industry again. It is typical. He keeps forgetting that they have an enviable record when it comes to safety. It was the unions in the building industry that set standards for scaffolding. It was the unions in the building industry that set standards for the use of asbestos and finally got people to remove asbestos, and that set even air-conditioning standards.

I welcome the comments of the honourable member for O'Connor in supporting what the honourable member for Shortland and others have said here, but I think that he ought to rethink his own position, as far as the Liberal Party is concerned, when it comes to allowing foreign vessels to come into Australia. He is willing to let flag of convenience ships come to Australia. He has just made a speech that I took note of. I thought it was an excellent contribution in regard to safety issues. He talked about the problems that have come about because of the lack of standards. That is what this issue is about; it is a question of safety and an issue of seaworthiness of foreign vessels.

I acknowledge the point made by the honourable member for O'Connor about the Greek vessel, the Kirki. I was told that the thickness of the plating was the thickness of a sheet of newspaper, instead of the width of a matchbox. We need to argue the issue of safety. If we are going to do that we need to protect Australian ports. At the moment there is simply no way that we can test the standards of the ships coming here. There is no pre-inspection system; there is no international arrangement whereby we know the standard of the ships coming here. We do not know anything about them until they actually berth. They are the issues we ought to tackle. It certainly raises the question of the standards of the flag of convenience ships—those that register in countries such as Panama and Liberia for virtually little or no cost. The standards of those ships are inadequate, if they exist at all. The consequence is risk to property, people, seamen and passengers. I join with other speakers in saying that there is a need for tougher enforceable international standards.

We have the right as a country to know exactly what vessels are coming into port. We have a right to know not only that they are coming here, but also whether they are safe. Yet this information is not available. We have no advice as to the adequacy of standards. We have no certification of the standards. As we found with the Kirki, we could have a ship break up a few kilometres from the coast and there is always the risk of loss of property and of lives.

I would argue in line with what is being said in the motion. Not only should we note it, but Australia needs to do more about it. There is surely a need for an international forum on this issue. There is a need to give greater priority to internationally enforced standards. Where we have ships of convenience moving around this nation, placing at risk property and people, then we need to speak out against it. That is exactly what the motion is doing: it is expressing concern about the unseaworthiness of foreign vessels visiting Australian ports.

The honourable member for Shortland made the point—I want to reiterate it—that we do not need any further argument about it; we need standards. We need to have an increase in the inspection rules. We need to invoke some sort of system whereby we know that there will be a standards test on ships at their port of departure. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to congratulate the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) on moving this motion this morning. The motion notes the loss of bulk carriers, deplores the needless loss of life of seafarers, expresses concern about the unseaworthiness of foreign vessels visiting Australian ports and calls on the Minister for Aviation and Shipping Support (Senator Collins) to take action. That is a very appropriate motion for him to move.

PARA.TAB: Australia is very dependent on bulk carriers because our iron ore, iron ore concentrates, coal, wheat, alumina and bauxite are all dependent on export by bulk carriers. This motion is aimed at bulk carriers and rectifying the deficiencies in safety factors. The problem with the debate as it has progressed, however, is that we have been able to detect within members of the Australian Labor Party the wish to use safety features as a process whereby they can make work for painters and dockers and perhaps provide unnecessarily stringent requirements, set not by safety standards but by the whim of those who happen to be on the job doing it. Their self-interest will naturally encourage them to go beyond international standards.

Australia needs to observe international standards. We have plenty of powers under the Navigation Act to apply to foreign vessels the requirements that are necessary. The fact is that it is not being done. The way in which the Government has chosen to protect the Australian industry is by imposing cabotage charges. That has the effect of frightening off all but the bravest of shippers wanting to put their vessels on the Australian coast.

In a recent survey it was found that 4 per cent of inward cargoes come fortnightly or more often, and 70 per cent of inward cargoes come monthly or less frequently. By contrast, 19 per cent of outward cargoes go fortnightly or more often, 29 per cent go between fortnightly and monthly, and 52 per cent go monthly or less frequently. It is not surprising that exporters are really concerned about shipping movements. When a question was put to them as to whether they would prefer slight freight charges or a decrease in the turnaround time, the cry was that a slight increase in freight charges could easily be carried by Australian exporters, but the tying up of vessels and the inconsistency of our delivery times are of greatest concern to them.

In summary, I would like to see proper and effective safety measures applied to vessels carrying bulk cargoes on the Australian coast. It is important for the environment, for the protection of lives and for fishing opportunities that this be done. We should ensure that there is no pollution and damage to Australia by making sure that vessels safely carry the cargoes that we want them to carry.

Alternatively, safety should not be used, as it is used in some areas, as a means of gaining extra opportunities for militant unions to apply their rules to this process. So the line between those two things has been part of the debate today. The honourable member for Shortland was impeccable in his presentation, not seeking to move into that protectionist union supporting attitude. Other speakers have not been so careful and they stand exposed for the real purpose of the motion. I support the motion.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! It being 12.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with Sessional Order 104A. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.
Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I grieve for my State of Tasmania, and first of all for the uncertainty in it. For the last seven weeks I have spoken about the Greens. I think it is pretty well known that I have not got very much time for the five Greens in Tasmania. I believe that they have created a situation in which Tasmania is on its knees. Many of the press reports about the Greens have been very damaging to the State of Tasmania. I believe also that people from this other island—I mean Australia—have a false illusion of what has happened in Tasmania. It is all very well to care for the birds and the bees and the trees but, regrettably, there are a lot of people who need protection and who need help and assistance. I believe that the five Greens collectively have done a lot of damage to Tasmania. I first of all grieve on that particular point.

PARA.TAB: Tasmania is a very unusual place. It has 430,000 people, with about 200,000 located in the south of the State. It is a very close community. After being a politician for 16 years, I have begun to understand a little bit of the intricacies of Tasmania, which can sometimes be to the detriment of people in public life. They can be very enclosed.

It is very difficult to criticise the media because the media has the last laugh. It can ruin a politician. I do not wish to criticise the media. However, there are a small group in Tasmania who might eat together and have a few drinks together, but they know exactly what is going on. I watch with interest sometimes the way that they create a situation in which the people of Tasmania can believe it and the people on this other island, this big island—the mainland—can believe it also. That has perturbed me for a long time. I believe that what they have done to Robin Gray has been absolutely cardinal.

In this place I have parliamentary privilege. I do not usually like that; I usually like to say exactly what I think and what I feel, and it is too bad for the person at whom that might be directed. I hope that I have never become bitter. I hope that I have never become nasty. I hope that I have never really tried to harm anybody.I make no excuse for the fact that Robin Gray is a friend of mine. Over the 16 years that I have been in federal politics, at times I have been involved with Robin Gray. At times we have agreed and at other times we have disagreed. However, when I read what has happened to that man, I despair. When a person is in public life, that person can be ruined by the stroke of a pen, at the whim and fancy of a royal commissioner. The fact that a person might be a very learned judge or a very learned barrister or solicitor does not mean that he cannot be biased. It does not mean also that he cannot have a preconceived idea before bringing down his deliberations.

I find it incomprehensible that a man such as Robin Gray particularly can be not charged and yet brought to his knees by a report that unnecessarily, I believe, cost the taxpayers of Tasmania money. It cost over $1m for a report that found nothing different from what the police found. The report has not ruined Robin Gray but it has brought him to his knees.

The other day I read a letter in the Australian by his family.
