I would like to read that letter to this House because it is indicative of what can happen to any honourable member if he is put in a position in which somebody else can judge him and find out certain things about him, while his family know, in their heart and soul, that this man, their father, is innocent. This letter reads as follows:

As the sons and daughter of Robin Gray, we would like to express how proud we are of our father. He is innocent of any involvement in the bribe attempt and Justice Carter's ignorance of 23 witnesses indicating Robin Gray's innocence is completely unsatisfactory.

The fact is that if our father knew of the attempt, Justice Carter should have found evidence that would send him to trial. Justice Carter could not find any evidence, because no such evidence exists. So for Justice Carter to say that our father acted improperly is unfair, given that this is merely Justice Carter's interpretation of circumstantial details provided in the commission (those which are not admissible in a court of law) and not based on evidence.
In relation to the $10,000 donation, Ben and others gave evidence to show that Robin Gray never had any intention of keeping the money.
We are proud to be Robin Gray's children and he can hold his head high!

SPEECH.PARA: It is signed by Ben Gray, Jeremy Gray and Nicola Gray.

PARA.TAB: I just cannot believe what has happened to Robin Gray in Tasmania. For example, yesterday, 13 November, the Hobart Mercury led off with the headline, `Parliament says Gray should quit'. However, it did not say that the Parliament was led by the Labor Party and the Greens. It did not mention the fact that the Liberal Party in Tasmania has given its utmost support to Robin Gray. It has stood by him. It believes also that he has been the object of a nasty vendetta by the smiling Mr Field, the Premier of Tasmania, who smiles every time he is on TV. Of course, he is obsessed with power. He wanted to be the Premier of the State. He sold his soul to the devil when he joined in collusion with the Greens to form a government that has created the highest unemployment ever in Tasmania. It has created the biggest uncertainty that anyone could wish for a State and, as a result, it has been the worst possible government.

Mr Field today, thank God, has recognised his mistake and has come out with a vitriolic attack on the Greens. He is reported as `accusing the Greens of misplaced, self-righteousness and foolishness and of playing political games'. He has suddenly realised that the resource security in Tasmania, which cost the taxpayers of Australia $10m to bring into play, was rejected by the Greens because—let us face it—they do not want one tree chopped down in Tasmania. They want Tasmania to stay as it is, just for the benefit of a few people who would like to put a knapsack on their back and walk around Tasmania, and they forget about the ordinary people who are involved in the timber industry and about the other people who derive benefit from the Tasmanian timber industry. Of course we do not want to see Tasmania left barren; of course we do not want to see every tree chopped down. We need a balance. We need a balance between the environment and the interests that create jobs for Tasmanians.

All of a sudden Mr Field has realised that the combination with the Greens has been such a fruitful folly.There has been much publicity in Tasmania. I have said in this place many times that people such as myself, who try and care for the ordinary Tasmanians, do not get any publicity because we sometimes shoot from our hips and say, `Look, wake up Tasmania! Wake up Tasmanians! You have had the Greens for nearly three years, and look what they have done to you. You have crucified Robin Gray. You have brought him to his knees'. But, no, I do not believe that Robin Gray will be brought to his knees. I believe that the sensible Tasmanians will realise that this man has been vilified and has borne the brunt of a vendetta by the Labor Party and Mr Field and also by the smiling Mr Patmore. I have been told that he is a nasty piece of work. I do not know him very well, but I am told that he is a nasty piece of work and that he holds grudges. I am told that he would like to get Robin Gray, if he could, at every opportunity.

Those sorts of things just have to stop if we are to bring stability back to Tasmania. I think that the whole sorry episode concerning Mr Rouse and what happened with the deception and the bribe that was offered to one of the Labor politicians should be forgotten. I do not condone what Mr Rouse did. If we have a democracy, we have to live within the rules of that democracy and people have to do the right thing. But I think he has paid the price for that. I think he has lost everything that he had. He had great wealth; he had great stature in Tasmania as a businessman. But he has lost it all. He has paid his debt, and I think that the matter has to be buried and forgotten.

In Tasmania we have to go on and make certain that we can bring back economic benefits and that Tasmania becomes a proud State once again. All the bitterness of all the things that have occurred over the last few months has to be forgotten. Most of all, I think Robin Gray has to be given another chance to prove that he can be a good leader in Tasmania. This vendetta against him has to be forgotten. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In September 1987, when I made my maiden speech to this House, I canvassed the need to reform the structure of government itself in Australia. Australia as a federation has from the outset been in the grip of a conflict between the national and State governments—in simple terms, a battle between those who contend that the national government should be responsible for the setting of goals and the achieving of them and those who believe that State governments are more effective in responding to the needs of the people.

PARA.TAB: Our Constitution divides law-making power between the two levels of government. It specifically lists the subjects about which this Parliament can make laws while other areas not so listed are in the hands of the States. The exclusion of the Commonwealth from many areas has been viewed by many, particularly in the Labor Party, as a major constraint to reform. Indeed, as early as 1911, only a decade after Federation, the then Prime Minister Andrew Fisher described the Constitution as a dead hand on a reforming government. Fisher pursued a program of constitutional reform which arguably remains the most ambitious attempted by an Australian Prime Minister. In both 1911 and 1913 he put to the Australian people a sweeping referendum to extend the Commonwealth's powers over trade and commerce, control of corporations, monopolies, and labour and employment, including wages and conditions and the settling of disputes. On both occasions the proposals were defeated and in 1913, with the referendum held in conjunction with a general election, the negative vote contributed to Fisher's defeat at the polls by one seat.

The fate of Fisher's attempt to reform the Constitution has largely been shared by all those attempts that followed. Labor's attempts to gain constitutional reform, at least through referendum, have mostly been unsuccessful. In the last 20 years, three further serious attempts have been launched to revise our system of federalism. In the 1970s the Whitlam Government instituted a series of Constitutional Conventions involving both State and Commonwealth governments and, certainly, politicians from both sides. Although these conventions were useful and raised the level of debate, no meaningful reform flowed from them. In 1985, the then Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, appointed a Constitutional Commission under the leadership of Sir Maurice Byers. The Commission reported to the Parliament in 1988, and we all recall the rather ill-fated attempts to have four very simple reforms to the Constitution agreed to by referendum. The Australian people rejected these reforms, generally overwhelmingly, with most of the questions gaining less than 40 per cent of the popular vote.

Against this background, it is not surprising that the High Court has played a significant role in interpreting the Constitution to meet the changes thrown up by changing times. The High Court has gone through several periods of interpretation, but it is fair to say that in recent times it has taken the view that the Constitution must be read in such a way as to allow the national Parliament to make laws that recognise Australia's role in the international community.

In that context, the sometimes petty sensitivities of State governments cannot stand in the way of the Commonwealth being able to govern in the national interest. However, it is not the role of the High Court to make political decisions about the appropriate roles of State and Federal parliaments. The division of power between the States and the Commonwealth is an issue that law-makers in all Australian parliaments have to make decisions on. In this context the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) launched the third serious attempt to reform our system of federalism in recent times. That process has stalled. However, while this is of concern, it should not really surprise us.

It should be remembered that in July 1990 the Prime Minister proposed that Australia spend the decade leading up to the centenary of Federation debating the future of our federal system and attempting to make it serve better the people of Australia; that is, it was going to be a decade-long process, not one decided in a number of Premiers Conferences in the first year.

If the 1990s do in fact see a decade of debate and, hopefully, reform in federalism, then the failure at this stage to reach agreement on fiscal imbalance probably will count for very little. This is especially so when one compares the process the colonies first went through in the 1880s in reaching agreement about nationhood. Nonetheless, I think most Australians will be disappointed with the attitude adopted by the States. Certainly the States are correct in wanting to have a guaranteed level of income and certainty about that level over a period of time. But surely no-one can reasonably expect that Australia will move down the path which will see separate State income taxes evolve. That debate really ended in Australia some 50 years ago and fond memories on behalf of the States about the good old days really do not advance the debate. In any event, a more fundamental question must be answered before discussions on fiscal imbalance in the division of power proceeds, and that is whether a nation of 17 million people really needs three levels of government.

For many years prominent Australians, including the Prime Minister prior to his election to Parliament, foresaw an Australia where the States would be replaced by a two-tiered system of a national government and stronger regionally oriented local government. I think that, if we had a blank sheet to work from, a country of our size really would not need the number of politicians and the level of bureaucracy that it has. The reality, of course, particularly given the Australian public's well-demonstrated reluctance to embrace even minor constitutional reform, is that the basic structure of federalism is here to stay unless that proper debate over a long period can change the nation's outlook. Such a debate in my view is worth while and I think the Commonwealth should promote debate on the basic structure of our federal system while attempting to make what we have work better.

The disappointing aspect at this stage, in my mind, is that the States can see nothing worth while about the process, unless they can get their hands on more money or at least have the ability to get more money. Surely sorting out the proper division of responsibilities and the issues of service delivery alone merit the continuation of the Special Premiers Conference process. That the States, five out of six of them with Labor governments, do not accept this is something that I find very difficult to understand.

In the end, I suspect, the current disappointment will be only a hiccup and that reform will continue. When we look at the basic facts we see that we are a small country; we are trading in a world which is becoming increasingly hostile to us; we have a large international debt; and we have, obviously, compelling economic problems. That we should walk away from what, I think, can fairly be regarded as the most significant area of reform—the way in which government operates—is a luxury that we cannot afford. Various State Premiers have been reported in the media and on television in recent days as saying that they are pulling out of the Conference and that they are disappointed that there is not going to be debate about the State income tax. Their saying, `We are going to take our bat and ball and go home' does those State Premiers no credit whatsoever.

Before speaking in this debate I had a look at the Labor Party's national platform in relation to constitutional reform and the division of responsibilities between the States and the Commonwealth parliaments. That platform makes it perfectly clear that the orientation of the Labor Party is towards the development of a strong, effective national government. Again, I find it hard to understand and extremely disappointing that Labor State Premiers can get so caught up with issues within their own borders that they can tend to lose a national perspective. That is not a fault just of the Labor Premiers but, because there are more State Labor governments in this country, the Labor Premiers have responsibility for seeing this process through at this time.

I hope that the process continues. I am confident that it will. I think maybe some time in the future—and I look forward to this day—a republican Australia with a modern system of national government will deliver the services that Australia needs effectively, efficiently and in a much better manner than is currently the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have had two weighty issues brought before us in the grievance debate. The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) used his time to talk about Commonwealth-State relationships and the future of Australia. I think it is good to see the grievance debate focusing on some of those types of issues. Also, of course, prior to that, the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) mentioned royal commissions. I want also to speak today about royal commissions.

PARA.TAB: On 22 April this year, the Carter Royal Commission into an Attempt to Bribe a Member of the House of Assembly and Other Matters began its hearings into the allegation of political bribery surrounding the 1989 Tasmanian State election. Six months later, after 42 days of public sittings, 107 witnesses and expenditure of over $1m, the findings of the Commission were released last week on Tuesday, 5 November. Because of the nature of these findings and the process adopted by the Commission, I believe, along with many other Australians, that injustice has occurred. No-one doubts the involvement of Mr Edmund Rouse in an act that I believe represented a frontal attack on our democratic processes. The testimony of evidence, witnesses, his own admission and subsequent gaol sentences are a monument to that act.

This is not the case in regard to Robin Gray. The Commission did not find that he had acted unlawfully. Bribery and the possible involvement of the number one Minister of state are very serious matters which the public has a right to know about. But, equally, everyone has a right to be dealt with fairly and justly. I do not want to dwell on the particulars of this Royal Commission in detail because I want to speak more generally than that. What happened in this Royal Commission—I have not gone back to read a lot about royal commissions previously, but it has happened in others as well, I know—would not happen in a court of law. One may ask why. Why can the proceedings and the standards of a royal commission be lower than those of a court? After all, are not royal commissions called infrequently because they are very serious matters? The courts are in action daily. Therefore, if the standards of a royal commission are different, should they not be higher rather than lower?

Our system of justice in the courts is based on the principle of innocent until proven guilty. The standard of proof in a court would have been proof beyond reasonable doubt. In the Carter Royal Commission the evidence did not establish guilt proven beyond reasonable doubt with respect to the Hon. Robin Gray, MHA, otherwise charges would have been laid. To put it another way, there was such a degree of doubt about the evidence that Mr Carter believed that it would not stand up in court. The same conclusion was arrived at by the Tasmanian Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Damian Bugg, after consideration of police investigations—and without spending the $1m.

Because of the seriousness of an act of bribery, I am certain that if there had been one shred of evidence against the former Premier he would have been charged. There was not. Mr Gray was a most successful Liberal Premier and he has had his career shattered on the basis of suspicion. In a sense, it was a trial by assertion and implication. No citizen should have his career and personal standing so attacked.
As the editorial of the Sun-Herald of 7 November states:

SPEECH.PARA: We do not presume to judge Mr Gray's role in this sordid affair, but we do argue that the Royal Commission's finding though in accord with the terms of reference has unintentionally and inevitably treated Mr Gray with absolutely no regard for fairness.
I say to the Australian people and I say to this Parliament: if we are to have royal commissions they should at least be fair.

PARA.TAB: Today, I am not arguing a case for Robin Gray the individual. The issue is far greater. Mr Gray became associated with this commission of inquiry not because of himself but because he had the leadership of a major political party, a party which an arrogant businessman wanted to govern the State, despite not having gained a majority of seats at the most recent election. That is the sole basis on which Robin Gray got involved in this Royal Commission. That could happen to anyone in this Parliament who became leader of one of the major parties here or in our State parliaments.

The actions of this Commission have raised the question: should the Parliament require findings in cases such as this to be made on the higher evidence of proof, as required by the criminal jurisdiction? I believe it should. Don Chipp, a former leader of the Australian Democrats, on page 50 of the Sunday Telegraph of 10 November 1991, was reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a man's career has been shattered with allegations of misconduct being found on the balance of probabilities.

I say that it is not satisfactory that the higher standards of proof be not used in such important matters of personal and public justice. Suspicion is not a necessary and sufficient condition to prove guilt. The evidence must move any person from a cognitive position of being suspicious to one of being convinced. Under our system of justice it is not enough to suspect a citizen of guilt, no matter who they are. That guilt must be proven beyond reasonable doubt.

PARA.TAB: Mr Gray is the latest example of someone who can be placed on trial publicly, without adequate safeguards for the protection of the right to natural justice. For findings to state that actions were improper but not unlawful is, I believe, a denial of the right to natural justice. Adding to the travesty of justice that has occurred is the injustice that a citizen, as in this case, can be committed to pay his or her legal costs, yet not be charged. For a State Government to act in this manner and deny legal costs is not a sign that it is searching for truth, but rather one of retribution and malice.

The expectation that Mr Gray, or any other person for that matter, should be forced to find legal costs of $135,000—probably more—when no charges have been laid is unfair and unjust. If we have royal commissions, maybe everybody who goes before them, no matter what happens, should have their costs covered because they concern matters of high public importance. Otherwise, royal commissions should not be called. Mr Gray has repeatedly denied knowledge of the bribery attempt by Mr Rouse. After intensive investigation the Commission was unable to prove otherwise. Yet, at the moment, the defendant is liable.

This latest Royal Commission highlights the need for parliaments to ensure that future royal commissions be directed to use the higher standard of proof; that is, `beyond reasonable doubt' and not `on the balance of probabilities' and that payment of costs be made for defendants not charged. Maybe we can give consideration to covering the costs for all people who appear before royal commissions. I am suggesting that at least we give directions to our royal commissions to have the highest standard of proof and to cover the costs of at least those people who are not charged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of grievance because, as many people in this Parliament would realise, the city of Fairfield which is within my electorate has one of the highest rates of unemployment within Australia. The people in my electorate are hurting. All they want is the chance to work.

PARA.TAB: My grievance today is that these people are not being given an equal chance to obtain a job, as many of them are now discriminated against because of their age. It was recently brought to my attention that an increasing number of my constituents believe that they are missing out on jobs because of their age. The over-40s category of people looking for work is apparently now the hardest hit, as many of the jobs being advertised have strict age limits attached. My point is reinforced by an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 22 October, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: People at 40 today are barely acceptable to some employers, judging by the plethora of job advertisements specifying younger workers. By 45 or 50, they have crossed the Rubicon. They have become the Older Worker, a social problem, the butt of employer prejudice and discrimination.

I add at this stage that in a survey I conducted, the average age of members of the House of Representatives is 48 years of age; of senators, 49.3 years of age; and of members and senators, 48.4 years of age.

PARA.TAB: Although in the area that I am addressing no age group looking for work is spared in a recession, the over-40 age group seems to be suffering the most from discrimination. These are the people who have established families and have the added pressures of keeping a roof over the heads of their children and food on the table. According to that aforementioned article, today's 40-year-olds often have young children or babies. They expect and need to work another 20 to 25 years. Often they have huge mortgages. They need the protection of age discrimination laws, which few States have enacted.

Unfortunately, New South Wales is one of those States which has not, as yet, enforced any laws about age discrimination. With the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate at 9.7 per cent in that State, any law which will contribute to equal opportunities for those looking for a job is, I would think, vital. South Australia has already amended its equal opportunities legislation to cover age and it is now unlawful to treat people unfairly on the basis of age in advertising in that State. This means it is illegal to publish or cause to be published an advertisement in South Australia that indicates an intention to discriminate on the grounds of age. The Act also includes employment advertising originating from interstate which appears in South Australia, even if the job being offered is located interstate.

This new legislation enables South Australian applicants to pursue work without age being a barrier. Complaints can now be made to the Equal Opportunity Commission in South Australia if an employer discriminates on the basis of age when hiring, sacking and training employers. Other States are also considering legislation to guard against age discrimination. According to an article in the Business Review Weekly of 19 July:

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales was the first state to propose legislation against age discrimination, but its original package of reforms has been altered significantly. Compulsory retirement has been outlawed, but further amendments to the Anti-Discrimination Act have been dropped because of pressure from employer groups.

In view of the unemployment problem facing New South Wales, and particularly my area of Fairfield, the New South Wales Government should stand up and have the guts to make the necessary changes to enforce anti-discrimination legislation, as the South Australian Government has already done.

PARA.TAB: The Council for Equal Opportunity and Employment, which was established by the Business Council of Australia, and the Confederation of Australian Industry in 1986 issued a report in regard to discrimination which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Age discrimination can occur in any sphere of a person's life. However, most age discrimination complaints in Australia and overseas relate to employment, in particular to discrimination against older workers.

I know that a number of my constituents would agree with that statement. One woman who contacted me was 43 years of age, single and had been unemployed for over eight months. Over the years, this woman has struggled to educate herself, single-handedly support her family and pay a mortgage. She felt that she was now considered too old for executive appointments. However, male executives the same age as her were considered to be too young when applying for those jobs. She said that she now wondered whether her next step was to lie about her age, to be able to compete on the job market.

PARA.TAB: Another case that I can bring to mind is of a male constituent who was also over 40. Recently he came to see me for help, as he had been retrenched from his factory job. He had been unable to find work to support his wife and three children since that time. He was not eligible to receive unemployment benefits of any kind as his wife was working part time in a supermarket. This man did not know where to turn and he felt that he was being discriminated against because of his age when applying for jobs. In light of this, should we not, as a Federal government, also consider legislating against age discrimination on a wider scale?

For instance, perhaps age discrimination should be addressed in regard to our Commonwealth Employment Service. It has been brought to my attention that there is nothing in the current CES manual for CES officers which deals with age discrimination complaints. Surely in this day of equal opportunity and anti-discrimination we can legislate to ensure that discrimination on the basis of age is not acceptable in jobs advertised by the CES. Although age has been a popular criterion for employers to measure the level of experience needed in a job candidate, job advertisements that specify the age of an applicant are fast becoming offensive and inappropriate.

In the minutes remaining to me, I would also like to bring to the attention of the House my concern with the delay in New South Wales in introducing the Jobskills program which was announced by our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the March economic statement. This program is currently operating in Queensland and Western Australia, reportedly with some success. But there has been a decided lack of interest from local councils and other organisations eligible to participate in the program within New South Wales. The $45m Jobskills program will allow local government to employ additional staff and help ease employment problems in the local communities over the next two years. The objective of the Jobskills program is to improve the long term employment prospects of those who have been unemployed for 12 months or more by broadening their employment experience and equipping them with new skills through work experience and training.

I would not like to try to estimate the current number of people in my electorate who have been unemployed for more than 12 months, but I know that in the June quarter that figure reached approximately 3,500. Jobskills would, therefore, obviously have a viable place in the Fairfield community. Consequently, I am going to continue to investigate why this program has not been implemented in New South Wales as yet and is not even expected to begin before February of 1992 at the earliest.

I have been informed that at present there is resistance from some of the local councils and community groups in New South Wales to the Jobskills program, because they believe that it is too much like the old Commonwealth employment program which involved labour intensive and project related training. However, I have been assured by the Department of Employment, Education and Training that this is not the case.

There has also apparently been some opposition from a union group to the training wage provided for in the program; evidently the group believes Jobskills would mean program participants were working for the dole. I must say that I believe such fears to be unfounded. Jobskills will provide a combination of work experience and training which will be arranged through appropriate organisations which will be contracted to act as intermediaries or brokers.

I am particularly keen to have a Jobskills program initiated in Fairfield as soon as possible, as the Department has allocated in the program's budget 110 Jobskills places for Fairfield local government area. This is the largest number of Jobskills places allocated in any local government area in New South Wales and although Fairfield City Council is yet to decide whether it is interested in participating in the program as either broker or employer—or indeed at all—at least I am pleased to say that Wesley Mission's Skillshare project in Fairfield, Effect Employment, has expressed to me its interest in participating in the Jobskills program. I commend the Mission for it.

It was not until my inquiries in representation to the Department regarding the lack of Jobskills programs in Fairfield that the Council, I understand, investigated the feasibility of implementing such a program. DEET will be approaching Fairfield City Council personally and I sincerely hope that these discussions prove to be fruitful for the sake of all of those thousands of long term unemployed people living within my electorate. I have been informed that councils such as Parramatta, Blacktown, Liverpool and Bankstown have already been in contact with the Department and that DEET is now discussing with them the potential of the Jobskills program—an example that I hope Fairfield City Council will soon emulate. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to grieve on behalf of the 170 Victorians who are unable to get a job at the Camperdown abattoirs. This raises industrial relations issues of the 1990s and, in particular, the right to work, compulsory unionism, voluntary contracts between management and the work force, the role of picket lines, productivity, profitability, the use of contract labour and the high cost of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service in meatworks. I would like to refer to two other meatworks in Victoria. The Seymour abattoirs use a similar system that has been advocated at the Camperdown works. Seymour is a domestic abattoir and contract labour is being used on that plant. The inspection service has allowed the works to proceed and all is well in that plant—a plant which operates similarly to Camperdown.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the position in Wodonga in northern Victoria, members of this House would be aware that there was a major confrontation at that particular plant. Wodonga Meats suffered from 82 days of strikes by the AMIEU members, between May 1989 and April 1991, costing the company $3m in losses. In April of this year management said, `Enough is enough' and terminated the services of 11 union delegates who would not abide by the bans clause inserted into their award. A picket line was then established by these delegates and the usual AMIEU thuggery was used—and that was identified by the television coverage of that particular picket line.

At the end of that month, management was forced to send termination notices to 200 employees who had declined to sign an agreement stating that they would be available to work five days per week without imposing bans or going on strike—quite a normal, sensible arrangement between management and the work force, I would have thought. Eventually 182 staff were terminated, 82 of the original staff were kept on and the balance of 325 staff was met by hiring of the new staff, most of whom required training.

A bonus system of payments has meant that the work force is now achieving greater productivity in five days than the former unionised work force could achieve in four weeks, due to the continual imposition of bans, strikes and go slows by the AMIEU. We can contrast the production of 350 head of cattle and 2,800 head of small stock per day with the former union-approved tally system under which a level of 2,560 small stock and 260 head of stock was reached.

The workplace is safer and Workcare claims have been dramatically reduced. Most importantly, the work force is happier because people are grossing nearly $1,000 per week in some cases. Perhaps the most significant factor is that around 80 of the Wodonga meat employees are former AMIEU members. Other AMIEU stalwarts who declined the offer probably regret doing so.

I wish to return to the situation at Camperdown. Let us get the facts straight, because there has been a lot of misrepresentation about the argument at that abattoir. As far as the history of the abattoir goes, it was purchased by Mr Fami of Famicorp Pty Ltd. He operates a meatworks at Deniliquin and he decided to purchase the Camperdown abattoir in the hope of introducing new techniques and a new approach. What he was concerned about was the AMIEU attitudes to the low tally arrangements, working from 7.30 a.m. till midday. That was the eight-hour day. The work force was strike prone and historically it was very hard to get more than four days per week out of it.

What Mr Fami was really trying to do was to introduce a section 115 provision, which has been introduced into the meat award in Victoria with Don Smallgoods. A similar arrangement has been introduced by ICI at its Botany Bay plant and is working particularly well. Productivity has improved, the work force is much happier and the plant is returning to profitability.

In the instance of the Camperdown abattoir, the management decided to put on contract labour. Troubleshooters was employed to organise the contract labour with a view to increasing production output, similar to the situation in the building industry, where Troubleshooters has been employed on a productive basis to get the job done at a particular price. A confrontation and dispute took place between the new owner and the old unionists who maintained old attitudes. Wally Curran had been in charge of a regime where originally, some 10 or 15 years ago, there were 8,000 members in the AMIEU; there are now 1,700 members. So much for Wally Curran's creation of jobs. There used to be 20 export works in Victoria and now there are only six left, largely due to Wally Curran's anti-productive activities.

The situation in Camperdown was that the Federal meat inspection service approved the works for export licence and the licence was granted. Various things were repaired and put in order. I make the observation in passing that one of the problems facing meatworks all around Australia is the high cost of the meat inspection service—$69,000 per meat inspector, when in fact the inspectors are paid only $29,000. Having had the permission to operate, Famicorp Pty Ltd negotiated possible changes to work practices, as I was saying, to move away from the outdated Federal award. It employed Troubleshooters.

Following these arrangements, the picket line was instituted by the AMIEU. We had an old style picket line in an environment where we had one million unemployed Australians. These personnel had never been employed by the new company and we had a battle of ideology, not a battle for jobs. The picket line in technical terms was instituted outside the works. The picketers had their own toilet. They had a heap of wood to keep the fires burning during the cold month of September. They had a tent to make sure they could be protected from the weather. In fact, they were very well established. One of the difficulties for management was that the roadway outside the works was a demarcation line the Hampden Shire and the local city council, so both municipalities had some difficulty in making a decision about whether the obstruction should be removed from the front of the plant on the council property.

The union picket line, of course, was similar to other picket lines in Victoria where there are special deals done between the Government, the police and the union movement. It seems that unionists enjoy special privileges, unlike other Australians, when they are on a picket line. It was obvious in this particular picket line that they could conduct themselves in a manner that you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I and other members of this House would be put in gaol for or for which we would be charged with using abusive language and other unlawful acts.

I understand from investigation that the picket line can be removed if there are unlawful acts of public nuisance and obstruction. I understand that that is fairly difficult to prove in a court. On this occasion, it is quite obvious that violence, intimidation, bad language and physical jostling by those picketers on the picket line has taken place. But the courts in Victoria have been reluctant to remove the picket lines. I am in favour of the right to have peaceful protests, but not in the context of this sort of picket line.

When the works began to operate, we had 80 police on the site to allow workers to go to work. Five to 10 police horses were there to allow the workers to go to work. The workers had to leave the police station at 7 o'clock in the morning in a furniture van, be escorted by the police to the works and leave the works at 4.30 in the afternoon in a similar process in which they were abused and shouted at.

Troubleshooters was training these new workers. It has managed to improve the productivity and meat quality standards. Along with the difficulties faced by the workers travelling in a furniture van, the picketers managed to make sure that black bans were imposed on the truckies who entered the works and on processed meat in other parts of Victoria. What is more, the works were sabotaged during these very turbulent times.

The Victorian Minister for Agriculture, of course, has been part of the action and he raised the issue in the Victorian Parliament only yesterday. He said the meat was not approved; that is wrong. He suggested that the quality was not correct; that is wrong. He said that management was late going to the works; that is wrong. And he also said that the Liberal Party was part of these confrontation tactics; that is wrong. He used parliamentary privilege to make these outrageous claims.

What is happening in the Camperdown Meatworks is that the farmers want their animals processed, the workers want to work, the owner wants to get a return on his investment, the police want to return to their normal duties in other parts of Victoria, and I am quite confident that the picketers would like to get out of the cold and rain, return to their homes and not be involved in a worthless, useless and non-productive picket line which is stopping Australians getting work at a time when there are one million unemployed here in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to grieve on what I see as a fairly alarming tendency, in a situation of economic downturn, in certain sections of this Parliament—unfortunately on both sides of the House—to label certain groups as being opposed to any kind of economic or resource development. Two of the most obvious targets that are mentioned from time to time are conservationists, or Greens as they are called—we had an example of that in the Parliament this morning—and, of course, traditional Aboriginal communities.

PARA.TAB: I want to deal with that view for what it is, an essentially dangerous process, because it seems to me, certainly from the history of my own political party, that if one is dealing with an idea whose time has come, for many conservative or vested interest groups what one does is unfairly label the group, and thereby minimise the concept.

There are many people whose overwhelming political commitment is the preservation of the environment. As a group, they are probably more diverse than any of the political groupings in our own Parliament or in our established political parties. While maintaining their environmental concern, they may well disagree on what particular areas or projects are the subject of immediate concern. They may even disagree as to the tactics to be used. But it is important in a political democracy that we listen to the arguments that are being advanced rather than simply dropping a label on `the conservationists' or on `the Greens', on the basis that that means one does not really have to examine the merits of the propositions that are being put.

My own Party—and I have been in it for over 40 years—has constantly been a victim of that kind of strategy. I remember a time, as you would, Mr Deputy Speaker, not so long ago, when our own Party was amongst the first in Australia to recognise the reality of the Chinese revolution and say, `Well, we have to recognise the People's Republic of Red China'. We were immediately arraigned as fellow travellers and communist sympathisers. You would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, as other members of our House would know, that any unionist who happened to stand on a ticket for election to a union which may have contained a communist became a fellow traveller. Or if a union, which may have had a membership of 20,000 or 30,000 Australian citizens, had a communist officer it became a communist union. The purpose of that sort of terminology is to ascribe positions which do not necessarily hold for the organisation as a whole or for its membership. At this stage in Australia's development, I would have hoped we would have been mature enough not to use those sorts of labels.

I know, as do members of the Liberal Party and the National Party, that they are continually subjected to attempts by groups like the lunatic League of Rights to take over branches and to change their structures. That does not make every member of the Liberal Party a supporter of the League of Rights. There are, of course, differences of approach in the Labor Party. Therefore, I am putting my own position on record. I for one—and there are many individual members on both sides of this Parliament who feel deeply about environmental issues—am not going to simply be privy to a process whereby those concepts are downgraded and demeaned by using labels.

The same is true for traditional Aboriginal communities. We recently had the example of an independent commission, the Resource Assessment Commission—which was lauded both by representatives of Aboriginal communities and of the mining industry for its approach to the examination of all the evidence in respect of Coronation Hill. It is an extraordinary thing that a body as prestigious as this should examine all the arguments that are put and reach its conclusions, and those conclusions are then adopted by the Government—and an immediate attack is launched. The concept is again promulgated by no less a person, unfortunately, than the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), who became the disciple of the proposition that every time a mineral resource is discovered an Aboriginal group will find a sacred site. It is a demeaning concept; it is, essentially, part of an approach which should not have any credible position in our body politic.

At present these allegations are continuing to be made. We talk about speeding up resource development on the basis of having to deal with these groups. There is a certain inconsistency in our coalition Opposition talking about the freedom and the right of management and labour to reach voluntary agreements when at the present time in the Northern Territory a whole range of mining agreements that have been reached between Aboriginal communities, through their land councils, and mining developers are being held up on the basis that they are contrary to the provisions of the land rights Act.

Almost 15 years ago the mining industry was concerned that it would explore on Aboriginal land, with the permission of Aboriginal communities, and would find a mineral resource to be developed but that the negotiations that were to take place to bring that process to fruition would take a great length of time. The mining industry's concern was to speed up that process. I was Minister at the time and I responded to that because it seemed to me that there was evidence to show that these were legitimate concerns. But the process that was adopted was designed, first of all, to protect Aboriginal communities and, at the same time, to create a situation in which miners, having reached agreement about exploration, would not then find themselves hopelessly delayed when it came to development.

What has occurred in Aboriginal Australia since then has been a maturing and experience in respect of mineral development such that many Aboriginal communities, through their land councils or through their leadership, are perfectly happy. Once they are satisfied that their communities and their sacred sites are not under threat, they are more than happy to say to the miners, `Come in and explore and if you find something we'll develop it together or we'll discuss and negotiate about it'. And many mining companies are happy to do that.

There are at present no less than three disjunctive agreements—and that is how they are described. One is at Roper Bar, which involves 206 square kilometres; another is at Cox River, 2,898 square kilometres; and the third is at Beswick, an area of almost 2,500 square kilometres. These sorts of agreements have been reached freely between mining companies, on the one hand, and Aboriginal communities, on the other. But they have been held up because the Northern Territory Government—a conservative government that is part of this political grouping in Australia which says, `Really there has to be freedom of management and labour to negotiate' but which does not believe in freedom for mining companies or Aboriginal communities that have negotiated and reached agreement to proceed, because the Northern Territory Government and sections of the mining industry do not like disjunctive agreements.

There is going to be a court case wherein, and for the first time in history, the Northern Territory Government will actually be arguing, in my opinion incorrectly, to uphold provisions in the land rights Act. There are another three mining applications, involving large areas of land, which agreements are waiting to be signed, and the parties are delayed waiting the outcomes of the actions of the Northern Territory Government. In all, we are looking at agreements which have been reached for the exploration of over 15,215 square kilometres.

If we are talking about the way in which we need to develop Australia, we should not be in a situation in which various interest groups, both in this Parliament and outside this Parliament, are prepared to stick labels on various groups and say, `They are the people that are holding up development'. We cannot blame either the Aboriginal communities or the environmentalists in Australia for the economic plight that we now face. There have been many arguments and there will be more; that will involve Aboriginal communities and conservationists, and that is appropriate in a democratic community. But I think it is important that we look at the arguments as they are presented, and the reality of what is happening on the ground. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson Mr J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance is that many Aboriginal people may well be disadvantaged by the very structures that have been set up, ostensibly to help them. I frankly raise this subject with some reluctance because it seems that those who dare to challenge the prevailing orthodoxy run the gauntlet of being accused of racism. Therefore, I preface my remarks by saying that I care very much about what happens to Aboriginal people and, in common with my family before me, seek their best interests.

PARA.TAB: From the 1830s, first in the Hunter Valley and subsequently on the Clarence, my forebears maintained a tradition of good relationships with the local people; indeed, a member of my family is largely credited with leading the push for the vote for Aboriginal people in this country. To this day I enjoy a great friendship with an elderly Aboriginal lady in Gunnedah who often tells me of the great affection and regard that she had for my family in general, and my grandfather in particular, when she was a younger lady.

In turning to a sorry saga centring on Barwon Aboriginal Community Inc. at Walgett in my electorate, I reject any suggestion of motives other than those arising from genuine concern for the local Aboriginal people. Barwon Aboriginal community grew out of the Walgett Aboriginal Foundation, which was a charitable organisation devoted to housing, financial and funeral arrangements and, therefore, assistance for the local Aboriginal community. Today it is a registered company, limited by guarantee, which involves itself in a wide range of activities: Aboriginal housing, a bus service for the elderly, self-drive rental cars, general social work, the leasing out of a pub—the famous or, should I say, infamous Oasis—and construction enterprises. To put it mildly, the community has had a chequered career managing all of these affairs in recent times.

Until some 15 months ago the company was directed by one Mr Chris Wilson, under whom it had greatly expanded. Mr Wilson evidently had a mind like Albert Einstein's when it came to unearthing possible funding sources. After many allegations, he was dismissed from the company when he was charged with using brick pavers and an air-conditioning unit that belonged to Barwon Aboriginal community to upgrade his private

SPEECH.PARA: home. Over a year later that case has still not been heard, which is, in itself, quite disturbing. He allegedly charged $36,000 to a Westpac Mastercard which was provided to him for expenses incurred while carrying out his duties for BAC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like a National Party Minister to me.

—That is utterly ridiculous, and the honourable member, with that flippant remark, discredits the very Aboriginal people I am trying to help. Mr Wilson allegedly charged up the $36,000 on his Mastercard. Sources tell me that that money went on everything from motel accommodation through to dinners, cigarettes, a waterbed, a pushbike and linen.

PARA.TAB: Wilson was replaced by one Mr Phillip Hall, who allegedly had faced serious allegations here in Canberra before he went to Walgett and soon himself became a controversial figure. He took over a debt of about $120,000 and, after 18 months of activity, managed to leave behind a slightly increased one, of $340,000.

Mr Hall was eventually dismissed after an incident surrounding a boat, the specific purpose of which was to supply transport and food delivery during floods. The boat happened to belong to the Commonwealth. The boat was sold for $2,500 and had to be subsequently bought back for $5,000 or $6,000 when the legalities of the ownership were established.

More importantly, an internal audit suggested that many of the transactions undertaken by Mr Phillip Hall's use of BAC funds were suspect and doubtful. The audit was not an investigation into any allegation, just an examination of the management and accounting practices of BAC. It commented that quite often Mr Hall alone recommended and approved expenses, including his own expenses.

A report of the audit to ATSIC includes under the heading `doubtful and suspect transactions' over $20,000 paid to Walgett's Oasis Hotel for furniture and bedding—and there was no documentation; $9,000 for a computer which is not used by BAC—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! Can the chair inquire whether the person mentioned in the honourable member's speech has been charged or whether charges are pending?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. There was also no paperwork to support that transaction. Also included is an amount of $8,600 for plumbing—again no bill or invoice was available to support the payment, which Mr Hall himself approved.

PARA.TAB: Mr Hall was replaced by one Michael Anderson, under whom the drama continues. In response to the sale of the aforementioned boat, which was not BAC's to sell in the first place, ATSIC cancelled all funding in March of this year. I understand from sources within ATSIC that it will not be resuming funding while Mr Anderson is employed by Barwon.

The loss of $2m of taxpayers' dollars in annual income has produced an extraordinary flurry of activity as Barwon sells off assets, often at grossly undervalued levels, in an attempt to remain solvent. A tractor which cost $40,000-odd a couple of years ago has been exchanged, as I understand it, for outstanding rent of $2,000 or $3,000. One home was sold for $48,000, when its estimated value was around $85,000 to $100,000. Another valued at $65,000 has been sold for $35,000 on $3,500 deposit. I understand that, in addition, 13 Barwon Aboriginal community flats, worth perhaps $1.5m, are on sale for $250,000. Effectively, I can draw no conclusion other than that these assets are being sold to pay off fraudulently incurred debts in a manner well outside what I understand to be ATSIC's guidelines.

Well might it be asked, `Who wants to do something to clean up this mess?' The answer appears to be that just about everybody wants something done except those who apparently benefit from the situation. The local Aboriginal community wants the matter investigated and cleaned up, and why would they not? The local council wants the matter investigated. The local police want the matter cleaned up. The local inspector is a man I have the highest regard for and he frequently tells me of the incredible frustration that he feels in the face of this implausible situation. ATSIC personnel privately informed me that they believe it ought to be cleaned up and that the ASC ought to be involved. As the local Federal member I want it cleaned up and the Minister responsible, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), wants it cleaned up.

Despite the virtually unanimous recognition that the whole stinking mess needs cleaning up urgently before it erupts into something ugly on the streets of the town, virtually nothing has been done. Despite the best efforts, none of us, either singularly or together, has been able to have this matter resolved.

ATSIC's official position was quoted in the Sydney Morning Herald on 7 August this year. It said that it was under no obligation to investigate BAC, despite the findings of the internal audit. It said that under the ATSIC Act it was not obliged to pursue an inquiry into allegations surrounding the use of funds it allocated to BAC Ltd—although its cancellation of the corporation's $2m annual funding is a clear indication that it thinks that something is wrong.

The Walgett police have neither the authority nor the resources to undertake the massive auditing task that would be required to establish the true position and take appropriate action. The ASC, when it was asked by the Minister to involve itself, said it was not a priority. The New South Wales Fraud Squad, I have just been advised, is slowly coming around to thinking about doing something about this mess.

A great deal is being missed out on by the Walgett Aboriginal people: $2m worth of ATSIC funding has been withdrawn; 28 families are waiting for houses and up to 20 people live in one house; and services are being lost. It appears that nothing is being done about it.

I want to put it to the House that this is an extraordinarily unfortunate message to send out to the Aboriginal people in that community. It seems to suggest that they need not worry about the possibility of being caught out, reprimanded or in any way disciplined if they act in ways that might be regarded as less than appropriate. I put it to the House that that is an appalling model, particularly in the emerging situation where the Telegraph Mirror reported two days ago that Walgett is now the fourth-worst area in New South Wales for assault and the sixth-worst area for theft.
If my words are not enough, I record some words of a local European worker, a member of the Labor Party, who has sacrificed much of his life working for Aboriginal people in that town. He says:

When repeated instances of mismanagement, fraud, theft, blatant incompetence and nepotism are continually shoved into the too hard basket by politicians and bureaucrats afraid to bite the bullet for fear of being branded "racist", then you have an acceptance of second, third, or even tenth best as being the norm for Aboriginal organisations.

One could reasonably expect, given the shocking events of the past 200 years, that only the very best would be allocated in terms of personnel and programs and that only the highest standards would be acceptable to help overcome the deficits. Instead we have a crippling mediocrity, at best a maximum of inefficiency which constricts and engulfs policies and dooms this already disadvantaged group of Australians to perpetual economic and social poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: I put it to the House that without accountability we will never achieve justice for Aboriginal people. Without justice being done and being seen to be done, all the reconciliation processes and all the money in the world will achieve nothing for the Aboriginal people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Friday the House of Representatives Select Committee into Print Media held hearings in Canberra and the Chief Executive of West Australian Newspapers Ltd, David Aspinall, and the chief editor, Bob Cronin, appeared before the inquiry. The Saturday morning edition of the West Australian reported those events. I was particularly concerned about the way in which they were reported. Therefore, I wrote a letter to the West Australian.

PARA.TAB: The letter, as of this day, has not been published, so I intend to read it into Hansard. I received today a letter from the editor giving his reasons for not publishing my letter and expressing concern about the fact that some of the details in my letter did not relate to the terms of reference of the Committee. I indicate that, of course, the Committee has had a number of witnesses before it and indeed the questioning has been wide ranging and widely reported. The letter that I wrote reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The selective coverage of Friday's Print Media hearings by your newspaper is alarming. During two hours of questioning a number of issues relating to the West Australian and its performance and management were raised. Reports in the West on Saturday did not reflect the tenor or breadth of that questioning.

I imagine that the readership would be interested to know that the Chief Executive David Aspinall agreed that he may well continue in the ongoing management of the newspaper—contrary to a report in the West on November 5th.
That was just four days before. The letter continues:

The committee was told that he, as Bell Group chairman, negotiated his own contract with Bond Corporation (which appointed him to the board). The details of the contract, which was varied as late as July, 1991, are confidential.
Prospective buyers of shares in West Australian Newspapers Holdings might like to know that none of those appointed to the board of this new company have experience in newspaper management.

No doubt employees of the West Australian would like to be informed about the prospective redundancies outlined by Mr Aspinall in his evidence. Equally the evidence given by Professor Baxt regarding the closure of the Daily News would be of interest to journalists and the public alike.

Somehow a profitable business which previously held valuable property assets has become burdened with substantial debt as a result of Bell Group borrowings. Bell shareholders lost, bond holders lost and owners and management received little scrutiny.
The newspaper itself has carried little critical analysis of these events. Balanced coverage of Friday's hearings would have been in the public interest.
Copies of the full transcripts of the hearings are available from my office . . .
That is the letter that I sent to the West Australian; unfortunately it was not published.

PARA.TAB: The letter I got today from the editor of the newspaper gives reasons why it was not published. Basically, it says that these things were not of interest. In fact, Mr Aspinall's evidence contradicted a report in the West Australian just five days before. I believe that it would have been of interest for people to know that. Certainly his evidence in respect of his contract outlines the Bond culture that existed in Western Australia during the last decade. Indeed, electors in my area were horrified by the fact that Bond executives received salaries of $5m a year while the company was losing billions. There was no performance related reward for executives and there is considerable concern about that.

Other matters in the evidence that I have looked at since indicate clearly that some of the things that Mr Aspinall said have been contradicted in newspaper reports since then. He said, for instance, that Bond never borrowed any money whatsoever from the Bell Group; however, a report in the West Australian indicates that it did.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Dubois)—Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106, the debate is interrupted, and I put the question:
That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians take great pride in Gallipoli, although it was a major defeat for this country. We can take pride in it because, even though the defeat was probably inevitable, it was a courageous act and, in the context of that time, a correct act. The same cannot be said for Australia's actions when Indonesia invaded East Timor. Amongst ordinary Australians—the Australians who are not in Parliament and do not partake in foreign negotiations—there remains a great discomfort about Australia's abandonment of East Timor.

PARA.TAB: Fifty thousand East Timorese died resisting Japan's southward push and assisting Australians in the Second World War. However, our reaction when they were invaded was to abandon them. Many Australians still do not know why; I suspect that, like me, they feel a sense of shame when the East Timorese issue is raised.

Usually we can forget it and take comfort in the reassuring statements that are issued from time to time assuring us that all is well in East Timor; the Indonesians are benign dictators who, in contrast to their former colonial ruler, have furthered the welfare of the local population; health and education have improved; and resistance is confined to a handful of extremists.

The massacre at the Santa Cruz cemetery at Dili shatters this illusion of a compliant population and a benevolent military. It is time that the Australian Government re-examined the situation in East Timor and asked what our moral obligations to that country and its people really are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a desperate attempt to appeal to the emotions of people living in one of Australia's sunniest cities, the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) issued in Townsville on 4 July this year a media release in which he gave a so-called example of the unfair nature of the wholesale sales tax. The Leader of the National Party referred at first to toothpaste and then said:

SPEECH.PARA: Worse still is the 20 per cent on the sunblock and skin protection creams essential in preventing skin cancer in this sun-drenched country.

I have news for the Leader of the National Party. The truth is that all manufacturers of skin block products of SP4 and above are eligible for sales tax exemption. Provided their product conforms to Australian standards, no sales tax is applicable.

PARA.TAB: If one of the coalition's supreme leaders cannot even get his facts straight on sunblock, how can the Liberal and National parties expect anyone to believe their consumption tax propaganda? Consumption tax is bad news. Just as certainly as consumption tax would mean Townsville residents would be paying at least 15 per cent extra for a product that helps prevent skin cancer, it is more than just idle speculation that a Liberal-National consumption tax would be imposed on freight charges, adding even further to the burden.
In August 1990, Queensland National Party President, Don McDonald, admitted the following in a radio interview about consumption tax on freight:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of people who work in the towns of western Queensland and northern Queensland who won't get concessions, but who will pay those extra cents every time they buy something. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the attention of the House a serious and rampant abuse of Austudy in Australia. I have learnt from very concerned parents of government assistance to teenagers who walk out of perfectly good houses and call themselves homeless. They automatically receive Austudy at the student homeless rate of $226.50 a fortnight.

PARA.TAB: The ease with which these kids can do this appals me. They have only to find someone who will sign an affidavit saying that they have been verbally abused at home. Often the person signing the affidavit has no knowledge of the family at all. There is no independent assessment of the home and no visit by a social worker or government official.

One supposedly homeless boy in my electorate received a lump sum of more than $1,000 only a few days after he left home. The people who signed his affidavit had never met his parents. No-one even bothers to tell the parents where their children are. Frantic parents report their children missing, which wastes police resources as well. Parents, it seems, have no rights in this area. We have not only a financial responsibility to clean up the appalling waste of taxpayers' money, but also a moral responsibility.

Making it so easy for disgruntled teenagers to declare themselves homeless places a permanent strain on the family and can break it up. I do not need to tell the House what a serious charge child abuse is. What about the children in this nation who are really homeless, the kids who genuinely have no homes and are the victims of real abuse? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I am sure members opposite will also support his remarks in relation to the situation in Timor. I think that all the members of this House are tired of being misled by the Indonesian Government as to events in Timor. We have to put on record that the events there are barbaric. We have pursued a policy of appeasement for a number of years. Sadly, that has failed. What is now clear is that we need a policy for self-determination for the people of East Timor.

PARA.TAB: We can no longer tolerate this attempt by the Indonesian Government to continually mislead the people of Australia by saying that it is an internal matter or some sort of a disruption or that the demonstrators started it. The sad thing I find is that this country is a near neighbour of ours. We have pursued a policy of what I would regard as civilised engagement with that Government and, clearly, that has not worked. We do need self-determination and we do need to find out the full facts on what has happened there. I believe the Australian people deserve that. We need to get on record that we really feel strongly about the appalling behaviour of the Indonesian armed forces. I think members in this House would share those views.

In closing, Mr Deputy Speaker, I also say that I support the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in his move towards a national wool day and I would like to discuss the matter with him. I believe we could do something quite substantial in terms of motions we might move before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the House today because of an article I read only this morning which is of great concern to me. It is about the collapse of the Collinsville merino stud in South Australia, which must be of concern to all Australians and all woolgrowers. I believe this Parliament should turn its attention to the collapse of the Collinsville stud. One cannot have the collapse of a major stud such as the Collinsville stud, which influences a third of Australia's merino flocks, without it coming to the attention of this House. The risk we run as a nation is that it could be broken up piecemeal and sold off, or it could be sold off to foreign interests.

PARA.TAB: For a number of years, Collinsville has been at the sharp end of the high technology breeding industry. Perhaps the money it spent in that area has led to some of its financial problems. But it has made major advances and these advances could well be lost to the industry because of the lack of ability of the wool industry to take those up further. The cost of this loss to the wool industry and to Australia as a nation cannot, I believe, be overstated.

I also want to bring to the attention of this House today the motion of the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Hulls) which is order of the day No. 5 on today's Notice Paper. It calls for the banning of the export of merino breeding material. I believe that should not be removed from the Notice Paper. It should be brought forward, as a matter of urgency, for this Parliament to debate, in the light of the collapse of the Collinsville merino stud in South Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, child abuse, as the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) on the Opposition side said, is a very serious concern in Australia. It is my view that the greatest area of child abuse is what I call the intellectual abuse of children which is taking place in a lot of our schools today. It seems that children are subjected to a lot of pseudo-scientific nonsense and are being brainwashed with stories of doom, particularly in the environmental area.

PARA.TAB: The great purveyors of this sort of abuse, of course, are those in the welfare industry. I have a particular case in my area, in the town of Newman, where social workers, at their own behest, have taken young children aged 14 months and just over two years from the care of very caring foster parents and have sent them back to the Aboriginal community, where their future is very dismal indeed. Their chances of survival are not good and their chances of any sort of worthwhile or meaningful future are just about zero. Minister Ripper in the Western Australian Government deserves to be very strongly censured for being such a gutless Minister in the face of all the evidence presented him. His decision is a classic in the Yes, Minister vein, and I am sure that he will live to regret it; unfortunately, the children may not be so lucky.

TALK.START.PARA: —Chelsea Lodge, which is hostel accommodation attached to the Winchelsea Hospital, was opened by the hospital president, Jo Kelly, on Sunday, 10 November. This occasion was a time to pay tribute to all those people in the Winchelsea district who had brought this project to its final completion.

PARA.TAB: In 1984, the hospital committee decided to build a nursing home for the benefit of local residents. After years of negotiation and discussion it was finally agreed to construct a 16-unit hostel for the senior citizens of the district. The Federal Government contributed $410,000 to the total cost of $930,000. The balance of moneys came from philanthropic trusts, hospital capital funds and a magnificent fundraising effort by virtually every community group in Winchelsea and the surrounding locality.

I wish to place on record the community's appreciation to the hospital president, Jo Kelly, for his total commitment to the project, to the late Don Craig for his vision and enthusiasm and to Ian Peake for his unstinting efforts during the planning process.

The most noteworthy feature of the construction of Chelsea Lodge and its operation is the reflection in bricks and mortar of a selfless community prepared to work for an objective of caring for their aged in a local environment amongst their friends and relatives. The pioneering spirit of self-help is alive and well in Winchelsea.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, speak on East Timor because the massacre has added 100 or so to the 100,000 to 200,000 Timorese killed since Indonesia invaded East Timor in December 1975. The situation, of course, is now totally intolerable.

PARA.TAB: Does the UN vision of a post-Cold War new world order apply to the suffering people of East Timor or not? Australia, indeed the world, demands the answers, for we are among the few nations to recognise the Indonesian annexation. The Indonesian version of this latest atrocity must be severely questioned, for these events were witnessed by two US journalists. Their account has been widely reported.

Our desire for cordial relations with Indonesia and the maintenance of the Timor Gap oil treaty must not obscure our national responsibilities towards human rights, especially in our own region. It is insufficient to simply condemn this atrocity and further to demand an inquiry conducted by the Indonesian Government.

The UN Secretary-General should now intervene and the UN Security Council should debate the situation and status of East Timor. Our Australian Government should press for: firstly, Indonesian acceptance of the Portuguese parliamentary mission; secondly, debate of the issue at the United Nations Security Council; and, thirdly, a UN task force to report on East Timor. After 16 years of ambivalence, it is time that the new world order delivered for the East Timorese.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Royal Commission into the Building Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —The New South Wales Royal Commission into the Building Industry has uncovered an appalling story of institutionalised corruption at all levels by builders, subcontractors, unions and industry organisations.

PARA.TAB: Many millions of dollars of public money have been stolen, particularly by collusive tendering rings organised by industry associations. Corrupt tendering processes have been facilitated by selective and closed tendering procedures adopted by Commonwealth, State and local governments. Corruption has flourished with the abandonment of traditional safeguards of public tendering and public scrutiny of the tendering process.

From 1987-88 to 1990-91, the project services division of the Australian Construction Services awarded contracts worth over $750m. Yet the percentage of works let by public tenders has fallen from 55 per cent four years ago to only 5 per cent today. It is incredible that, despite the evidence of recent royal commissions and inquiries around Australia, the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has rejected a public opening of tenders and espouses secrecy and deal making—a certain formula for continuing corruption.

Public works must be carried out primarily by public tenders awarded to the lowest tenderer unless acceptance of a higher tender can be openly justified. The Minister's defence of secrecy is an open door to corruption and his reliance on statutory declarations to guard against collusive tendering is naive at best.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I have written to the US President, George Bush, to ask him to use the outstanding ability that he has demonstrated on international affairs to clean up the United States agricultural policy that is impacting unfairly on Australian farmers. I believe that only the President can bring into line the United States Congress and the Senate, which have shown little courage or integrity, and it seems that the US politicians that are bankrolled by the farm lobby are—
—They are wimps.

—Exactly! They are wimps and are prostituting the very principles of free trade that we as leaders of the Cairns Group are trying to press forward in the finals of the Uruguay Round. I am sure that, if the President backs a decent policy, he will succeed. I certainly hope that he responds to Australia because we have demonstrated as allies not only that we are fair dinkum but also that we are the best the United States has got. I do not think it is too much to ask on behalf of Aussie farmers.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware of the statement by the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services about the Government's third runway decision—`I am not bound by the Cabinet decision'? Does the Prime Minister's peculiar version of government include any principle of collective ministerial responsibility? Does the Prime Minister expect the Minister to follow the example of the honourable member for Barton and resign from the Ministry or will the Prime Minister roll over and let the Minister openly challenge his rapidly vanishing authority?

—I was totally aware of the particular interest and concern that the Minister in question had about this issue. He was given the opportunity, together with another member of the back bench, to put to—
—He is front bench, by the way.

—I am saying that he, with another member of the back bench, spoke to the Cabinet last evening and made, from his point of view, I believe, an effective presentation of his concerns. He did it very responsibly. The processes have now been undertaken by the Cabinet having made a decision—a decision which has been endorsed by the Cabinet. I expect totally that the Minister in question will be in line with the decision of the Government.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. What response has the Government received to representations to the Indonesian Government about the tragedy in East Timor? What further information has come to light about these events?

—I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question. I am sure that all members of the House would be interested to know the developments of which we are aware, and I certainly want to share those with the honourable member and with the House.
