PARA.TAB: Since I spoke to the House yesterday on this issue our Government has discussed at very high levels with the Indonesian Government the appalling events in Dili yesterday. Yesterday afternoon our Ambassador in Jakarta, Mr Phillip Flood, met General Moerdani, who is Acting Foreign Minister as well as Minister for Defence and Security, and Senator Evans had long talks in Seoul with Mr Alatas, the Foreign Minister for Indonesia. In both these discussions, Australia expressed the points that I outlined to this House yesterday: we are deeply disturbed by the tragedy in Dili and deplore the loss of innocent life; we want an urgent account of what happened there; we want a full inquiry into the circumstances and that those found responsible be appropriately dealt with.

In their responses, General Moerdani and Mr Alatas expressed deep concern and regret at what had occurred and understanding of the strong reaction that we in Australia have felt and have expressed about those events in Dili. In his long discussion with Senator Evans, Mr Alatas agreed on the need for a full and internationally credible inquiry and recognised the potential of the incident to undermine Indonesia's efforts to improve the situation in East Timor. The Commander of Indonesian's armed forces, General Sutrisno, has publicly expressed his regret at the deaths and he has promised a thorough investigation.

The Government welcomes these indications that Indonesia is responding positively to the concerns that we and other members of the international community have expressed about the events of Tuesday. I must say that I am disappointed that they were not more fully reflected in the statement released last night by the Indonesian Embassy. We will, of course, continue to press our concerns and we will take a close interest in the manner in which the inquiry into the shootings is conducted, as well as in the conclusions and the action which follows.

Turning to the second part of the question, General Sutrisno is reported to have told journalists in Jakarta yesterday that at the most 50 people died in the incident. I want to stress that, whatever the final number of casualties, it is obvious that an appalling tragedy has occurred. It does not depend on what the final number is; an appalling tragedy has occurred.

Both General Moerdani and Mr Alatas have given us accounts of what occurred based on preliminary information which is available to them. In addition, I am pleased to say that our Embassy official arrived in Dili yesterday afternoon and he will stay in Dili for several days so that he can speak to as many people as possible about the incident. It still is not possible to speak with any certainty about many of the details of the incident.

The Indonesian authorities are continuing with their inquiries and are awaiting the return of a number of key personnel from Dili. The Indonesian authorities have said that the incident was provoked by an attack on an Indonesian military officer. Other witnesses claim that there was no provocation. We are continuing to investigate these and other aspects of the incident, including with non-government sources. It would be unwise to comment further until we have more detail.

Nonetheless, I hope it will be recognised that whatever provocation may have occurred—we do not say that any did; but it is important to say that whatever provocation may have occurred, if any—the response by the Indonesian military has been tragically excessive. I believe, in saying that, I would be reflecting the views not only of all members of this House but of the people of this country. I conclude by saying this: after all these years it is clear that the problems of East Timor are not going to be solved by military force.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

We were permitted to do that on the basis that we would not be bound by that Cabinet decision. That was the basis on which we addressed the Cabinet on that occasion.
—You have to do better than that.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order!

—Is the Treasurer aware of recent published critiques of market economics? Could he outline to the House the Government's approach to economic reform? Can it be characterised as being based on laissez faire economics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question goes to the serious question of the philosophy and objectives of economic reform. The clear objective of economic policy is to raise the standard of living of all Australians. This Government holds, however, that an additional objective is to ensure that the process of economic change and reform is not disproportionately carried by those in the community least able to protect themselves.

PARA.TAB: It is a fact that those who argue for the unbridled and uncontrolled operation of markets in this country are arguing, in effect, for economic and social chaos. They propose a grand experiment, not with test tubes or white laboratory mice, but rather with the lives and values and preferences of the men and women of urban, regional and country Australia. They therefore display the characteristics of the cynic who, in the words of Oscar Wilde, `knows the price of everything but the value of nothing'. The cold, computer-driven conservatives!

It was with interest that I read a recently published criticism of laissez faire economics. This criticism impressed me—indeed, it amazed me—because it was written with force and depth rarely observed in Australian intellectual life.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—Come on, Brian. What is happening here?
—Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.
—Someone will have to go.
—The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.
—The quote that has provoked the question by the honourable member for Hinkler is:

ANSWER.PARA: Are we going to risk the hopes, the achievements, the dreams and the aspirations of 17 million Australians on a theory of level playing field, economic rationalism, computer modelling laissez faire economics?

Must we accept a better Australia means risking the very economic foundations on which this nation has been built over one hundred years? We don't have to bulldoze down those structures and rebuild the economy brick by brick.

I rarely agree with the Leader of the National Party in the Senate, Senator Ron Boswell, whose quote it is; however, I agree with him more—once—than he agrees with the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the National Party—never.

PARA.TAB: I made the point yesterday, as did the Prime Minister, that the Nationals are desperate to shed the cloth of neo-conservative rationalism. After all, the definition of a National Party member is merely `a pork barrel in disguise'. We had it yesterday—the Queensland push signalled to the Leader of the National Party, through Bob Katter Jr, that his leadership days are numbered. This was reinforced over the weekend by Senator Ron Boswell, who dumped in a huge way on the National Party Leader. Again I quote:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the great leaders of the National Party from Sir Earle Page, John McEwen to Doug Anthony, fought and won those victories for rural and regional Australia.

PARA.TAB: Mr Bradford interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for McPherson will cease interjecting.

—Further, I am told that the honourable member for Dawson is so concerned about the introduction of a consumption tax, which would hit hardest those in his electorate, that he is considering resigning from the National Party in order to start up his Independent National group. I conclude by providing some advice to the Leader of the Opposition and the not so great Leader of the National Party: never, ever trust the Nationals.
—You are so wrong.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. In view of the answer of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, will the Prime Minister detail the terms of the agreement that he had with that Minister as to the nature of his participation in the third runway debate? Who was the other Minister who was referred to by the Minister for Higher Education? Does the Prime Minister accept what the Minister has just said—that he is not bound by the Cabinet decision?
—Let me make quite clear what the position is—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are used to this senseless guffaw. I will wait until it has subsided, and then I will tell Opposition members what the position is—and I trust that the Minister understands it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —If Opposition members will contain themselves, I believe the position will be seen by them and even understood by them. I repeat what I said: the Minister, not in his capacity as Minister, but as the—
—Oh, come on!
—This is unreal.
—Order! The House will come to order. The Prime Minister has been asked a question by the Leader of the Opposition; he is answering the question, and the House will listen to the answer.

—But in terms of the representation of his electorate he had very deep concerns about what he understood was the decision that was going to be considered by the Cabinet. I had a discussion with him; he wanted to speak and I made it clear to him that an opportunity could be provided. He normally would not have been at the Cabinet meeting. I made the decision not just in respect of him; I knew that there were a number of members in the Sydney region who were concerned about this issue—in my judgment, understandably concerned—and I decided that they should have the opportunity to make a presentation to the Cabinet. The Minister in question was there in that capacity, not as a member of the Ministry. That was the capacity in which he attended. Normally, he would not have been at the Cabinet meeting.

PARA.TAB: A number of backbenchers were interested in this issue in their capacity as members representing areas around the airport. I said—and it was agreed by my colleagues in the Cabinet—that they should have the opportunity of making a presentation. Mr Baldwin was there in that capacity, and he spoke. After he and the honourable member for Barton, who had the same opportunity, had spoken, they left the Cabinet room and played no part in the decision. My point in doing that was to ensure that Mr Baldwin, in that capacity, was able to make his presentation and when the matter went to Caucus he would not be bound, having been there and made that presentation, but would be totally free in the Caucus to argue his case and vote. This was an eminently sensible and fair thing to do. It was done by me with the support of the Cabinet. But the position now is that Mr Baldwin and every member of the Caucus are bound by the Government decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources, who is the Acting Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, aware of recent claims that Australian ports are now amongst the most efficient grain loading ports in the world? Are these claims correct? What benefits have flowed to Australian grain growers as a result of the Government's micro-economic reforms to grain transport and loading?

—I have seen claims that Australian ports are now amongst the most efficient grain handling ports in the world, and in this instance these claims were made not by the Government but by the Australian Wheat Board in a press statement issued on 4 November. The Australian Wheat Board, in its statement, describes the improvements evidenced on the waterfront as `spectacular', noting that since 1988-89 the time taken to turn grain vessels around at Australian ports has dropped from an average of 4.52 days to 2.4 days, almost a 50 per cent reduction, cutting in half the turnaround time, and representing, importantly, savings of some $10m per annum.

PARA.TAB: Importantly, the Director of the Wheat Board says that reduction in loading time and the consequent cost savings have resulted from the Australian Wheat Board's enthusiastic adoption of the reform principles negotiated with the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, stevedoring industry unions and employers and, importantly, the cooperation of the work force at the ports in question. This stands in stark contrast to the Opposition's `fix bayonets' policy of waterfront reform, wherein the Leader of the Opposition, amongst others, has indicated that the appropriate course to follow is to send in the troops. There is no doubt that, at a time when the grains industry is facing enormous difficulties, the Government's micro-economic reform package is bearing fruit. It is substantially reducing the cost of grain handling at the waterfront and there is a significant flow-on effect in the reduction of shipping freight costs.

Mr Speaker, you and honourable members will recall that when the Government put grain handling on the waterfront reform agenda, through the reforms recommended by the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport, and also via the Inter-State Commission waterfront report, and when the Government set in train the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority process, which has made possible these spectacular gains through a negotiated process, the Government was vigorously opposed by all members opposite.

Everyone in this House will recall—and if perchance they forget, I invite them to have recourse to Hansard on this matter—the deep divisions between the Liberal and National parties on this issue. There was a total, chronic inability to put the national interests first in backing a vital program of micro-economic reform. This Opposition had to be dragged kicking and screaming, as Hansard will attest, to this fundamental reform.

There are two messages from these `spectacular' gains. The first message is that the Government's micro-economic reforms are working and they are providing real benefits to grain growers at a time of great difficulty for them. The second is that it highlights the enormous gap, indeed the chasm, between Government substance and Opposition rhetoric.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again addressed to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I ask the Minister again in his capacity as a member of the Hawke Government: does he withdraw his statement made last night that he is not bound by the Cabinet decision; and does he now totally endorse the Government's third runway decision? If not, when will he resign?

—The Prime Minister's description of the Government's decision making processes is essentially accurate. It is an outcome which I argued against strongly and which I regret, but I simply endorse what the Prime Minister has said by way of the Government's decision making processes. I am not going to add anything further to a matter outside of my ministerial responsibilities.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Can the Minister inform the House of the success of the existing labour market programs in assisting the unemployed into jobs even during the present recession?

—I thank the honourable member for Prospect for her question. I am aware not only of the very keen interest she has in this area but also of the terrific job she is doing in assisting particularly the young people in her electorate. The honourable member for Prospect asked about the efficacy of labour market programs conducted and delivered by my Department. The Department has done some important work on just this area, comparing how many program participants in the labour market programs have jobs three months after they complete their placements and how many DSS beneficiaries generally who have moved from social security payments into the labour market over the same period of time have jobs. These figures show that those individuals who participate in labour market programs are much more likely to be in jobs than social security beneficiaries as a whole, even those who have been unemployed for the same period of time.

PARA.TAB: Specifically, in August of 1991 for those unemployed for up to six months, 49 per cent of Jobstart participants were still employed three months after they had finished their Jobstart placement and, overall, 36 per cent of labour market program participants had jobs compared with just 13 per cent of those beneficiaries as a whole who had moved into employment. The figures are even more stark for those people who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer, as 47 per cent of Jobstart participants still had jobs three months after they had completed their placements and 21 per cent of those in labour market programs in general compared with just 3 per cent of those who were general DSS beneficiaries.

So, whilst it may well be true that the recession has made it very much more difficult for the unemployed and particularly the long term unemployed to find jobs, those people who have the opportunity to participate in labour market programs, and particularly in the Jobstart program, have very much better chances of getting jobs. The announcements that the Prime Minister will be making this afternoon will indicate further enhancements to these programs generally, and we make these changes in the sure knowledge that these programs will be of particular benefit to those who participate in them. I take the opportunity of tabling a chart which indicates the efficacy of these programs in the way in which I have described.

In conclusion, whilst we can anticipate that members opposite will have lots to say on the question of employment and unemployment this afternoon—and they have a crocodile tears-type topic to put up in the context of a matter of public importance this afternoon—it ought to be very clear to everyone just exactly where those opposite are coming from in relation to assistance to the unemployed. If we go back to what those opposite said in the context of their economic action plan and to what they said in the context of the last Budget, it is perfectly clear that one of the areas which has been targeted as an area of expenditure reduction is precisely this area of assistance to the unemployed. They have in mind a dramatic reduction of some $288m in expenditure programs, which will deny assistance to something like 150,000 unemployed people.

So, whilst we can expect to see some mock anguish on the part of those opposite this afternoon, let it be perfectly clear that this Opposition has but one thing in mind—to rip away support and to deny additional support to these people whom we are trying to assist in this difficult period. Let me make it clear that the support that members opposite are intending to rip away, the support extension that they are denying, is real and beneficial support as demonstrated by these figures that I have read out. This is not some kind of trivial support. This is meaningful support to unemployed people, people in real need; it is assisting them back into the labour market.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed again to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I ask the Minister again in his capacity as a member of the Hawke Government: does the Minister acknowledge, without qualification, that he is bound by the Cabinet's decision on the third runway—yes or no?
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Resign!
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Kooyong!
—My question is addressed to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The Minister would be aware of some concerns expressed in my electorate regarding people with disabilities.
—How many backbenchers got into your Cabinet meetings, John?
—Order! The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will cease interjecting!
—I ask the Minister: can he inform the House what steps he is taking to reassure the community concerning the Government's intentions for services for people with disabilities?
—Quite a few.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong!
—In fact, when Malcolm was—
—Order! If the honourable member for Bennelong continues to interject, I will—
—I am not. I am having a conversation.
—I warn the honourable member for Bennelong! If he wants to have a conversation, he can go outside. If he continues to have the conversation, he might be sent out.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am certainly aware of his interest in disabilities and the concerns that he has conveyed to me concerning possible changes in direction in this program. Only this morning at a major meeting of service providers, the ACROD National Convention, I spoke about the Government's considerable achievements in relation to disability services and its intentions with regard to the future. The Government's disability services program, as honourable members will know, is a key aspect of its commitment to social justice and particularly social justice for this group of people who often have been denied the opportunity for full participation in the community.

PARA.TAB: This morning I announced that the Government would be amending the Disability Services Act to lay permanently to rest the anxiety about services closing after June 1992. The amendments will remove the June 1992 deadline and, hence, provide for the continued funding of services which meet basic levels of service. Organisations will have more time to make the changes necessary to provide a good quality service, one which reflects the basic human rights of people with a disability and that gives them more say in how the services work.

I also announced that the extension of time would be linked to other changes designed to help services continue to work towards meeting the requirements of the Disability Services Act. There will be three key steps. The first will be minimum outcomes or basic human rights such as people with disabilities being supported to set up workers' committees where they work or residents' committees where they live; in other words, the opportunity for people in the various workshops and services to have access to basic rights, to air grievances and to have that grievance dealt with in a way which is seen to be fair.

Secondly, there will be enhanced outcomes or more advanced standards, such as improved wage levels for people in sheltered workshops. People who know anything about this area know that wage levels in sheltered workshops are extraordinarily low, often averaging about $30 a week, and that they have no relationship at all to any productivity contributed by people with disabilities. Thirdly, there will be eligibility outcomes or full implementation of the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act, such as integration into open employment.

Services which have not met minimum outcomes by June 1992 will be subject to sanctions, including no access to indexation and transition funds. All service providers will generally be expected to reach eligibility outcomes by June 1995.

The Disability Services Act is one of the Government's most significant reforms. It has resulted in significant changes in the attitude to people with disabilities and in the qualities of service being provided. A large number of new services—over 100—are being funded. There has been about a 60 per cent real increase in funding for services for people with disabilities.

I believe the strategy I announced this morning will be successful. It will enable us to build on what has already been achieved under the Act. At the same time, it will deal with those concerns expressed by some service providers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith Airport), Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In view of the failure of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services to publicly support his Government's decision on the third runway without qualification, will the Prime Minister require him to make an unequivocal public statement of support for his Government's decision or will he require the Minister to resign?
—I am glad that the Leader of the Opposition has returned to this question for two reasons: first, it enables me to dispose of this question, and then—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Secondly, it enables me to reveal his unbridled hypocrisy. I made the position quite clear in my statement in this House a while ago. I repeat it so that, just perhaps, the Leader of the Opposition might understand. The situation is that Mr Baldwin had the opportunity of speaking to Cabinet; and he spoke. He spoke on the basis that when he left after he had spoken he was not bound in terms of the subsequent Caucus consideration of that matter by the decision of the Cabinet. He still had open his position to argue in the Caucus a position different to that adopted by the Cabinet. He exercised that right, but once the Caucus had considered that Cabinet decision, and that was endorsed by the Caucus, then not only Mr Baldwin but every other member of the Caucus was bound by the decision. In his statement in answer to the question he said that he accepted my exposition, as he must do.

PARA.TAB: Having disposed of that, let me expose the hypocrisy of the Leader of the Opposition. I ask rhetorically whether the Leader of the Opposition has carpeted the honourable member for Bennelong, because the honourable member for Bennelong publicly exposed much of his private reservations about the political judgment of the Leader of the Opposition. He went to the National Press Club; he indicated that he has a different view about this question of State tax. He has indicated that he thinks that the position that I and the Government have adopted is right. But, of course, in agreeing with me, he disagrees with his Leader.

Honourable members will recall that last week—and then, under pressure, this week—the Leader of the Opposition totally identified himself with the proposition that the States should have a right to levy an income tax. That is the position of the Leader of the Opposition. The honourable member for Bennelong—a member of his front bench—explicitly and publicly repudiated it. Instead of worrying about some fictitious problem that I am supposed to have with Mr Baldwin, I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition try to get some degree of orderliness, uniformity and consistency on his front bench—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition doesn't have a formal position on that issue.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—On the question of whether the States should have the right to have an income tax, I hope only that the Leader of the Opposition continues to adhere to his view, that he overcomes the objections of the honourable member for Bennelong and that the position of the Opposition maintains one of being that he supports the right of the States to have an income tax. Sort the honourable member for Bennelong out; we have no problems on our side.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Transport and Communications been drawn to reports that Evergreen Airlines proposes operating airline services to Australia? If there is any substance to those reports, what information can he provide to the House on the Government's intentions in respect of that matter?
—I did notice—
—Why don't you sell Tullamarine while you are at it?
—Order! If the honourable member for Bruce continues to interject, I will name him.

—I noticed reports in the paper today which suggested that some understanding had been given by the Government to Evergreen Airlines that there would be an opportunity for it to act as our second international carrier. Those reports are totally without foundation. This is not a matter that has had a great deal of public debate, but it is a fact that there have been discussions between the Victorian Government and the principal of Evergreen Airlines from time to time on what type of role it might play in the Victorian area. A set of quite interesting proposals are on the table in that regard.

PARA.TAB: These things have always been made absolutely clear by the Government to the Victorian Government and also to representatives of Evergreen Airlines: first, that the Australian Government has made a clear-cut decision on the issue of designation of a second carrier. We have said that, for the life of this Parliament at least—and that does not anticipate a change of policy—there will be one designated passenger carrier operating from Australia, and that will be Qantas. We will not be designating anyone else.

We have also made clear to airlines operating to Australia—and Evergreen is now one of those—the terms of the agreement we now have with Taiwan, which is going extremely well and which has been one of the many advances in international aviation that we have made during the course of this year. Under that agreement, the principals of Evergreen are, as are the principals of any other international airline operating to Australia, entitled if they wish to bid for 25 per cent of Australian Airlines when it comes on the market.

Of course, if they are principals of airlines that do not operate to Australia or, for that matter, any other foreign businessman, they are entitled to look at a higher percentage than that. But 25 per cent is that limitation. Of course, they would be very welcome to do that if they wanted to express their interest in that and involve themselves. But there is no implicit or explicit government undertaking that there will be an opportunity, by virtue of such an investment, to then participate in a second designated carrier. I would not anticipate the Government going down the road of a second designated passenger carrier from this country. But if anyone were to turn his mind to that subsequently, I imagine that it would be quite clear that that opportunity would be tendered, not granted. As I said, that is not saying that we have any intentions in that regard at all. So there could be no anticipation. As I said, there has been no understanding—explicit, implicit or whatever—that such an opportunity will arise.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Ministerial Responsibility: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, Third Runway

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again addressed to the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I refer the Minister to a previous answer in Question Time this afternoon in which he referred to the Prime Minister's description of the Government's decision making process as essentially accurate, and then failed to give an unequivocal statement of support for the Government's third runway decision. I ask the Minister three questions. How is the Prime Minister's description of the decision making processes inaccurate? Second, did the honourable member do a radio interview after the Cabinet and Caucus processes were completed yesterday in which he said he was not bound by the Cabinet decision? And third, will he now give an unequivocal statement of support for the Government's decision on the third runway?

—The Leader of the Opposition is really starting to go into cracked record mode, isn't he? How many times am I going to have to reiterate what I have already said? The Prime Minister's description of the Government decision making process is accurate. I said that two questions ago. I simply am not going to add anything further to that, and that is the same answer the honourable member will get every subsequent time he asks this question.

—My question is of the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 11 November reporting comments by the South Australian Minister for Marine and Harbours, Mr Bob Gregory, expressing concern with a Federal Government decision to close down four Spencer Gulf navigational aids, and claiming that this action has been taken without consultation with the South Australian Government. Can the Minister advise what consultative process has been involved with the decision to discontinue these navigation aids, and the reasons for the decision?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. He has raised this matter with me. Since late last year the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, AMSA, has been consulting with the South Australian Department of Marine and Harbours on the proposed decommissioning of four navigation aids located in the northern Spencer Gulf.

PARA.TAB: AMSA is responsible for meeting the Commonwealth's responsibility for providing the navigation aids network to meet the needs of commercial shipping; that is, large merchant vessels. All costs of operating this network are met by the commercial shipping industry through payment of the marine navigation levy. Navigation aids which support rivers and inner waterways and those specifically for fishing and pleasure craft are provided by State governments or the local authorities that are concerned.

In reviewing the navigation aids provided in the Spencer Gulf, AMSA relied on advice from the Maritime Services Advisory Committee on Navigational Safety, a consultative body drawn from the shipping industry which provides advice to AMSA, amongst other things, on changes in the navigation aids network. The Committee consulted its respective associations and shipmasters transiting the Spencer Gulf and, in October last year, confirmed to AMSA that the commercial shipping industry did not have a continuing requirement for those four navigation aids.

There are a number of other Commonwealth and State navigation aids in the northern Spencer Gulf marking hazards and allowing fixing of position on the recommended shipping tracks and port approaches. One of the four aids concerned, the Middle Bank beacon, is redundant because of overlapping coverage provided by other lights. The other three lights are not required for navigation by commercial ships. In fact, two of the three are ageing structures in poor condition and are considered hazardous to AMSA maintenance staff.

Hence AMSA proposes to decommission these four navigation aids, rather than continue to impose their cost on the commercial shipping industry, unless the State Department of Marine and Harbours wants to take responsibility for them. I think the comments attributed to Mr Gregory indicate that these lights are needed as port approach beacons and to assist fishing and pleasure craft. As these are clearly State responsibilities, it is within the purview of his Department to take responsibility for them.

The concerns Mr Gregory and the local councils in the region have raised about this issue have been referred to AMSA. However, the bottom line for AMSA is continuing to impose a charge on commercial shipping for navigation services that commercial shipping does not require. Already the Chairman of the Australian National Maritime Association has been critical of the benefits of shipping reform being eaten away by increased State government charges, particularly port charges, and I think it is very important to ensure that that does not occur. Therefore, if the South Australian Government wishes these aids to continue—and it may have reason in the light of the circumstances in which it finds itself with pleasure craft in that area—then that is a matter it ought to wholly meet itself.

The situation is that if commercial shipping is obliged to pay for these aids then it is likely to kick up very strongly. I know the honourable member for Grey is a man of some substantial influence with the South Australian Government. I think it would be very helpful if he were to go along and have a bit of a chat with that Government and strongly advocate that if it sees real value in these services—and only it can know this from the pattern of usage of pleasure craft in the area—it would be sensible for it to spend the money on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HIGHER EDUCATION AND EMPLOYMENT SERVICES

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith—that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services no longer possesses the confidence of this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

—The activities today of this House in Question Time are indicative of what is the single most important failure of the Hawke Government, and that is the complete shambles and complete lack of authority that have been demonstrated by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to his Ministers. His Ministers in fact take it now almost as a God given right that they can speak out and take any public position on any issue irrespective of the decision making processes of the Government. What we saw today in Question Time was a Minister deliberately trying to duck the authority of the Prime Minister in relation to his responsibilities as a Minister of this Government.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, it has been a basic tenet of the practices of the Westminster system of government that there are very clear-cut standards and procedures in relation to the concept of ministerial responsibility. Might I just read from House of Representatives Practice, second edition, page 87, where the following quotation appears:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been generally agreed that among the principles implicit in the convention each Minister is required to abide by the following:
* he or she must be prepared not only to refrain from publicly criticising other Ministers and their actions but also to defend them publicly, or else resign.
It is as clear-cut as that. They must be prepared not only to refrain from publicly criticising other Ministers and their actions but also to defend them publicly, or else resign.

PARA.TAB: On several occasions this afternoon in Question Time the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) was given the opportunity to publicly and without qualification support the Government's decision in relation to the third runway, and he chose not to do it. In fact, he went as far as he could, I believe, in the context of Question Time, to maintain his independence on that issue. He went as far as he could to maintain his independence by drawing attention to the fact that the Prime Minister's description of the decision making processes in relation to Caucus and in relation to the Cabinet on the third runway were only essentially accurate, not totally accurate. Then, of course, he refrained from giving the unequivocal commitment that is required of him in his position as a Minister to publicly support the position of a government.

We know, of course, that this decision that has been taken by this Government has had a very long and chequered history in relation to the Government showing a degree of sustained inactivity. It was a decision that we had taken in government back in 1982. The honourable member for Hume (Mr Fife), now Manager of Opposition Business in the House, then, as Minister, took that decision to government and supported the construction of the third runway.

This Government then ran in 1983 in opposition to the third runway decision. The members of the Government then spent the rest of the last seven to eight years fighting and scrapping amongst themselves to try to get that item back on the agenda and to take a decision which was, as I say, taken in 1982, and should have been taken at any time from then, particularly as our economy went into the worst recession in 60 years and there was a desperate need for this Government to come to grips with the economic malaise of this country and to show a little bit of leadership. But right through that period this issue has fundamentally divided this Government. What we have seen in recent days is a Prime Minister who is fundamentally weak, who lacks the necessary authority to continue as Prime Minister, and is unable to pull his Ministers into line on issues as important to this nation as the third runway.

This is just the last of what has been a series of public displays of weakness by our Prime Minister where he has allowed members of Cabinet to speak openly and to criticise his position, to differentiate their position on major Government policy issues, and he has been unable, on any occasion through that period—as he was again today—to pull them into line.

In the last couple of weeks, for example, we have seen Senator Richardson publicly criticise the Prime Minister and his leadership on several occasions, either directly or indirectly, in his role as campaign manager for the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who is the major leadership contender for the prime ministership of this country at the present time in the ALP. This week we saw the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) publicly announce that the Prime Minister would be making a statement about the Government's position on the State Premiers' proposal for revenue sharing. Those are two clear-cut examples of the Prime Minister's having had every opportunity to pull these people into line and, of course, of having refrained from doing so.

This example today is a clear cut example of what has been a succession of prime ministerial and ministerial failures that go to the very heart of this Government and its inability to govern this country. This Minister, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, has wilfully and knowingly, I believe, breached the agreed principles of Cabinet responsibility. It has come to our attention that yesterday evening, after the Cabinet and Caucus processes had taken their course, the Minister was quoted on radio as saying that he was not bound by the Cabinet decision. He went out knowingly to continue to support a position he had taken against what became the Government's decision on the construction of the third runway at Mascot. Called to account in the Parliament today, he was unable or unwilling to confirm publicly what he is required to do under the agreed principles of Cabinet responsibility, that is, to publicly support the position of the Government on a decision such as that.

It is pertinent to recognise that the Minister in question who is being censured has not got a sense of decency and sense of propriety, and does not give Parliament its due place in this public debate, because he has left the Parliament at this particular time and is not prepared to face the censure for his unwillingness to support the decision.

The position is clear cut. If he is not prepared to come out and publicly support this decision that the Government has taken to go ahead with the construction of the third runway, if he is not prepared to put aside his own personal views—I might say he seems to have been given a particularly wide berth in being able to put those personal views both publicly and privately up to the time the decision was taken—and if he is not prepared, now that the decision has been taken, to publicly stand up and defend the Government's position, to give unequivocal support to that position and to go out to defend that position, he is left with no choice but to resign under now what are well established and well agreed principles of ministerial responsibility.

I think it is interesting that there is probably more to this issue than has emerged in Question Time. When the Minister said that he thought the Prime Minister's description of what had happened was essentially accurate, he was tipping us off that in fact there were other elements to that agreement with the Prime Minister that had not yet come to light. It is interesting in this regard that an ex-Minister of this Government, the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), was on television this morning on the Today show and was asked this question by Mr Liebman:

SPEECH.PARA: Who sold you down the creek then?
To which he replied:
Well, it is reopening old wounds but I had undertakings from the Prime Minister that weren't honoured and that is simply the truth of the matter.

That begs the question as to whether the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services feels similarly cheated by our Prime Minister. I will tell honourable members what I think that deal was. I think the deal was that he would be allowed to campaign publicly, before the decision was taken, against the construction of the third runway; secondly, I think he was allowed to speak in the Cabinet meeting and to put his case; and I think that the third part of the deal, and the important part of the deal, which has in a sense been exposed here in the Parliament today, was that he could continue to speak and to campaign against that Government decision.

PARA.TAB: If we look at what he said last night on radio when he was asked the following question by a journalist:

SPEECH.PARA: Can you campaign against this?
we see that he said:
I am not bound by the Cabinet decision. My view is well known and my views are, I am sure you are all familiar with them.

It is a very clear-cut case; he says he is not bound by the Cabinet decision after the Government had taken its decision and after he had had his opportunity to put his case. From that we can conclude only one thing, that there was a deal with the Prime Minister and they hoped they would sneak by on the basis of his not being called to account. The Minister has no choice but to resign. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Is the motion seconded?

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion, and say that the only charitable interpretation which can be put on the fact that the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) is so cowardly that he is not in the House at this time to deal with this motion is that he has gone back to his office to type the letter of resignation which is owed to this Parliament. There is no doubt that the principle of Westminster convention and Cabinet solidarity has been totally breached by the actions of this Minister, not only in the last 24 hours but also in 2 1/2 years. Remember that it was in March 1989 that the Federal Cabinet made the initial decision to proceed with the third runway, and to proceed with it subject to the environmental considerations. The principle became clear cut when the Minister, as honourable member for Sydney, accepted his portfolio position and then decided to mount a sabotage campaign against the third runway. At each and every opportunity he used his position as Minister, his entitlements and his additional staff resources to mount a major campaign against the fundamental decision of the Federal Cabinet of March 1989 to proceed with the third runway.

PARA.TAB: This Minister has breached that principle every week he has been a Minister, and more so in the last two days. In supporting the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) I want to highlight the very real nub of this matter. Yes, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave some sort of deal to allow this outer Minister to enter Cabinet to argue the case against the third runway. The second aspect of that deal, we were told, was that he was also allowed to then go to Caucus to continue that debate. But the third aspect which the Prime Minister indicated was that after that Caucus broke up, after that decision was taken, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services was bound to the Cabinet and Caucus decision. Indeed, the Prime Minister added, `and so are all the other Caucus members', such as the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), and indeed the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay).

It was after the Cabinet and Caucus decisions that, we now suspect, there was a further deal. That further deal was that the Minister had a very special exemption to go back to his electorate and to continue to oppose the third runway decision. That was the answer the Minister gave to the first question by the Leader of the Opposition. That is the nub of the matter—he had a very special deal to go back to his electorate to say that `because of our very major concerns about the implications of the issue for our electorate, we were'—and I quote the Minister's answer to that question—`permitted to do that on the basis that we would not be bound by that Cabinet decision'. That was an explicit undertaking in the Prime Minister's deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —An unbelievable deal.

—It was an unbelievable deal. It was a total breach of the Westminster convention and one which should bring this Minister on to the floor of this House to utter the words, `I resign'. The honourable member for Barton had the courage to do that; he was honest enough to do that. The honourable member for Barton resigned over this very issue, yet this Minister skulks away to his room. I hope he will write the letter of resignation that this Parliament and this Prime Minister are entitled to. The Prime Minister should have the guts to demand it and should demand a bit of discipline from his Cabinet.

PARA.TAB: We all know that this Prime Minister has let go on the matter of Cabinet solidarity and discipline. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) plays golf with the Prime Minister in the morning and then spends the next day and night knifing him behind the scenes and counting the numbers. The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) can go off and torpedo the new federalism process. Minister after Minister can breach Cabinet solidarity. This Minister has been caught red-handed by the questions of the Leader of the Opposition and has been caught red-handed at breaching Cabinet solidarity. He should now resign.
Opposition members interjecting—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—Until members of the Opposition remain silent, I will not call the Leader of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having watched the moronic performance of members of the Opposition during Question Time when they got their questions out of order, as far as I can see the last bunch of people I will take advice from on parliamentary tactics is that lot. Let me dispose of this matter very quickly. The simple fact of the matter is that there is no case to answer. The reason why we have taken the unusual action of allowing this to be debated as a suspension of standing and sessional orders rather than as a censure motion, is as a matter of courtesy to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). He moved that the standing and sessional orders ought to be suspended. Generally speaking, we would accept a censure motion where we thought there was any particular point in it. If we were not going to accept it, we would knock off a suspension of standing and sessional orders without debate. But because the Leader of the Opposition moved it, we allowed him to argue his point on the suspension of standing and sessional orders.

PARA.TAB: As I have had occasion to remark in the past, members of the Opposition have massively devalued the censure motion process. Therefore, they have put themselves in a position where it is impossible to take them seriously. They were absolutely 100 per cent dead wrong on the answers they were given in Question Time. As far as we are concerned, the notion that this Government ought to find itself under any sense of obligation to accept a censure motion from them, goes straight out the window.

As I had occasion to remark here before, what a difference this is from the days of Bob Menzies when there would be about one censure motion a parliament. We cop an average of one a week from the Opposition—not because there is substance to it but because of the ignorance of the parliamentary and governing process of the Opposition. What did the Leader of the Opposition have? The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) came into this place and was asked the following question: do you agree with the analysis of events by the Prime Minister? This concluded with the fact that the Minister was bound by any decision taken by the Caucus on this matter. The Prime Minister made that clear. Every member of Caucus, including the Minister for Higher Education, is bound by the decision taken by Caucus.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mayo!

—It is confirmed by the person who was the subject of this censure motion, the Minister for Higher Education. That is the end of the matter. If the Minister for Higher Education had got up here and said, `No, I am not bound; I don't accept the Caucus decision'—or whatever—then that would create a different situation. That was not the answer the Opposition got. When he was first questioned by the Leader of the Opposition on what his attitude was to the Cabinet decision, he said, `I did not support the Cabinet decision'. This was taken to be a very meaningful statement by all members of the Opposition. They said, `Oh, he didn't support the Cabinet decision; the man ought to be sacked immediately'. For the information of honourable members opposite, he is not a member of the Cabinet. Under our rules, which they well know, when a matter is debated subsequent to a Cabinet meeting in Caucus, all members of the Cabinet are bound to support that position during Caucus discussion.
—The honourable member for Mayo!

—People who are not members of the Cabinet are not bound to support Cabinet decisions when Caucus discussion proceeds. When we come to the conclusion of the consideration by Caucus, the rule that we have that applies to us is that all members of the Caucus are bound by that decision. Because we have taken a Caucus decision on the subject of the third runway, every member of this Party, including the Minister for Higher Education, is bound by that decision. He then confirmed it—
—He didn't confirm it.
—He did. He confirmed that in two answers.
—The honourable member for Mackellar!

—The explanation that I have just given is precisely the question. He was asked whether he was bound by it. I have just told those opposite exactly what the Prime Minister said to them, if they are capable of understanding what was put to them.
—I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—He confirmed that that was the case; that is, he is bound by the decisions that are taken by the Caucus. Under our rules—this is another important part of that procedure—if a junior Minister comes into the Cabinet and participates in the whole of the Cabinet debate—
—These are just rules you have made up.
—I warn the honourable member for Mayo.

—With all due respect, those opposite are not the arbiters of convention; they are the breachers of convention. We do not accept any particular set of their definitions of what a convention is. I am telling them exactly the processes that we go through; that is, if a member of the junior Ministry participates in a full Cabinet debate and proceeds to the conclusion of that Cabinet debate, then he is as bound as any Cabinet Minister by that process.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, if the Minister had stayed in the Cabinet for the conclusion of the Cabinet debate then he would have been in exactly that position. He would have been bound as any Cabinet Minister in the subsequent discussion in Caucus. Because he was not there when the matter subsequently came before Caucus for discussion, he was free to vote and do as he pleased in that regard.

Let us not cavil at these sorts of things. Members of the Opposition mucked up their tactics during Question Time today. We are not going to allow them any particular award that they do not deserve from any of the answers that they have been given. They have been given straightforward answers. The conclusion of those answers, unrepudiated, is that all members of Caucus are abiding by the Caucus decisions that were taken by the Government at that stage. As individual members of Caucus, they are entitled to take any particular position on this sort of issue prior to that point. They utilise their rights to do so and they utilise their rights to do that publicly.

During the last couple of years the Minister for Higher Education was placed on a collision course with his colleagues and the rest of us when we decided that, subject to a satisfactory environmental outcome, we would proceed with the third runway at Mascot. He has made his position on that absolutely clear over the last couple of years. He has been entitled to make his position on that absolutely clear over the last couple of years, as has the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), the honourable member for Barton (Mr Punch), the Speaker, and one or two other honourable members who have had concerns in that area. They are entitled to defend what they perceive to be the interests of their constituents as vigorously as they can.

We, as a democratic party, proceeded through the processes of our decision making on this matter. I might say that on this matter we are the only government that has arrived at a complete solution to the requirements of aviation at Kingsford-Smith Airport. The Opposition has never been able to take a position on a parallel runway at Kingsford-Smith that would actually have advanced the capacity of the airport to sustain operations. The Opposition's proposal would not have done that. With our proposal we will be able to sustain effectively the benefits of a parallel runway operation—and we have also enabled the selection of a second airport site.

It is no wonder that Opposition members come into this place with bluster and blaggarding, with a totally irrelevant censure motion, totally unjustified by the answers that were given to them in Question Time. They wish to conceal the real consequences of the decisions taken by the Government in Caucus yesterday—a major step forward in micro-economic reform in the aviation sector which Opposition members were never capable of delivering. The fact that they have been incapable of delivering that is a matter of no little distress to their various spokesmen, and indeed shadow Ministers, from time to time.

We on our side of the House do not have to give any form of respectability at all to the Opposition's grief in that matter. We particularly do not have to give any explanation as far as this matter is concerned. In Question Time the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services made his position quite clear, which was that he accepted the definition that he was free to oppose Cabinet decisions when they went to Caucus and he is now bound by decisions of the Caucus in regard to this matter. (Time expired)
Question put:
That the motion (Dr Hewson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, taking account of your duty of office to ensure that members of this House get to and from Parliament without undue difficulty, can you assure the House that you acknowledge that you are bound by the Government's decision to build the third runway at Sydney Airport?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that the honourable member for Sturt might have been aware of standing order 152 which provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: A question without notice may be put to the Speaker relating to any matter of administration for which he is responsible.
