TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Prime Minister.
—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—We will have personal explanations later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr Speaker, Australia today is at a point of historic convergence: the hurt of the recession is at its maximum impact; yet, simultaneously, and by no means coincidentally, the gains and rewards of the long hard process of restructuring are within our grasp.

PARA.TAB: The immediate focus of this statement is on the problem of unemployment. But through that prism, I want today to look ahead—to the prospects and promise for this nation.

In this statement today I bring to the people of Australia a message of fundamental confidence. It is a message grounded firmly on the facts, not only the factual evidence of recovery, but upon the most important fact of all—that the work of this Government over the years, and the response of the Australian people, have brought us together to the threshold of a new era of achievement.

In the specific context of unemployment, let me begin with this unqualified assertion: this Labor Government has an unalterable commitment to preventing the present levels of unemployment from becoming a permanent feature of the Australian economy and the Australian society. I say to this House what I have said repeatedly outside: I have not spent the whole of my 33 years in public life in the Labor movement of Australia to acquiesce in allowing the present high levels of unemployment to continue.

Some weeks ago, I initiated an examination of what action the Government could take to respond to the current severe unemployment situation. In the same period, the members of the Parliamentary Labor Party's working group on unemployment, under the chairmanship of the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), have worked with great diligence to produce a constructive report, and I thank them for it. Further, in accordance with undertakings I gave in my address to the ACTU Congress in September, I met with representatives of the ACTU on 29 October to consider their proposals to alleviate unemployment. I have also had the benefit of consultation within the Economic Planning Advisory Council, and I take this opportunity of thanking all members of EPAC for their constructive contributions to the discussion on this matter.
As an outcome of our analyses and these consultations, I shall be detailing, later in this statement, measures related to the unemployment problem.
These measures build on the strategy for reducing unemployment already put in place by the Budget. The measures include:

initiatives in the post—secondary area to ensure that our young men and women have access to training in the long term as well as in the short term. High quality investment in additional training now will deliver a work force better suited to the challenges of the future;

a further expansion of labour market programs to assist the unemployed obtain and upgrade skills. This will not only help prepare for the recovery but will ensure a proper safety net is provided for those who have been most affected by the recession;

the acceleration of infrastructure projects in the areas of road, rail, post-secondary education, and science, with benefits for our traded goods industries and for the quality of teaching and research in our educational and scientific institutions; and
facilitation of the development of new industries and restructuring of existing industries.
These measures total some $313m in calendar year 1992. They are measures which meet the critical tests of advancing our economic strategy, while maintaining the integrity of the Budget.

Since the Budget, we have been carefully watching economic developments to ensure that the Budget strategy for sustainable recovery with low inflation is on track. It is on track, and we are determined that it stay on track. This Government will not be diverted from its fundamental economic strategy and its goals:
sustainable recovery to provide sustainable job growth, and rising living standards; and
above all, the goal of building an internationally competitive economy.

There may be some who would argue that the Government, satisfied as it is that the fundamental economic strategy is on track, should pay no regard to the representations of the ACTU, and others, on the matters dealt with in this statement.

Not only do I reject that argument, but I go further. The very fact that our strategy is on track—the fact that the great objective of creating a restructured, low inflation, internationally competitive economy is now within our grasp—is in large measure a result of the constructive cooperation and restraint that have been practised by the working men and women of Australia. That is, precisely, a reason to listen to those who represent them.

Their members have experienced unemployment, not only through the recession, but through the process of long term industrial restructuring we are pursuing. Yet in the representations they have made to us they have not asked for this process to be slowed. They understand, accept and are committed to its continuation, in the knowledge that it is in the long term interest of their country.

And, of course, Mr Speaker, the views of the union movement reflect the growing concern at all levels of the community, as the statistical projection of unemployment of more than 10 per cent, made in May, has become the harsh reality.

Nobody feels this concern more deeply than I. It is a concern fully shared by every member of my Government. That is why we accept it as our inescapable duty to take whatever action we responsibly can to restore sustainable job growth as soon as possible.

Given this Government's unsurpassed record of job creation since 1983, there can be no doubt about our commitment to this goal and our capacity to achieve it. This is a Government which from its inception has been absolutely committed to sustainable job growth.

Budget-time forecasts were for growth of around 3 3/4 per cent through the course of 1991-92. The main sources of growth were expected to be business restocking, housing investment, and moderate growth in private consumption. Net exports were also expected to contribute to growth.

Indicators available since the Budget support those forecasts: we are coming out of recession. The early stages of recovery are clearly evident in the trend growth now apparent in the housing and retail sectors, and there are now positive signs pointing to recovery in other sectors. Building approvals for private dwellings increased by around 15 per cent in the September quarter. Retail sales have shown renewed strength, growing by 2.9 per cent in real terms in the September quarter. Indexes of consumer sentiment are significantly above their levels of a year ago. Business surveys indicate that the outlook for sales, profits, and investment is beginning to improve.

Our international trading performance has improved markedly. We are on track to record a current account deficit in the order of $14 billion in 1991-92, considerably lower than in recent years both in absolute terms and as a proportion of GDP.

While unemployment has reached unacceptable levels, the level of employment has stabilised in the last four months, halting the falls in employment that have been occurring since mid-1990. The recent improving trend in full time employment is encouraging.

All this is consistent with the view that the economy is in the early stages of recovery. This is not to deny that unemployment may rise further. But the essential point is that the evidence of the recovery has begun to appear.

A central objective of the Budget strategy is to ensure that, as the recovery proceeds, the Budget will move back into surplus. This will free national savings for productive investment by the private sector. In this way, the current account will be safeguarded and the economy set on a sustainable growth path.

Since the Budget was drawn up, the immediate risk that private calls on national savings would grow faster than public calls were falling has lessened. This lessening is attributable to two main factors:
first, the forecast reductions in inflation have been factored into community expectations more rapidly than we had hoped;
and second, there has been a worsening of the drought, leading us to be less sanguine about prospects for the rural sector.
These domestic developments have taken place against the background of some uncertainties about the economic prospects for our major trading partners.

The changes have not been of a magnitude to cause us to revise the Budget forecasts for overall activity. However, they have reduced the risk that any supplementary measures would see the public sector's call on national resources become unsustainably high. This reduced risk is particularly true of measures targeted to the period immediately ahead.
In short, there is now some scope to do more to prepare for new jobs and opportunities.
But, Mr Speaker, we must continue to recognise the limits which responsible economic management imposes, at this critical point in the recovery.

To fail to do so would be to throw away the real gains which underlie the present economic situation, and which underpin the splendid prospects ahead for this nation, as a strong, competitive, low inflation economy, enmeshing itself in the economies of the world's fastest growing region.
To maximise the benefit to the economy at this stage of the cycle, the measures I announce today are concentrated in calendar year 1992 and, wherever possible, in the first half of 1992.
I have said that a major thrust of these measures is directed towards expansion of education and training programs.
In this area, I announce today proposals involving gross expenditure in calendar year 1992 of $130m.

Education and training are basic to the Government's strategy of building a competitive Australia. And they are basic to the more immediate hopes and aspirations of many thousands of individual Australians, especially among our young people.

Community demand for education and training is at its highest level ever. The proportion of our young people remaining to the end of secondary school has virtually doubled in a decade and student numbers at our universities have risen by over 50 per cent.

A different situation, however, applies in vocational education and training, including TAFE. While student demand for TAFE and training has continued to increase strongly, labour market conditions and budgetary priorities of State governments, who have the responsibility in this area, have combined to limit the training opportunities made available in this essential sector. In consequence, the level of unmet demand for TAFE has risen steeply in recent years.

This situation demands urgent action. I must say, Mr Speaker, that one of the major disappointments arising from the Premiers' decision not to attend the Special Premiers Conference in Perth next week is that it will make resolution of these problems even more difficult.

The problem has been highlighted, may I say, dramatically and with extraordinary competence by the Finn report on post-compulsory education and training. The Finn report poses major challenges for all governments, State and Commonwealth. We must respond to these challenges. It is time TAFE took its rightful place within the education system of Australia.

The Government has decided to provide extra funding in 1992 to enable additional enrolments in post-school education, mainly in TAFE. In total, a sum of $115m will be provided for post-secondary education and training. A further $15m in higher education capital funding will be brought forward from 1994. This additional funding will be allocated mainly to provide additional TAFE places, and to meet urgent needs for equipment and building refurbishment in both TAFE and universities.

For 1992, the Government expects that these measures will provide an additional 40,000 students with opportunities to gain vocational skills. The States will be required at least to maintain their expenditure in real terms in 1992, pending the negotiation of longer term arrangements. They have also agreed to cooperate in maximising the number of places provided from the additional Commonwealth funding.

Looking to the longer term, the Commonwealth will continue to pursue its offer to the States of a new set of funding arrangements for vocational education and training, designed to upgrade the capacity and status of our TAFE and training institutions. I see this as an urgent national priority. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and I will do everything immediately within our power to pursue this priority.

Mr Speaker, the unemployed have borne the heaviest cost of the recession. Despite the economic recovery which is now under way, the number of long term unemployed will continue to rise for some time to come. If we are to harness in full the opportunities provided by recovery, we must strengthen the skills of job seekers and particularly the long term unemployed. It makes economic sense to do so—by ensuring that skills shortages do not emerge during the recovery.
More importantly, social justice demands that we do so.

Today, I announce enhancements to the employment access program, Skillshare and the self-employment assistance program to enable larger numbers of the long term unemployed to obtain the skills needed to take advantage of new job and business opportunities as these emerge from the recovery.
The enhancements will provide increased opportunities for some 56,000 unemployed people in 1992, including:
an increase in training places that will prepare an additional 31,000 people for labour market re-entry;
an increase in the Jobstart program, providing an additional 15,500 job subsidy placements;
an increase in the special intervention program to provide an additional 9,000 especially disadvantaged with assistance early in their period of unemployment.

With these enhancements, in addition to those announced with the implementation of the Newstart program, at least 300,000 unemployed people will be assisted by the CES through labour market programs in 1992.

This additional assistance will involve gross expenditure of $78m in 1991-92, and $124m in 1992-93. This will raise total labour market program expenditure from $400m in 1990-91 to an estimated $774m in 1992-93—which is a 94 per cent increase.

We have identified areas where some major Commonwealth infrastructure spending could be accelerated—spending which would have occurred anyway because of its essential nature or high economic returns for the nation.
Today I announce expenditures totalling $112m in calendar year 1992 to improve our economic infrastructure.
Such improvements will bear directly on the competitiveness of our export sector.

The task of internationalising the Australian economy requires an internationally competitive transport infrastructure. This year, we have made major advances in this area with the establishment of the National Rail Corporation; the National Road Transport Commission; and continuing rapid reform of our shipping industry and dramatic developments in the reform of our waterfront industry.

We will bring forward $82m of roads expenditure on the national highway system and arterial roads, and provide $20m for what will become the rail network of the NRC. This spending will provide industry with a better, more efficient transport system. In doing so, it will support the continued expansion of our export sector. At the same time, it will provide a direct boost to employment and confidence.

I also announce today that we will provide $10m immediately to CSIRO to upgrade its facilities. These funds will be fully spent in 1992. This decision will ensure that CSIRO researchers will have the physical infrastructure necessary to maintain their vital—and constructive—work.
The Government is acutely aware of the problems that are being encountered as the Australian economy undertakes its essential restructuring:
our exporters are entering new, highly competitive markets;
many of our traditional firms are confronting radical change and a requirement to make substantial new investments;
new firms are struggling to establish themselves and often new technologies.
Today I announce measures designed to assist in each of these areas.

The Government will allocate an additional $10m to the development import finance facility (Diff) in 1992. The funds will enable us to offer finance to Australian firms for significant new projects in China, India and South East Asia.

The decision will allow the Diff to meet more of the demand on its funds. The existing backlog meant that projects in power, communications, transport and resource processing had been held over. In all those sectors, Australia is rapidly establishing international competitiveness—and of course, Mr Speaker, while those projects will be undertaken in these other countries, the undertaking of those jobs will mean significant employment increases within Australia and the creation of additional opportunities in the future for Australian investment and job growth.

Mr Speaker, since my March statement, a number of companies in the textile, clothing and footwear industries have demonstrated their commitment to the Government's objective of creating strong and viable industries—industries which will be competitive and in which jobs will be secure.

To reinforce this commitment, the Government will bring forward $15m in calendar year 1992, to be available for restructuring purposes approved by the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority.

The Australian Industry Development Corporation (Aidc) has recorded a profit of $9.6m for 1990-91. The Corporation has asked to retain this profit as additional capital to help meet the demand for equity in new project development. We recognise that additional capital is needed particularly for new investments in resource processing. The Government has therefore agreed that the profit should be retained by the Corporation.

The Government has also decided to extend the Commonwealth guarantee on the Corporation's liabilities to 1998. This recognises the importance of the Corporation's role in industry development, by enabling it to minimise its borrowing costs.

In the March statement, I announced a major extension of sales tax exemptions available to business. The legislation is currently before the Senate. Allowing for the flow-on effects of reducing costs earlier in the production chain, the exemptions will provide a total benefit to business of more than $1 billion in a full year.

Mr Speaker, my statement today focuses, and properly does so at this time, on the matter of most immediate concern to the people of Australia, the problem of unemployment. I do not seek to disguise the magnitude of the problem. And we should all acknowledge the fact that even when the recovery is fully under way, and job growth restored, substantial reduction of unemployment levels will take time. To grasp this reality, one only has to recall the post-recession experience last time. Even when this Government had achieved average job creation of 230,000 a year, as it did over the period to mid-1990, the associated fall in unemployment was gradual compared with the spectacular growth in jobs.

But in acknowledging that, let me say, Mr Speaker, it is time, beyond time, to stop talking down the Australian economy. The central fact is that the Budget strategy is on course. The economy is recovering. And we will emerge from the recession with a stronger economy than before.
Let me illustrate this truth by pointing to the results of the structural reforms we have already achieved.

Exports of manufactured goods have increased by 112 per cent in real terms since 1983-84. Within manufacturing, exports of manufactured metals have risen by 62 per cent and exports of the more complex non-metal manufactured goods have increased by 147 per cent. Over the same period, exports of services have increased by 77 per cent.

The official Oecd statistics show that Australia's manufactured export performance in the past five years has been by far the best in the Oecd. They show that, in real terms, annual growth of manufactured exports has averaged over 15 per cent in Australia compared with the Oecd average of 6 per cent. Australia's rate of manufactured export growth has even outpaced that of the four newly industrialising economies of Asia—south Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong. These trends emerged well before the recession and have continued throughout the recession.
These facts are a remarkable tribute to the drive and the initiative of much of our business sector. It is a performance which presents an example and a challenge to the whole business community.
As I have indicated, the performance in many service areas, notably tourism, has also been strong.
Overseas tourist arrivals have more than doubled in just five years. The number—this is a remarkable figure—is expected almost to treble again by the year 2000, to around six million.
These projections lend compelling force to the Government's decisions in relation to aviation.

Following yesterday's decision by Federal Cabinet to approve the construction of a third runway at Sydney Airport, the Federal Airports Corporation expects preliminary work to begin within a month and major construction contracts to be let early next year.

As well as generating many thousands of sustainable new jobs at the airport and in directly related activities in the years ahead, the third runway will provide the capacity to meet the projected strong growth in tourist traffic.

In addition, the Government will shortly examine a proposal for the development of a general aviation airport at Badgerys Creek, Sydney's designated international airport. Based on preliminary design work already completed, it is envisaged that this new aerodrome would be operational in 1994.
The strong performance in the manufacturing and service industries has been buttressed by the continuing strength of the mining sector.
My Government has recently announced a new process aimed at encouraging major development projects including mining and minerals processing, agriculture and forestry.
The process for approving major projects in these areas will be speeded up, although I emphasise that proper environmental standards and Aboriginal and heritage issues will not be bypassed.
The strength of the manufacturing, services and mining industries stands, unfortunately, in sharp contrast to the current plight of the rural sector.
Many farmers have been hit by drought, compounding the severe downturn in farm prices, caused mainly by the trade war between the European Community and the United States.

As part of our commitment to easing the burden on the rural sector, the Government has massively increased funding for the rural adjustment scheme—from $62m in 1990-91 to $173m in 1991-92, which is a 179 per cent increase. Further, we have just announced arrangements to link rural adjustment scheme assessments to social security benefits.

It has to be acknowledged, however, that enduring relief will not occur unless there is liberalisation of agricultural trade. The farmers of Australia can be assured that this Government will continue to do all we can, in the coming crucial weeks of the Uruguay Round, to ensure it reaches a successful conclusion.

As I said at the outset, we now have an historic opportunity to move into the twenty-first century with a dynamic, reinvigorated, modern Australian economy. We have a unique opportunity to break the cycle of boom and bust. We have the opportunity to become one of the vibrant growth economies of the Asia-pacific region.

To seize this historic opportunity, we as a Government and a nation must embrace a set of key objectives and policies, designed to reinforce and accelerate the internationalisation of the Australian economy.
Australia's course is clear.
We must lock in the gains of low inflation. We must keep our nerve and resist demands for artificial solutions to the recession.
We must ensure that new investment continues to flow into our competitive, international industries with the economic recovery.
We must continue the vigorous pursuit of micro-economic reform.
We must continue the thrust towards the `clever country'. We must continue to assert maximum possible pressure for a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations.
We must, consistent with the commitment to growth, maintain in perpetuity our matchless environmental assets through policies for ecologically sustainable development.
That is this Government's national agenda for growth and reform. It is an agenda for jobs. It is an agenda for lasting, sustainable growth.
The measures I have announced today advance that agenda.

So today, Mr Speaker, I convey to the people of Australia a message of hope and confidence in the future of our great and unique nation. There is, simply, no nation in the world so well placed by virtue of its inner resources—its material resources, certainly, but much more important, its human, social and political resources—to weather the present storms, at home and abroad, and emerge from them, not only secure, but strengthened. Now is a time for strength of purpose, to ensure that Australia emerges from the recession with resilience, assured of its abilities, confident that it can take its place as a leading competitor in a tough, competitive world.

For our part, we in the Labor Government will not falter. We owe that to those who have suffered through the recession. We owe it to all Australians. We owe it to the splendid future which is within the grasp of Australia, as we move towards the twenty-first century together.
Government members—hear, hear!

PARA.TAB: Additional funds for Employment Access Program (EAP), Self Employment Assistance Program (SEAP) and Formal Training Assistance (FTA) for the Skillshare program will increase the opportunities for unemployed persons, particularly the long-term unemployed, to access training and other programs appropriate to the current labour market conditions. Normal income support associated with these places will be provided under AUSTUDY.
Additional funds will also be advanced from 1994 for small scale renovations in higher education institutions. These projects are funded on a dollar for dollar basis with institutions.

PARA.TAB: In the March 1991 Statement "Building A Competitive Australia" the Government recommitted itself to the provision of up to $120m through the Industries Development Strategy for the TCF industries over the period to 30 June 1995. A number of companies have been in discussions with the Government and acceleration of the release of funds is warranted. (Currently $15m per annum is provided in the Forward Estimates for 1991-92 and 1992-93.) Projects approved by the TCFDA to be assisted under this Strategy will be announced by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce in due course.

DIFF assists Australian exporters of capital goods and services to compete against aid supported foreign suppliers in developing countries for government-owned, developmentally sound projects. DIFF takes the form of an aid grant which is used to soften the interest and payment terms of an export credit loan provided by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) to fund a development project. Projects are selected in consultation with the recipient developing country to ensure that they have the highest developmental priority.

The Government is to provide an interest subsidy to the ABC to enable borrowings of up to $15m to be made for this project—estimated to cost $44.5m. The subsidy (up to $1.5m per annum) will cover delay in the rationalisation in the Corporation's property portfolio in Melbourne and will ensure that construction of the project proceeds immediately.

The AIDC has determined its 1990-91 profit as $9.6m. The Government has agreed that the profit be retained in the Corporation to expand its scope for supporting development projects, rather than returned as a dividend to the Commonwealth as occurred in the previous year. (The 1991-92 Budget estimated a return of $8.8m.)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity of commenting, on behalf of the Opposition, on the parliamentary statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on what he calls the economy and employment. We do not need any more assessment of what we have had here this afternoon than that of his own colleagues: they sat there quietly; they sat their half asleep. There was a total lack of enthusiasm—a total lack of support—because they know, sad though it is, that this statement is little more than a joke. If the situation were not as serious as it is in relation to the pain and hardship of unemployment, this could be easily just accepted as a joke. But the situation is much worse than that and it calls for a much more substantive response than is within the capacity of either this Prime Minister or this Government.

PARA.TAB: This statement this afternoon is nothing more than a blatant political exercise. Think about it: where did it come from? Where did this statement originate? There is an attempt in the first page to explain some sort of chronology of events leading up to this statement. But this statement arose under the pressure of the leadership challenge of the ex-Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who, while the Prime Minister was over in Harare, made a couple of statements, publicly campaigned about unemployment and jobs and, of course, torpedoed the new federalism initiatives. The Prime Minister got on the plane to come home. He was under an enormous amount of pressure to do something positive. He got off the plane and said, `Well, I am going to have a jobs statement; I am going to make a statement about employment'. That is where it came from.

This is nothing more than a blatant political exercise. This statement has been cobbled together in the last couple of weeks to try to give it some semblance of responsibility and respectability. But there is nothing in there of any substance. This does not go to the heart of the unemployment problem in this country. This does nothing about the true plight of unemployment in this country. I doubt whether the Prime Minister has any concept of the magnitude of the unemployment situation in Australia today. If he has, I ask how he could start a speech with the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia today is at a point of historic convergence: the hurt of the recession is at its point of maximum impact; yet, simultaneously, and by no means coincidently, the gains and rewards of the long hard process of restructuring are within our grasp.

Can honourable members imagine the joy and comfort and the warm inner glow that those who are lining up on the unemployment rolls are today feeling when they hear about this historic convergence? They have no doubt about the first part of that convergence, that the hurt of the recession is at its point of maximum impact, but they will be totally cynical—as will everyone else in this country be totally cynical—about the claim that the long, hard process of restructuring is about to bring us any rewards. There are no rewards, and there are no answers in this document.

PARA.TAB: As I say, this is a blatant political exercise. It is designed to appear to do something about jobs. It is designed to appear to recapture the initiative that has been taken away by the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, while the Prime Minister was in Harare, and it does nothing to deal with the fundamental problem of unemployment in this country.

It is particularly important to note that the Prime Minister, having in his earlier remarks said that the immediate focus of this statement is on the problem of unemployment, went on to talk about himself and his job. He always puts his job far and away ahead of the jobs that need to be created for the nearly one million Australians who are unemployed as a result of his policies and as a result, of course, of the policies of the ex-Treasurer, who is sitting up there, I am pleased to see, in support of my statement—not necessarily in support of the Prime Minister's statement. As we go through the document we see how he focuses on his own role and he says—

TALK.START.PARA: —Cannot take it; come back.
—There goes the honourable member for Blaxland. The Prime Minister made the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: In the specific context of unemployment, let me begin with this unqualified assertion: this Labor Government has an unalterable commitment to preventing the present levels of unemployment from becoming a permanent feature of the Australian economy and the Australian society.
I can only think back to the statement he made in the course of the election campaign in 1983, when he said:
One in ten Australians out of work—a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago, and which no Australian Government should ever be forgiven for creating.

I could not agree more. He has had eight years in the job. The situation is markedly worse than the situation he inherited. He has done nothing about job creation in Australia. His monument today, 8 1/2 years into his term as Prime Minister, is nearly one million Australians unemployed.

PARA.TAB: As has been rightly said in the past, honourable members opposite can hardly call themselves a Labor Party or a Labor government if the only monument to show for it is one million unemployed. I make a prediction that this statement will go down in history with some of the other `world's greatest statements' and `world's greatest events' of the past. They are totally vacuous statements, absolutely without any sense of vision or direction, absolutely without any understanding of the nature of the problem.

Remember the great economic summit back in 1983? Then there were the tax summit in 1985, the priority one program of 1985, the billion trees program of 1989, the third term micro-reform agenda—and micro it was—and the new federalism initiative. There was absolutely no concept on any of those occasions as to the nature of the problem, and there is no concept today. This document does not even scratch the surface of what has to be done in Australia to deal with the problem of the unemployed.
The Prime Minister makes another opening remark:

SPEECH.PARA: The immediate focus of this Statement is on the problem of unemployment. But through that prism, I want today to look ahead—to the prospects and promise for this nation.

`Prism' was a very carefully chosen word. It distorts his vision very, very badly. He has absolutely no understanding of the nature of the unemployment situation in Australia today. As I said, there are nearly one million Australians presently unemployed as a result of this Government's policies.

PARA.TAB: But let us look at some of the components of that pain and hardship. The expression `one million unemployed' is getting a lot of currency, but it does gloss over the magnitude of some of the pain and hardship that really exists in Australian families today.

The latest statistics, for example, reveal that 226,000 people are unemployed from families where no-one has a job, which is an increase of 41 per cent in the last 12 months. There are 193,000 Australian children who live in homes where nobody has a job, which is an increase of 40 per cent in the last 12 months. There are 566,000 people who have now been unemployed for more than three months, which is an increase of 70 per cent in the last 12 months. A total of 219,000 people have been unemployed for more than a year, which is an increase of 74 per cent in just 12 months. One year ago the median duration of unemployment was 13 weeks; today it is 26 weeks. That starts to convey the magnitude of the unemployment problem and the pain and hardship that it brings for average Australians.

It is no wonder that Roy Morgan research shows that 28 per cent of Australians now fear losing their job, and 53 per cent fear not being able to find another one if they do lose their job. Unemployment is the single biggest issue in this country today, and one can only be appalled that in those circumstances this Prime Minister comes in with yet another vacuous statement which will do nothing to create jobs of any significance in this country in the remaining time that he will be in government.

The fact is that we are now locked into a level of unemployment in Australia that is nothing short of alarming. We have to go back to the 1930s to find an experience where our unemployment problems were as bad as they are today. One can take the Government's own model; one can use its assumptions. One can do projections out through the 1990s, and one will find that in 1995-96, for example—the middle of the decade—we will still have, under this Government's policies, nearly a 9 per cent unemployment rate in Australia. Think about it—another five years.

We are starting from a position where we already have 30 per cent youth unemployment; we already have that long term duration of unemployment, with the prospect of 300,000 Australians ending up as long term unemployed, and under this Government's policies we will not do much better than 9 per cent by the middle of the decade. Of course, even to get that number, in the Government's model, means further significant cuts in living standards of average Australians, a resumption of higher inflation and a current account deficit that blows out back towards 6 per cent of GDP. Think of the pain and hardship now, and try to imagine what it will be like in five years time under this policy—indeed, under the policies of this Government.

Against that background, to get a document like this, which does virtually nothing to create genuine and sustainable jobs, is nothing short of a tragedy. It shows the extent to which this Prime Minister is totally paralysed today in terms of his inability to put in place the decisions that are needed to actually give some hope to those who are unemployed in this country.

Let me go on and briefly talk about some of the measures the Prime Minister specifically refers to in this document. In doing so I think it is important to note that on the first page, of course, it is indicated that he got the clearance of the ACTU before he made any statement. The ACTU has the veto over this. One of the great challenges for the rank and file in the next election is to recognise, and to vote accordingly, that the leadership of the ACTU, along with the Government's leadership, is to be deserted. They should vote with their feet and demonstrate that they now have a total lack of confidence in that leadership, which obviously has not been in their best interests.

I notice Bill Kelty and his mates still have their jobs. But how many of the rank and file have lost their jobs while they played these stupid games with this Government in the way that this Government goes about its business?

It is also interesting to note on page 2 that the statement says that, despite the fact the Government is spending quite a lot of money, it is `maintaining the integrity of the Budget'. What on earth is `maintaining the integrity of the Budget'? It can keep spending more and more, but somehow it will maintain the integrity of the Budget. The fact is that the total package of measures the Prime Minister brought down today is unfunded.

Next week when we bring down our package, Government members will climb all over it to try to find a dollar here or a dollar there to say that we did not fully cover this with the funds. They will ask, `Where is the money coming from?'. I ask: where is the money coming from? In this statement we have a significant increase in Government expenditure, something to the tune of $390m on today's initiatives alone, which is fully unfunded.

Just in case honourable members have missed it, I point out that towards the end of the figuring there is another admission that sort of slots in, that the Government has actually spent nearly another $1 billion since the last Budget. So we are looking at somewhere around $1.6 billion or $1.7 billion of additional expenditure, all of it unfunded. There is a $1.7 billion hole on top of the $4.7 billion deficit, which I think is a hole, which was the essential feature of the Government's Budget on the last occasion.

It is very important that we recognise that this is nothing short of a blatant political document, an attempt to throw money at problems rather than deal with problems. Throwing money at problems has never solved anything in this country. What we have to do is get away from the Whitlam generation. He started that concept that everything could be free—free education, free health—and now we are going to have free jobs. It is easy to spend money, to throw money at problems. That is the fundamental problem with this country. We cannot create sustainable jobs in Australia by throwing money at the problem. We have to deal with the basic structural problems and inefficiencies of this country, a task that is way beyond this Government; it is way beyond its capacity to take the decisions that are required to turn this place around.

Nevertheless, against that background, I think we should be fair. There are some initiatives in this document that do go in the right direction. Some of the education and training initiatives should be funded but they should not mask the fact, which the Prime Minister tried to do, that the Government has no medium term concept of a viable education system for this country. They should not mask the fact that the Government has no medium term concept of how to run the TAFE institutions or how to fund them adequately to ensure standards of excellence in those institutions; they have always been, in a sense, political footballs that are kicked around by this Government.

Do not take from anything that I say that I endorse a vision behind these numbers. Nevertheless, it is important that we address the failures of the TAFE system. It is important that we make sure that they are adequately funded in the course of this decade. It is important that we make sure, in doing that, that we raise the quality of those institutions, that we do something about the industrial relations problems in those institutions, and we do something about the financial autonomy of those institutions. None of those problems are addressed in this document. The Government is simply throwing more money at them, but throwing more money around is not going to solve these major problems for this country.

We have only to look at some of the statements that have been made by the Government's own committees of inquiry. For example, Ivan Deveson said that we are now arguably at the back of the pack in skills formation relative to other OECD countries. Brian Finn in the Finn report says that training in Australia generally falls short of best international practice. The Government does not have any concept of how to improve the situation. When employers do not train people, the Government figures it can solve the problem with a levy. We really do need a fundamental rethink of training in this country and we need to address the problem in a significant way.

Similar statements can be made about education. Short term palliatives such as are contained in this document are not going to do anything about the fundamental problems with education in Australia—the phenomenal erosion of standards and concepts of excellence in education, including TAFE education. Similarly in labour market programs, the Government, always in trouble, spends more money. People are going to be better educated and better trained; they are simply not going to have any jobs to go to because this statement does nothing about creating jobs.

Perhaps the most offensive parts of the statement are the bits that deal with what the Government calls industry development. We can go through this document and really struggle to find out what the Government means by industry development. One of the decisions is that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is to get an interest rate subsidy to enable it to expand its borrowings to restructure its land portfolio in Melbourne. I am sure it will be of great comfort to the small to medium size businesses still struggling under 16 to 18 per cent interest rates to know that the ABC—another group of mates of this Government—has been able to get an interest rate subsidy to restructure its property portfolio in the midst of the worst recession in 60 years.
Similarly, the AIDC has apparently made some money this year—something like $9.6m.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is last year.

—I do not know how that happened. It has made some money, but it is allowed to keep it. All the businesses out there are going to say, `We start to get a bit ahead and they claw it off us. They do nothing about our cost disadvantages. They do nothing about corporate tax or the impact of the wholesale sales tax and other things on us. Yet it can look after the AIDC'. To what end? One is left to guess after reading this document.

PARA.TAB: Then there is the third runway decision. Finally the Government has taken the third runway decision. Having come into government on the back of a decision we took in 1982 to actually go ahead with the third runway, it has finally taken that decision—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nine years ago.

—Nine years down the track. It is pinning its hopes on this major project to actually turn the employment situation around in Australia. We have called since 1982 for that project to go ahead—and we are pleased to see it, in that sense—but what about all the other projects sitting out there that have been blocked as a result of various other deals that have been done by this Government with the green movement and the Aboriginal heritage movement? Where are all those other projects? The Government says, `Don't worry, we have restructured here. We have got a new decision for approving projects'.

PARA.TAB: It refers to the recent statement by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) headed `Government Acts on Impediments to Major Projects'. What a classic statement that was. The Government introduced a new process which it called the 45-day rule. The 45-day rule is that proposals are to be lodged with the Cabinet committee within 45 days of their receipt by the relevant Minister. On face value one is tempted to say, `That is not bad, within 45 days it will actually get into the Cabinet committee'. But then one realises that all the environmental procedures and the Aboriginal heritage procedures all take place before that piece of paper goes into that Cabinet committee. Of course it might take only 45 days to get from the Minister's office into that committee, but there is no time limit on the decision itself.

So we have a basis here for a repeat of the third runway. It was nine years for the third runway. With Coronation Hill we can go back to December 1986, when the conservation zone was established. Finally, the Government struggled with that decision and, in June this year, on the basis of Bula, it took the decision to knock it over. Again, it sent all the wrong signals to the business community about what has to be done in this country to turn things around.

Of course, the Government has got itself into a bit of a bind on the wholesale sales tax. It concedes our point, as it did in the March statement, that wholesale sales taxes really are a major cost impost on business, so the Government has started to try to take a few of them off business. We have $400m of these taxes which are going to be lifted off business, neglecting the fact that business people pay about $6 billion or $7 billion in wholesale sales tax, depending on which estimate is used?

TALK.START.PARA: —Double it on their figures.
—It tells us that the $400m it is going to take off is worth $1 billion in terms of cost impact on the business community—
—What is six worth, Ralph?

—What is $7 billion worth? We know $7 billion by 2 1/2 is about $16 billion, and that is what we are going to take off the business community when we abolish the wholesale sales tax as part of our tax reform package next week. I thank those opposite for conceding the argument. If it is worth starting, it is worth finishing. In that sense there are billions and billions of dollars that can be taken off the business community to create genuine capacity to create genuine jobs. Yesterday, my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), in anticipation of this package, took out some numbers in the Murphy model to see what impact there would be on unemployment if the Government were to spend a few hundred million dollars on infrastructure projects and other things. That is a pretty reasonable question. He used the Government's numbers again, of course, and did the exercise.

PARA.TAB: To be generous, let us say there was a $500m boost. This package is only about half of that or less. But with a boost somewhere between $250m to $500m, do honourable members know what that does for the unemployment rate in 1992-93? In percentage terms, it lowers it by somewhere between 0.01 and 0.03. If it starts at 10.55, it becomes 10.54 or 10.52. So all of that for a reduction of 0.03. Obviously the Government was not game to go anywhere near 0.05 because it thought it would be arrested for total incompetence when it comes to dealing with major economic problems in Australia such as unemployment.

The tragedy of this statement is that there is an alternative if one is prepared to take the right decisions, there is an alternative if one is prepared to provide a bit of leadership, and there are alternatives that one can take in the short term and in the long term to turn our economic circumstances around. We do not believe that there is any real alternative amongst the ones we hear bandied about. To bring about major and dramatic social change in Australia, we cannot tinker. Those opposite have tinkered for eight years and they have got one million unemployed. We have to make significant, major and fundamental change and we have to do it as a matter of urgency.

The evidence is there. We can go to any of the major studies that have been done, either by the Government's own body, the Industry Commission, or by the Business Council or others. The reform agenda is there. It is across the board. It involves trimming the size of government, privatising government business enterprises, and contracting out government businesses and the provision of government services. It involves tax reform. It involves, importantly, labour market reform—a genuine move to enterprise bargaining. It involves addressing all the cost disadvantages in the infrastructure industries, most of which are dominated of course by unions in the public sector in areas such as electricity generation and telecommunications. There is reform of the waterfront and all of those other areas. The package is there.

By the year 2000, on the Government's numbers we can boost economic activity by somewhere between 12 and 15 per cent or 16 per cent per year—$50 billion to $60 billion compared with a couple of hundred million dollars. That is what it is going to take to get full employment in this country.

I challenge the Government to make a commitment to full employment. There should be a hard-headed commitment to full employment. It is achievable in the course of this decade. The Government can halve the unemployment rate from 10 per cent to 5 per cent in the course of this decade, keep price stability and get its balance of payments and its debt under control, provided it is prepared to take some of those hard decisions. The options are there. The evidence is overwhelming. It has been supplied by those in the Government and outside the Government, yet the Government has fallen short on every one of those reform decisions.

We believe that there is no alternative to that major process of structural reform in this country. If some of those decisions are politically difficult, too bad. If the Government wants to run around trying to scare people in the course of the next 12 months about a reform agenda like that, we will constantly remind it of the magnitude of the problem it presently has—one million unemployed—and the fact that it is not going to do much about it in the course of its remaining time in office under the policies it has.

The Government does not need to be open and objective about this matter; it is going to take time to implement a reform agenda like that and for it to have effect. But it can do some things virtually straight away to turn this unemployment situation around. It could start, for example, by saying that there should be no more national wage cases; there should be no more wage increases in Australia unless they are matched by productivity.

If the Government goes straight to the workplace as a matter of urgency and starts to get wage increases that are based on productivity, then for the first time in a decade workers in Australia will have a chance of real increases in real incomes. They will have a chance to actually earn more. If it is backed up with a decent tax reform package, they will have a chance to take home more in their pockets. That could be done today.

The Government could provide the lead. What does it do? Just before the last Budget it stitched up a deal in the Lodge for a 5 or 6 per cent wage increase this year through to September 1992. That, together with the other wage increases that have been given since the latter part of 1989, will give the Government a 7 or 8 per cent real increase in wages right through the worst recession in 60 years. It is the biggest increase that has ever been given by way of wage increases in a recession and it is a major reason why unemployment has already gone to 10 per cent—it has added a couple of percentage points to that unemployment rate. It is a major reason why it has gone to 10 per cent; it is a major reason why the Government's Budget predicted—despite what the Prime Minister said—that unemployment will keep going up under the Government's policies and its neglect.

Over and above that, there are a lot of other things the Government can do. It ought to be worried about youth wages. It ought to be worried about youth unemployment, given that it is 30 per cent and one in three of the kids who are now doing their school certificates and other examinations around Australia are not going to get a job. A lot of those kids are not going to find jobs in the first half of the 1990s under the Government's policies. It has a responsibility to look at the possibility of doing something about youth wages.

The Government has so compressed the relativities in Australia that it has discriminated against youth. One of the great tragedies in this country was the monumental failure of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, when he was head of the storemen and packers. Honourable members will remember that he moved on wool classers and eliminated youth wages. What happened? They all lost their jobs. That is the Government's concept of dealing with unemployment. It can reverse that right now.

The Government can also do something about its mad compulsory superannuation scheme. We have demonstrated that taxing the business community will create more unemployment. The numbers are somewhere between 45,000 and 100,000, depending on what sort of assumptions one wants to make. That is the Government's concept. It says, `If you happen to be left in the work force, we might be able to deliver you superannuation down the track as long as your employer doesn't go broke'. It not only destroys the national savings decisions that have to be taken; it also destroys any incentive for people to prepare for their own retirement and it sends the business community, under even more pressure, towards the wall and creates more unemployment. The Government can fix that; it can design a new superannuation system. It can get much more universal coverage of superannuation. It can easily do it if it stops running the rorts and so on that are associated with that system at present.

Whenever these guys fail they resort to compulsion. The Government could not get a health system, so it introduced a compulsory Medicare levy. It could not get any training, so it introduced a compulsory levy. It believes in compulsory unionism and compulsion across the board. It is usually an admission of past failure when the Government resorts to compulsion.

Another thing the Government could do immediately is get through Cabinet all the things it blocked in the last few years—not just the third runway decision. It would send a very positive signal to the business community. People should watch the Government get off its tail and start to genuinely accelerate investment in this country. It could tell the business community it would support a Wesley Vale style pulp mill in Australia if somebody were to put it up and it would not block it on some notional deal that it had done with the green movement.

The Government could reverse the Coronation Hill decision straight away. Why does it not do that? It is only a small project; it would send a very positive signal. The business community would respond very positively in that sense. The Government has a three-mines uranium policy which the Prime Minister himself says is illogical, but he does not have the capacity, the courage or the guts to get it through his Cabinet. He is so paralysed that he cannot reverse what he knows to be illogical to produce something which could contribute to the creation of jobs.

We could go right through a very long list of projects that are sitting there, projects such as Marandoo, for example, which is still being held up. For nine months it has been promised that something would happen. Nothing has happened. It is a potential major iron ore development. The Government should think about the position in relation to projects like that today. It should go back and think about when the Pilbara was opened up and Hamersley Iron went in there. Two mines were opened, two towns were built and 320 kilometres of railways were built. A port was built and the first iron ore was shipped within 18 months. In 18 months the Government cannot even get to the first stage of the decision making process, let alone the 45-day rule.

Another area we have identified where the Government could do something about unemployment and jobs in the course of the 1990s is immigration. We have said that in the short term the Government has to face the reality that we are going to have to live with a significantly lower level of immigrants to Australia: firstly, because our capacity to absorb them is a lot less in a recession and we see a very significant percentage of them ending up on unemployment benefits, both compounding their pain and hardship and compounding the pain and hardship of other Australians with whom they have been competing to get a job; and, secondly, because a lot of them do not want to come any more. Why would anyone want to come to Australia in the midst of a recession when all that they can get from this Prime Minister is an inane policy statement that does nothing? It addresses nothing about the basic problems of unemployment in this country.

There are a number of short term things that can be done. The Government can start today. It can put those policies in place and it can make a significant impact on unemployment, but all that has to be a forerunner to the major package of structural reform measures that have to be put in place in this country. It is coming down to a very interesting contest between us and the Government going into the next election. We have had the political courage and the determination to do something about these problems in Australia. We have set the political and economic agenda in this country for the last 18 months. We have developed a package of measures that address the issues that I have talked about today. We are going to enjoy jamming it down the Government's throat during the next 12 or 18 months or however long it takes between now and the next election.

We are absolutely committed to restoring full employment in this country. We are absolutely committed to maintaining price stability in this country. We are absolutely committed to breaking down some of the inane government practices that the Government has embarked on—all this reliance on compulsion and centralised control, the mad cities fantasies and mad everything else fantasies. We have seen no solutions to problems, just somebody's fantasy, all backed up by some political deal to stitch up a constituency to keep the Prime Minister in his job.

We are absolutely dedicated to changing the basic structure of this country. We want a generational change of leadership, a generational change of ideas and a generational change of policies and attitudes in this country. That is what we are going to deliver. We are going to give people what they want in this country—that is, the right to a job and the best hope they have for self-respect and decency and the best hope this country has.
Opposition members—Hear, hear!
Debate (on motion by Mr Willis) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Does the honourable member claim to be misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do, in two respects.
—Please proceed.

—In this morning's Australian, an article starting on page one and going over to page six referred in part to some remarks I made at the National Press Club yesterday. In the material portion the report states:

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard said he applauded Dr Hewson and his leadership team for showing the political courage to push ahead with the GST package.
In praising Dr Hewson, Mr Howard offered a thinly veiled swipe at former Opposition leader Mr Andrew Peacock for adopting much softer policy options at the last election.

SPEECH.PARA: It then quotes me as saying:

PARA.TAB: `At various stages people have said: "Why don't you guys sit there, say nothing and fall into office, because the other mob are self destructing",' Mr Howard said.

SPEECH.PARA: I am then quoted as going on and describing such an approach as being a recipe for encouraging greater cynicism about politicians.

PARA.TAB: The misrepresentation is the suggestion that in some way those remarks were a reflection on my colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). That is an absurd proposition. I had in mind people out in the community who, at various stages, have said to me and to some of my colleagues, `We think your GST proposal is a great idea, but why don't you sort of keep it under wraps until you have got there'. Together with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the honourable member for Kooyong, everybody else on the front bench of the Opposition and elsewhere, I have rejected that proposition. I reject totally the suggestion that in any way that comment was an express or implied criticism of the honourable member for Kooyong.

The other area of misrepresentation occurs in a report in this morning's Australian Financial Review which suggests, under the absurd heading `Howard backs Hawke on State taxing powers', that in some way there is a difference of view amongst the Leader of the Opposition, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and me on the question of revenue sharing with the States. This theme was taken up in error and in distortion during Question Time by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and, in a supplementary way, I claim a further misrepresentation during Question Time.

The fact is, firstly, that the Opposition has not totally determined a completely definitive position on revenue sharing with the States. Therefore, the analogy which the Prime Minister sought rather pathetically to draw between the attitude of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) and the Cabinet decision of yesterday on the third runway and the comments made by me and the Opposition Leader on revenue sharing was absolutely erroneous—patently erroneous—to all in the House. But, more importantly, when the comments made by me and the Leader of the Opposition are analysed, the suggestion in the Financial Review, which revels in getting these things wrong I might say, is also absolutely erroneous. The Leader of the Opposition made it clear in a news conference on 18 November, when he said:
Well, we have put that as one of the options and we would be delighted to participate in the discussions in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Then critically he goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: We do not really see those powers as the issue. Tax sharing though has got a lot of an attraction where really they just get a prearranged proportion of the tax revenue that is raised. They don't get a separate taxing power.

SPEECH.PARA: When one analyses the remarks I have made, one will find that there is no substantive difference between what the Leader of the Opposition has said and what I have said. I reject both the headline and the substance of the article in the Financial Review and, most particularly, I reject the pathetic attempt of the Prime Minister to draw some analogy with our position on tax sharing and the total collapse of Cabinet solidarity so far as the Minister for Higher Education is concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Privileges Committee in connection with the matter referred to the Committee by the House on 11 September 1991, together with the minutes of proceedings of the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The report that I have just presented follows a decision of the House on 11 September to refer to the Privileges Committee the question of whether Mr Stephen Paddison of the State Bank of South Australia misled the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in an answer he gave to the Committee on 30 April in response to a question about non-performing loans and losses by the bank.

PARA.TAB: Mr Paddison, in his evidence to the Standing Committee, had been asked whether publicly stated figures of $2.5 billion worth of non-performing loans and approximately $1 billion lost by the bank were still applicable. In his answer, Mr Paddison stated, firstly, that he believed that any official confirmation of the banks loan projections was most appropriately carried out in the context of the bank's full year results. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: So I will not comment on that.
But he went on to say:

I did comment that I thought that we were feeling fairly comfortable with our assessment procedures in an environment such as we have now. If you were plus or minus 10 per cent, I think that you would feel that you had done a pretty reasonable job of estimation, and we are certainly within those parameters . . .'

The concern that this answer may have been misleading arose from information contained in a copy of a confidential memorandum signed by the General Manager of the bank and dated 21 March. An attachment to this memorandum showed that the management of the bank projected non-productive accounts to reach $3.48 billion by December 1992 and potential losses to reach $1.3 billion by that date.

PARA.TAB: The essence of the complaint was that it was reasonable to presume that Mr Paddison, as a senior officer of the bank, would have known of the memorandum of 21 March and the projections attached to it when he gave evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on 30 April. Mr Paddison confirmed, in evidence to the Committee, that he was so aware.

The Committee of Privileges received a written submission from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who had raised the matter in the House in the first instance. The Committee made this material available to Mr Paddison and arranged for him to appear before the Committee on 7 November.

Mr Paddison, in his evidence, expressed regret that the answer he had given resulted in the honourable member for Mayo forming the view that Mr Paddison had misled the Finance and Public Administration Committee. He said that it was not his intention to mislead the Committee or any person who heard or read his evidence.

Mr Paddison said that, with the advantage of time to reflect, he acknowledged that the clarity of his evidence had been compromised by his qualifying comment and that he had been trying to convey the impression that the bank's loan loss and assessment procedures were still regarded as essentially accurate. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that my evidence would have been enhanced by an explanation of the significance of the particular figures referred to by Mr Downer MHR—i.e. the net figures of $2.5 billion and the net present value loss of $1.0 billion. I apologise for not recognising at the time the desirability of ensuring such clarity.

Mr Paddison stated that the variance between the figures quoted to him by the honourable member for Mayo and those quoted in the attachment to the 21 March memorandum was explained by the fact that the figures quoted by the honourable member for Mayo were net figures, whereas the figures quoted from the 21 March memorandum to the Board were gross figures.

PARA.TAB: After examining Mr Paddison thoroughly on this matter, the Committee of Privileges has concluded that he did not intend to mislead the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Accordingly, the Committee has found that no contempt was committed by Mr Paddison. It recommends that the House take no further action on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a short comment on the statement of the Committee of Privileges. As stated by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello), the Committee examined Mr Paddison thoroughly on this matter. But it seemed to me that Mr Paddison's answer to the question of the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) was incomplete, rather than ambiguous as stated by the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, as honourable members know, there are a lot of pressures in this chamber and I was unable to reach the Committee meeting on time to contribute to the decision. I accept the decision. I want to say that I would have said that Mr Paddison's answer was incomplete. Of course, he could have provided more detail voluntarily in answer to the honourable member for Mayo. Then again, the Standing Committee could have asked him for more detail. I believe the responsibility was just as much on the Standing Committee to seek that detail as on Mr Paddison to provide it.

I support the view of the Committee that Mr Paddison did not intend to mislead the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration in his answer to the honourable member for Mayo. I accept the decision. I wanted to make the point that I believe that his answer was incomplete rather than ambiguous.
